Text

Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban

by J.K. Rowling

CHAPTER ONE

OWL POST

Harry Potter was a highly unusual boy in many ways. For one thing, he (Potter) hated the summer holidays more than any other time of year. For another, he (Potter) really wanted to do his (Potter) homework but was forced to do it in secret, in the dead of night. And he (Potter) also happened to be a wizard.

It was nearly midnight, and he (Potter) was lying on his (Potter) stomach in bed, the blankets drawn right over his (Potter) head like a tent, a flashlight in one hand and a large leather-bound book -LRB-A History of Magic by Bathilda Bagshot-RRB- propped open against the pillow. Harry moved the tip of his (Harry) eagle-feather quill down the page, frowning as he (Harry) looked for something that would help him (Harry) write his (Harry) essay,

``Witch Burning in the Fourteenth Century Was Completely Pointless discuss.'' (him)

The quill paused at the top of a likely-looking paragraph. Harry Pushed his (Harry) round glasses up the bridge of his (Harry) nose, moved his (Harry) flashlight closer to the book, and read:

Non-magic people -LRB-more commonly known as Muggles-RRB- were particularly afraid of magic in medieval times, but not very good at recognizing it. On the rare occasion that they did catch a real witch or wizard, burning had no effect whatsoever. The witch or wizard would perform a basic Flame Freezing Charm and then pretend to shriek with pain while enjoying a gentle, tickling sensation. Indeed, Wendelin the Weird enjoyed being burned so much that she (witch) allowed herself to be caught no less than fortyseven times in various disguises.

Harry put his (Harry) quill between his (Harry) teeth and reached underneath his (Harry) pillow for his (Harry) ink bottle and a roll of parchment. Slowly and very carefully he (Harry) unscrewed the ink bottle, dipped his (Harry) quill into it, and began to write, pausing every now and then to listen, because if any of the Dursleys heard the scratching of his (Harry) quill on their way to the bathroom, he (Harry)'d probably find himself locked in the cupboard under the stairs for the rest of the summer.

The Dursley family of number four, Privet Drive, was the reason that Harry never enjoyed his (Harry) summer holidays. Uncle Vernon, Aunt Petunia, and their son, Dudley, were Harry's only living relatives. They were Muggles, and they had a very medieval attitude toward magic. Harry's dead parents, who had been a witch and wizard themselves, were never mentioned under the Dursleys' roof For years, Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon had hoped that if they kept Harry as downtrodden as possible, they would be able to squash the magic out of him (Harry). To their fury, they had been unsuccessful. These days they lived in terror of anyone finding out that Harry had spent most of the last two years at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. The most they could do, however, was to lock away Harry's spellbooks, wand, cauldron, and broomstick at the start of the summer break, and forbid him (Harry) to talk to the neighbors.

This separation from his (Harry) spellbooks had been a real problem for Harry, because his (Harry) teachers at Hogwarts had given him (Harry) a lot of holiday work. One of the essays, a particularly nasty one about shrinking potions, was for Harry's least favorite teacher, Professor Snape, who would be delighted to have an excuse to give Harry detention for a month. Harry had therefore seized his (Harry) chance in the first week of the holidays. While Uncle Vernon, Aunt Petunia, and Dudley had gone out into the front garden to admire Uncle Vernon's new company car -LRB-in very loud voices, so that the rest of the street would notice it too-RRB-, Harry had crept downstairs, picked the lock on the cupboard under the stairs, grabbed some of his (Harry) books, and hidden them in his (Harry) bedroom. As long as he (Harry) didn't leave spots of ink on the sheets, the Dursleys need never know that he (Harry) was studying magic by night.

Harry was particularly keen to avoid trouble with his (Harry) aunt and uncle at the moment, as they were already in an especially bad mood with him (Harry), all because he (Harry)'d received a telephone call from a fellow wizard one week into the school vacation.

Ron Weasley, who was one of Harry's best friends at Hogwarts, came from a whole family of wizards. This meant that he (Harry) knew a lot of things Harry didn't, but had never used a telephone before. Most unluckily, it had been Uncle Vernon who had answered the call.

``Vernon Dursley speaking.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry, who happened to be in the room at the time, froze as he (Harry) heard Ron's voice answer.

``HELLO? HELLO? CAN YOU HEAR ME? I -- WANT -- TO -- TALK -- TO -- HARRY -- POTTER!'' (Ron)

Ron was yelling so loudly that Uncle Vernon jumped and held the receiver a foot away from his (Vernon) ear, staring at it with an expression of mingled fury and alarm.

``WHO IS THIS?'' (he)
he (Vernon) roared in the direction of the mouthpiece.
``WHO ARE YOU?'' (unknown)

``RON -- WEASLEY!'' (Ron)
Ron bellowed back, as though he (Ron) and Uncle Vernon were speaking from opposite ends of a football field. ``I'M -- A -- FRIEND -- OF -- HARRY
``S -- FROM -- SCHOOL --'' (Uncle)

Uncle Vernon's small eyes swiveled around to Harry, who was rooted to the spot.

``THERE IS NO HARRY POTTER HERE!'' (he)
he (Harry) roared, now holding the receiver at arm's length, as though frightened it might explode. ``I DON``T KNOW WHAT SCHOOL YOURE TALKING ABOUT! NEVER CONTACT ME AGAIN! DON
``T YOU COME NEAR MY FAMILY!'' (Don/DON)

And he (Harry) threw the receiver back onto the telephone as if dropping a poisonous spider.

The fight that had followed had been one of the worst ever.

``HOW DARE YOU GIVE THIS NUMBER TO PEOPLE LIKE -- PEOPLE LIKE YOU!'' (Uncle)
Uncle Vernon had roared, spraying Harry with spit.

Ron obviously realized that he (Ron)'d gotten Harry into trouble, because he (Harry) hadn't called again. Harry's other best friend from Hogwarts, Hermione Granger, hadn't been in touch either. Harry suspected that Ron had warned Hermione not to call, which was a pity, because Hermione, the cleverest witch in Harry's year, had Muggle parents, knew perfectly well how to use a telephone, and would probably have had enough sense not to say that she (Hermione) went to Hogwarts.

So Harry had had no word from any of his (Harry) wizarding friends for five long weeks, and this summer was turning out to be almost as bad as the last one. There was just one very small improvement -- after swearing that he (Harry) wouldn't use her (Hermione) to send letters to any of his (Harry) friends, Harry had been allowed to let his (Harry) owl, Hedwig, out at night. Uncle Vernon had given in because of the racket Hedwig made if she (Hedwig) was locked in her (Hedwig) cage all the time.

Harry finished writing about Wendelin the Weird and paused to listen again. The silence in the dark house was broken only by the distant, grunting snores of his (Harry) enormous cousin, Dudley. It must be very late, Harry thought. His (Harry) eyes were itching with tiredness. Perhaps he (Harry)'d finish this essay tomorrow night...

He (Harry) replaced the top of the ink bottle; pulled an old pillowcase from under his (Harry) bed; put the flashlight, A History of Magic, his (Harry) essay, quill, and ink inside it; got out of bed; and hid the lot under a loose floorboard under his (Harry) bed. Then he (Harry) stood up, stretched, and checked the time on the luminous alarm clock on his (Harry) bedside table.

It was one o'clock in the morning. Harry's stomach gave a funny jolt. He (Harry) had been thirteen years old, without realizing it, for a whole hour.

Yet another unusual thing about Harry was how little he (Harry) looked forward to his (Harry) birthdays. He (Harry) had never received a birthday card in his (Harry) life. The Dursleys had completely ignored his (Harry) last two birthdays, and he (Harry) had no reason to suppose they would remember this one.

Harry walked across the dark room, past Hedwig's large, empty cage, to the open window. He (Harry) leaned on the sill, the cool night air pleasant on his (Harry) face after a long time under the blankets. Hedwig had been absent for two nights now. Harry wasn't worried about her (Hedwig): she (Hedwig)'d been gone this long before. But he (Harry) hoped she (Hedwig)'d be back soon -- she (Hedwig) was the only living creature in this house who didn't flinch at the sight of him (Harry).

Harry, though still rather small and skinny for his (Harry) age, had grown a few inches over the last year. His (Harry) jet-black hair, however, was just as it always had been -- stubbornly untidy, whatever he (Harry) did to it. The eyes behind his (Harry) glasses were bright green, and on his (Harry) forehead, clearly visible through his (Harry) hair, was a thin scar, shaped like a bolt of lightning.

Of all the unusual things about Harry, this scar was the most extraordinary of all. It was not, as the Dursleys had pretended for ten years, a souvenir of the car crash that had killed Harry's parents, because Lily and James Potter had not died in a car crash. They had been murdered, murdered by the most feared Dark wizard for a hundred years, Lord Voldemort. Harry had escaped from the same attack with nothing more than a scar on his (Harry) forehead, where Voldemort's curse, instead of killing him (Harry), had rebounded upon its originator. Barely alive, Voldemort had fled...

But Harry had come face-to-face with him (Harry) at Hogwarts. Remembering their last meeting as he (Harry) stood at the dark window, Harry had to admit he (Harry) was lucky even to have reached his (Harry) thirteenth birthday.

He (Harry) scanned the starry sky for a sign of Hedwig, perhaps soaring

back to him (Harry) with a dead mouse dangling from her (Hedwig) beak, expecting praise. Gazing absently over the rooftops, it was a few seconds before Harry realized what he (Harry) was seeing.

Silhouetted against the golden moon, and growing larger every moment, was a large, strangely lopsided creature, and it was flapping in Harry's direction. He (Harry) stood quite still, watching it sink lower and lower. For a split second he (Harry) hesitated, his (Harry) hand on the window latch, wondering whether to slam it shut. But then the bizarre creature soared over one of the street lamps of Privet Drive, and Harry, realizing what it was, leapt aside.

Through the window soared three owls, two of them holding up the third, which appeared to be unconscious. They landed with a soft flump on Harry's bed, and the middle owl, which was large and gray, keeled right over and lay motionless. There was a large package tied to its legs.

Harry recognized the unconscious owl at once -- his (Harry) name was Errol, and he (Harry) belonged to the Weasley family. Harry dashed to the bed, untied the cords around Errol's legs, took off the parcel, and then carried Errol to Hedwig's cage. Errol opened one bleary eye, gave a feeble hoot of thanks, and began to gulp some water.

Harry turned back to the remaining owls. One of them, the large snowy female, was his (Harry) own Hedwig. She (Hedwig), too, was carrying a parcel and looked extremely pleased with herself. She (Hedwig) gave Harry an affectionate nip with her (Hedwig) beak as he (Harry) removed her (Hedwig) burden, then flew across the room to join Errol.

Harry didn't recognize the third owl, a handsome tawny one, but he (Harry) knew at once where it had come from, because in addition to a third package, it was carrying a letter bearing the Hogwarts crest. When Harry relieved this owl of its burden, it ruffled its feathers importantly, stretched its wings, and took off through the window into the night.

Harry sat down on his (Harry) bed and grabbed Errol's package, ripped off the brown paper, and discovered a present wrapped in gold, and his (Harry) first ever birthday card. Fingers trembling slightly, he (Harry) opened the envelope. Two pieces of paper fell out -- a letter and a newspaper clipping.

The clipping had clearly come out of the wizarding newspaper, the Daily Prophet, because the people in the black-and-white picture were moving. Harry picked up the clipping, smoothed it out, and read:

MINISTRY OF MAGIC EMPLOYEE SCOOPS GRAND PRIZE

Arthur Weasley, Head of the Misuse of Muggle Artifacts Office at the Ministry of Magic, has won the annual Daily Prophet Grand Prize Galleon Draw.

A delighted Mr. Weasley told the Daily Prophet,

``We will be spending the gold on a summer holiday in Egypt, where our eldest son, Bill, works as a curse breaker for Gringotts Wizarding Bank.'' (the Daily Prophet)

The Weasley family will be spending a month in Egypt, returning for the start of the new school year at Hogwarts, which five of the Weasley children currently attend.

Harry scanned the moving photograph, and a grin spread across his (Harry) face as he (Harry) saw all nine of the Weasleys waving furiously at him (Harry), standing in front of a large pyramid. Plump little Mrs. Weasley; tail, balding Mr. Weasley; six sons; and one daughter, all -LRB-though the black-and-white picture didn't show it-RRB- with flaming-red hair. Right in the middle of the picture was Ron, tall and gangling, with his (Ron) pet rat, Scabbers, on his (Ron) shoulder and his (Ron) arm around his (Ron) little sister, Ginny.

Harry couldn't think of anyone who deserved to win a large pile of gold more than the Weasleys, who were very nice and extremely poor. He (Harry) picked up Ron's letter and unfolded it.

Dear Harry,

Happy birthday!

Look, I' really sorry about that telephone call. I hope the Muggles didn't give you a hard time. I asked Dad, and he (Dad) reckons I shouldn't have shouted.

It's amazing here in Egypt. Bill's taken us around all the tombs and you wouldn't believe the curses those old Egyptian wizards put on them. Mum wouldn't let Ginny come in the last one. There were all these mutant skeletons in there, of Muggles who'd broken in and grown extra heads and stuff.

I couldn't believe it when Dad won the Daily Prophet Draw. Seven hundred galleons! Most of it's gone on this trip, but they're going to buy me a new wand for next year.

Harry remembered only too well the occasion when Ron's old wand had snapped. It had happened when the car the two of them had been flying to Hogwarts had crashed into a tree on the school grounds.

We'll be back about a week before term starts and we'll be going up to London to get my wand and our new books. Any chance of meeting you there?

Don't let the Muggles get you down!

Try and come to London,

Ron

P.S. Percy's Head Boy. He (Ron) got the letter last week.

Harry glanced back at the photograph. Percy, who was in his (Percy) seventh and final year at Hogwarts, was looking particularly smug. He (Hogwarts) had pinned his (Hogwarts) Head Boy badge to the fez perched jauntily on top of his (Hogwarts) neat hair, his (Hogwarts) horn-rimmed glasses flashing in the Egyptian sun.

Harry now turned to his (Harry) present and unwrapped it. Inside was what looked like a miniature glass spinning top. There was another note from Ron beneath it.

Harry -- this is a Pocket Sneakoscope. If there's someone untrustworthy around, it's supposed to light up and spin. Bill says it's rubbish sold for wizard tourists and isn't reliable, because it kept lighting up at dinner last night. But he (Bill) didn't realize Fred and George had put beetles in his (Fred) soup.

Bye --

Ron

Harry put the Pocket Sneakoscope on his (Harry) bedside table, where it stood quite still, balanced on its point, reflecting the luminous hands of his (Harry) clock. He (Harry) looked at it happily for a few seconds, then picked up the parcel Hedwig had brought.

Inside this, too, there was a wrapped present, a card, and a letter, this time from Hermione.

Dear Harry,

Ron wrote to me and told me about his (Harry) phone call to your Uncle Vernon. I do hope you're all right.

I'm on holiday in France at the moment and I didn't know how I was going to send this to you -- what if they'd opened it at customs? -- but then Hedwig turned up! I think she (Hedwig) wanted to make sure you got something for your birthday for a change. I bought your present by owl-order; there was an advertisement in the Daily Prophet -LRB-I've been getting it delivered; it's so good to keep up with what's going on in the wizarding world-RRB-, Did you see that picture of Ron and his (Ron) family a week ago? I bet he (Ron)'s learning loads. I'm really jealous -- the ancient Egyptian wizards were fascinating.

There's some interesting local history of witchcraft here, too. I've rewritten my whole History of Magic essay to include some of the things I've found out, I hope it's not too long -- it's two rolls of parchment more than Professor Binns asked for.

Ron says he (Ron)'s going to be in London in the last week of the holidays. Can you make it? Will your aunt and uncle let you come? I really hope you can. If not, I'll see you on the Hogwarts Express on September first!

Love from Hermione

P.S. Ron says Percy's Head Boy. I'll bet Percy's really pleased Ron doesn't seem too happy about it

Harry laughed as he (Harry) put Herrmone's letter aside and picked up her (Hermione) present. It was very heavy. Knowing Hermione, he (Harry) was sure it would be a large book full of very difficult spells -- but it wasn't. His (Harry) heart gave a huge bound as he (Harry) ripped back the paper and saw a sleek black leather case, with silver words stamped across it, reading Broomstick Servicing Kit.

``Wow, Hermione!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry whispered, unzipping the case to look inside.

There was a large jar of Fleetwood's High-Finish Handle Polish, a pair of gleaming silver Tall-Twig Clippers, a tiny brass compass to clip on your broom for long journeys, and a Handbook of Do-It-Yourself Broomcare.

Apart from his (Fleetwood) friends, the thing that Harry missed most about Hogwarts was Quidditch, the most popular sport in the magical world -- highly dangerous, very exciting, and played on broomsticks. Harry happened to be a very good Quidditch player; he (Harry) had been the youngest person in a century to be picked for one of the Hogwarts House teams. One of Harry's most prized possessions was his (Harry) Nimbus Two Thousand racing broom.

Harry put the leather case aside and picked up his (Harry) last parcel. He (Harry) recognized the untidy scrawl on the brown paper at once: this was from Hagrid, the Hogwarts gamekeeper. He (Harry) tore off the top layer of paper and glimpsed something green and leathery, but before he (Harry) could unwrap it properly, the parcel gave a strange quiver, and whatever was inside it snapped loudly -- as though it had jaws.

Harry froze. He (Harry) knew that Hagrid would never send him (Harry) anything dangerous on purpose, but then, Hagrid didn't have a normal person's view of what was dangerous. Hagrid had been known to befriend giant spiders, buy vicious, three-headed dogs from men in pubs, and sneak illegal dragon eggs into his (Harry) cabin.

Harry poked the parcel nervously. It snapped loudly again. Harry reached for the lamp on his (Harry) bedside table, gripped it firmly in one hand, and raised it over his (Harry) head, ready to strike. Then he (Harry) seized the rest of the wrapping paper in his (Harry) other hand and pulled.

And out fell -- a book. Harry just had time to register its handsome green cover, emblazoned with the golden title The Monster Book of Monsters, before it flipped onto its edge and scuttled sideways along the bed like some weird crab.

``Uh-oh,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry muttered.

The book toppled off the bed with a loud clunk and shuffled rapidly across the room. Harry followed it stealthily. The book was hiding in the dark space under his (Harry) desk. Praying that the Dursleys were still fast asleep, Harry got down on his (Harry) hands and knees and reached toward it.

``Ouch!'' (him)

The book snapped shut on his (Harry) hand and then flapped past him (Harry), still scuttling on its covers. Harry scrambled around, threw himself forward, and managed to flatten it. Uncle Vernon gave a loud, sleepy grunt in the room next door.

Hedwig and Errol watched interestedly as Harry clamped the struggling book tightly in his (Harry) arms, hurried to his (Harry) chest of drawers, and pulled out a belt, which he (Harry) buckled tightly around it. The Monster Book shuddered angrily, but could no longer flap and snap, so Harry threw it down on the bed and reached for Hagrid's card.

Dear Harry,

Happy Birthday!

Think you might find this useful for next year. Won't say no more here. Tell you when I see you. Hope the Muggles are treating you right.

All the best,

Hagrid

It struck Harry as ominous that Hagrid thought a biting book would come in useful, but he (Harry) put Hagrid's card up next to Ron's and Hermione's, grinning more broadly than ever. Now there was only the letter from Hogwarts left.

Noticing that it was rather thicker than usual, Harry slit open the envelope, pulled out the first page of parchment within, and read:

Dear Mr. Potter,

Please note that the new school year will begin on September the first. The Hogwarts Express will leave ftom King's Cross station, platform nine and three-quarters, at eleven o'clock.

Third years are permitted to visit the village of Hogsmeade on certain weekends. Please give the enclosed permission form to your parent or guardian to sign.

A list of books for next year is enclosed. Yours sincerely,

Professor M. McGonagall

Deputy Headmistress

Harry pulled out the Hogsmeade permission form and looked at it, no longer grinning. It would be wonderful to visit Hogsmeade on weekends; he (Harry) knew it was an entirely wizarding village, and he (Harry) had never set foot there. But how on earth was he (Harry) going to persuade Uncle Vernon or Aunt Petunia to sign the form?

He (Harry) looked over at the alarm clock. It was now two o'clock in the morning.

Deciding that he (Harry)'d worry about the Hogsmeade form when he (Harry) woke up, Harry got back into bed and reached up to cross off another day on the chart he (Harry)'d made for himself, counting down the days left until his (Harry) return to Hogwarts. Then he (Harry) took off his (Harry) glasses and lay down, eyes open, facing his (Harry) three birthday cards.

Extremely unusual though he (Harry) was, at that moment Harry Potter felt just like everyone else -- glad, for the first time in his (Potter) life, that it was his (Potter) birthday.

CHAPTER TWO

AUNT MARGE``S BIG MISTAKE

Harry went down to breakfast the next morning to find the three Dursleys already sitting around the kitchen table. They were watching a brand-new television, a welcome-home-for-the-summer present for Dudley, who had been complaining loudly about the long walk between the fridge and the television in the living room. Dudley had spent most of the summer in the kitchen, his (Dudley) piggy little eyes fixed on the screen and his (Dudley) five chins wobbling as he (Dudley) ate continually.

Harry sat down between Dudley and Uncle Vernon, a large, beefy man with very little neck and a lot of mustache. Far from wishing Harry a happy birthday, none of the Dursleys made any sign that they had noticed Harry enter the room, but Harry was far too used to this to care. He (Harry) helped himself to a piece of toast and then looked up at the reporter on the television, who was halfway through a report on an escaped convict:

''... The public is warned that Black is armed and extremely dangerous. A special hot line has been set up, and any sighting of Black should be reported immediately.'' (the reporter)

``No need to tell us he (Harry)'s no good,'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)
snorted Uncle Vernon, staring over the top of his (Vernon) newspaper at the prisoner.
``Look at the state of him (Harry), the filthy layabout! Look at his (Harry) hair!'' (He)

He (Vernon) shot a nasty look sideways at Harry, whose untidy hair had always been a source of great annoyance to Uncle Vernon. Compared to the man on the television, however, whose gaunt face was surrounded by a matted, elbow-length tangle, Harry felt very well groomed indeed.

The reporter had reappeared.

``The Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries will announce today --'' (unknown)

``Hang on!'' (Uncle)
barked Uncle Vernon, staring furiously at the reporter.
``You didn't tell us where that maniac's escaped from! \What use is that? Lunatic could be coming up the street right now!'' (Aunt)

Aunt Petunia, who was bony and horse-faced, whipped around and peered intently out of the kitchen window. Harry knew Aunt Petunia would simply love to be the one to call the hot line number. She (Aunt) was the nosiest woman in the world and spent most of her (Aunt) life spying on the boring, law-abiding neighbors.

``When will they learn,'' (Uncle)
said Uncle Vernon, pounding the table with his (Vernon) large purple fist,
``that hanging's the only way to deal with these people?'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)

``Very true,'' (Petunia/Aunt Petunia)
said Aunt Petunia, who was still squinting into next door's runner beans.

Uncle Vernon drained his (Vernon) teacup, glanced at his (Vernon) watch, and added,

``I'd better be off in a minute, Petunia. Marge's train gets in at ten.'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)

Harry, whose thoughts had been upstairs with the Broomstick Servicing Kit, was brought back to earth with an unpleasant bump.

``Aunt Marge?'' (he)
he (Harry) blurted out.
``Sh -- she (Aunt)'s not coming here, is she (Aunt)?'' (Aunt)

Aunt Marge was Uncle Vernon's sister. Even though she (Marge) was not a blood relative of Harry's -LRB-whose mother had been Aunt Petunia's sister-RRB-, he (Harry) had been forced to call her (Aunt)

``Aunt'' (he)
all his (Harry) life. Aunt Marge lived in the country, in a house with a large garden, where she (Marge) bred bulldogs. She (Marge) didn't often stay at Privet Drive, because she (Marge) couldn't bear to leave her (Marge) precious dogs, but each of her (Marge) visits stood out horribly vividly in Harry's mind.

At Dudley's fifth birthday party, Aunt Margo had whacked Harry around the shins with her (Aunt) walking stick to stop him (Harry) from beating Dudley at musical statues. A few years later, she (Aunt) had turned up at Christmas with a computerized robot for Dudley and a box of dog biscuits for Harry. On her (Aunt) last visit, the year before Harry started at Hogwarts, Harry had accidentally trodden on the tail of her (Aunt) favorite dog. Ripper had chased Harry out into the garden and up a tree, and Aunt Marge had refused to call him (Harry) off until past midnight. The memory of this incident still brought tears of laughter to Dudley's eyes.

``Marge'll be here for a week,'' (Uncle)
Uncle Vernon snarled, 11 and while we're on the subject'' -- he (Vernon) pointed a fat finger threateningly at Harry --
``we need to get a few things straight before I go and collect her (Marge).'' (Uncle Vernon)

Dudley smirked and withdrew his (Dudley) gaze from the television. Watching Harry being bullied by Uncle Vernon was Dudley's favorite form of entertainment.

``Firstly,'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)
growled Uncle Vernon,
``you'll keep a civil tongue in your head when you're talking to Marge.'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)

``All right,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry bitterly, ``if she (Marge) does when she (Marge)'s talking to me.

``Secondly,'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)
said Uncle Vernon, acting as though he (Vernon) had not heard Harry's reply,
``as Marge doesn't know anything about your abnormality, I don't want any -- any funny stuff while she (Marge)'s here.

You behave yourself, got me?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``I will if she (Marge) does,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry through gritted teeth.

``And thirdly,'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)
said Uncle Vernon, his (Vernon) mean little eyes now slits in his (Vernon) great purple face,
``we've told Marge you attend St. Brutus's Secure Center for Incurably Criminal Boys.'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)

``What?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry yelled.

``And you'll be sticking to that story, boy, or there'll be trouble, spat Uncle Vernon.

Harry sat there, white-faced and furious, staring at Uncle Vernon, hardly able to believe it. Aunt Marge coming for a weeklong visit -- it was the worst birthday present the Dursleys had ever given him (Harry), including that pair of Uncle Vernon's old socks.

``Well, Petunia,'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)
said Uncle Vernon, getting heavily to his (Harry) feet,
``I'll be off to the station, then. Want to come along for the ride, Dudders?'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)

``No,'' (Dudley)
said Dudley, whose attention had returned to the television now that Uncle Vernon had finished threatening Harry.

``Duddy's got to make himself smart for his (Vernon) auntie,'' (Petunia/Aunt Petunia)
said Aunt Petunia, smoothing Dudley's thick blond hair.
``Mummy's bought him (Vernon) a lovely new bow tie.'' (Uncle)

Uncle Vernon clapped Dudley on his (Vernon) porky shoulder.

``See you in a bit, then,'' (he)
he (Vernon) said, and he (Vernon) left the kitchen.

Harry, who had been sitting in a kind of horrified trance, had a sudden idea. Abandoning his (Harry) toast, he (Harry) got quickly to his (Harry) feet and followed Uncle Vernon to the front door.

Uncle Vernon was pulling on his (Vernon) car coat.

``I'm not taking you,'' (he)
he (Vernon) snarled as he (Vernon) turned to see Harry watching him (Harry).

``Like I wanted to come,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry coldly.
``I want to ask you something.'' (Uncle)

Uncle Vernon eyed him (Vernon) suspiciously.

``Third years at Hog -- at my school are allowed to visit the village sometimes,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``So?'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)
snapped Uncle Vernon, taking his (Vernon) car keys from a hook next to the door.

``I need you to sign the permission form,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry in a rush.

``And why should I do that?'' (Uncle)
sneered Uncle Vernon.

``Well,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, choosing his (Harry) words carefully,
``it'll be hard work, pretending to Aunt Marge I go to that St. Whatsits --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``St. Brutus's Secure Center for Incurably Criminal Boys!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
bellowed Uncle Vernon, and Harry was pleased to hear a definite note of panic in Uncle Vernon's voice.

``Exactly,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, looking calmly up into Uncle Vernon's large, purple face.
``It's a lot to remember. I'll have to make it sound convincing, won't I? What if I accidentally let something slip?'' (unknown)

``You'll get the stuffing knocked out of you, won't you?'' (Vernon/Uncle Vernon)
roared Uncle Vernon, advancing on Harry with his (Harry) fist raised. But Harry stood his (Harry) ground.

``Knocking the stuffing out of me won't make Aunt Marge forget what I could tell her (Marge),'' (he)
he (Harry) said grimly.

Uncle Vernon stopped, his (Vernon) fist still raised, his (Vernon) face an ugly puce.

``But if you sign my permission form,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry went on quickly,
``I swear I'll remember where I'm supposed to go to school, and I'll act like a Mug -- like I'm normal and everything.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry could tell that Uncle Vernon was thinking it over, even if his (Vernon) teeth were bared and a vein was throbbing in his (Vernon) temple.

``Right,'' (he)
he (Vernon) snapped finally.
``I shall monitor your behavior carefully during Marge's visit. If, at the end of it, you've toed the line and kept to the story, I'll sign your ruddy form.'' (He)

He (Vernon) wheeled around, pulled open the front door, and slammed it so hard that one of the little panes of glass at the top fell out.

Harry didn't return to the kitchen. He (Harry) went back upstairs to his (Harry) bedroom. If he (Harry) was going to act like a real Muggle, he (Harry)'d better start now. Slowly and sadly he (Harry) gathered up all his (Harry) presents and his (Harry) birthday cards and hid them under the loose floorboard with his (Harry) homework. Then he (Harry) went to Hedwig's cage. Errol seemed to have recovered; he (Errol) and Hedwig were both asleep, heads under their wings. Harry sighed, then poked them both awake.

``Hedwig,'' (he)
he (Harry) said gloomily,
``you're going to have to clear off for a week. Go with Errol. Ron'll look after you. I'll write him (Ron) a note, explaining. And don't look at me like that'' (he)
-- Hedwig's large amber eyes were reproachful --
``it's not my fault. It's the only way I'll be allowed to visit Hogsmeade with Ron and Hermione.'' (Hedwig)

Ten minutes later, Errol and Hedwig -LRB-who had a note to Ron bound to her (Hedwig) leg-RRB- soared out of the window and out of sight. Harry, now feeling thoroughly miserable, put the empty cage away inside the wardrobe.

But Harry didn't have long to brood. In next to no time, Aunt Petunia was shrieking up the stairs for Harry to come down and get ready to welcome their guest.

``Do something about your hair!'' (Aunt)
Aunt Petunia snapped as he (Harry) reached the hall.

Harry couldn't see the point of trying to make his (Harry) hair lie flat. Aunt Marge loved criticizing him (Harry), so the untidier he (Harry) looked, the happier she (Marge) would be.

All too soon, there was a crunch of gravel outside as Uncle Vernon's car pulled back into the driveway, then the clunk of the car doors and footsteps on the garden path.

``Get the door!'' (Aunt)
Aunt Petunia hissed at Harry.

A feeling of great gloom in his (Harry) stomach, Harry pulled the door open.

On the threshold stood Aunt Marge. She (Aunt) was very like Uncle Vernon: large, beefy, and purple- faced, she (Aunt) even had a mustache, though not as bushy as his (Vernon). In one hand she (Aunt) held an enormous suitcase, and tucked under the other was an old and evil-tempered bulldog.

``Where's my Dudders?'' (Aunt)
roared Aunt Marge.
``Where's my neffy-poo?'' (Dudley)

Dudley came waddling down the hall, his (Dudley) blond hair plastered flat to his (Dudley) fat head, a bow tie just visible under his (Dudley) many chins. Aunt Marge thrust the suitcase into Harry's stomach, knocking the wind out of him (Harry), seized Dudley in a tight one-armed hug, and planted a large kiss on his (Dudley) cheek.

Harry knew perfectly well that Dudley only put up with Aunt Marge's hugs because he (Harry) was well paid for it, and sure enough, when they broke apart, Dudley had a crisp twenty-pound note clutched in his (Dudley) fat fist.

``Petunia!'' (Aunt)
shouted Aunt Marge, striding past Harry as though he (Harry) was a hat stand. Aunt Marge and Aunt Petunia kissed, or rather, Aunt Marge bumped her (Marge) large jaw against Aunt Petunia's bony cheekbone.

Uncle Vernon now came in, smiling jovially as he (Vernon) shut the door.

``Tea, Marge?'' (he)
he (Vernon) said.
``And what will Ripper take?'' (unknown)

``Ripper can have some tea out of my saucer,'' (Marge/Aunt Marge/MARGE)
said Aunt Marge as they all proceeded into the kitchen, leaving Harry alone in the hall with the suitcase. But Harry wasn't complaining; any excuse not to be with Aunt Marge was fine by him (Harry), so he (Harry) began to heave the case upstairs into the spare bedroom, taking as long as he (Harry) could.

By the time he (Harry) got back to the kitchen, Aunt Marge had been supplied with tea and fruitcake, and Ripper was lapping noisily in the corner. Harry saw Aunt Petunia wince slightly as specks of tea and drool flecked her (Aunt) clean floor. Aunt Petunia hated animals.

``Who's looking after the other dogs, Marge?'' (Uncle)
Uncle Vernon asked.

``Oh, I've got Colonel Fubster managing them,'' (Aunt)
boomed Aunt Marge.
``He (Colonel)'s retired now, good for him (Colonel) to have something to do. But I couldn't leave poor old Ripper. He (Ripper) pines if he (Ripper)'s away from me.'' (Ripper)

Ripper began to growl again as Harry sat down. This directed Aunt Marge's attention to Harry for the first time.

``So!'' (she)
she (Aunt) barked.
``Still here, are you?'' (unknown)

Harry was bursting to say that he (Harry)'d rather live in an orphanage than with the Dursleys, but the thought of the Hogsmeade form stopped him (Harry). He (Harry) forced his (Harry) face into a painful smile.

``Don't you smirk at me!'' (Aunt)
boomed Aunt Marge.
``I can see you haven't improved since I last saw you. I hoped school would knock some manners into you.'' (She)
She (Aunt) took a large gulp of tea, wiped her (Aunt) mustache, and said,

``Er --'' (Uncle)

``I won't have this namby-pamby, wishy-washy nonsense about not hitting people who deserve it. A good thrashing is what's needed in ninety-nine cases out of a hundred. Have you been beaten often?'' (unknown)

``loads of times.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Perhaps Uncle Vernon was worried that Harry might forget their bargain; in any case, he (Harry) changed the subject abruptly.

``Heard the news this morning, Marge? What about that escaped prisoner, eh?'' (Aunt)

As Aunt Marge started to make herself at home, Harry caught himself thinking almost longingly of life at number four without her (Marge). Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia usually encouraged Harry to stay out of their way, which Harry was only too happy to do. Aunt Marge, on the other hand, wanted Harry under her (Marge) eye at all times, so that she (Marge) could boom out suggestions for his (Harry) improvement. She (Marge) delighted in comparing Harry with Dudley, and took huge pleasure in buying Dudley expensive presents while glaring at Harry, as though daring him (Harry) to ask why he (Harry) hadn't got a present too. She (Marge) also kept throwing out dark hints about what made Harry such an unsatisfactory person.

``You mustn't blame yourself for the way the boy's turned out, Vernon,'' (she)
she (Marge) said over lunch on the third day.
``If there's something rotten on the inside, there's nothing anyone can do about it.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry tried to concentrate on his (Harry) food, but his (Harry) hands shook and his (Harry) face was starting to burn with anger. Remember the form, he (Harry) told himself Think about Hogsmeade. Don't say anything. Don't rise

Aunt Marge reached for her (Marge) glass of wine.

``It's one of the basic rules of breeding,'' (she)
she (Marge) said.
``You see it all the time with dogs. If there's something wrong with the bitch, there'll be something wrong with the pup --'' (Aunt)

At that moment, the wineglass Aunt Marge was holding exploded in her (Marge) hand. Shards of glass flew in every direction and Aunt Marge sputtered and blinked, her (Marge) great ruddy face dripping.

``Marge!'' (Aunt)
squealed Aunt Petunia.
``Marge, are you all right?'' (unknown)

``Not to worry,'' (Aunt)
grunted Aunt Marge, mopping her (Marge) face with her (Marge) napkin.
``Must have squeezed it too hard. Did the same thing at Colonel Fubster's the other day. No need to fuss, Petunia, I have a very firm grip...'' (Aunt)

But Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon were both looking at Harry suspiciously, so he (Harry) decided he (Harry)'d better skip dessert and escape from the table as soon as he (Harry) could.

Outside in the hall, he (Harry) leaned against the wall, breathing deeply It had been a long time since he (Harry)'d lost control and made something explode. He (Harry) couldn't afford to let it happen again. The Hogsmeade form wasn't the only thing at stake -- if he (Harry) carried on like that, he (Harry)'d be in trouble with the Ministry of Magic.

Harry was still an underage wizard, and he (Harry) was forbidden by wizard law to do magic outside school. His (Harry) record wasn't exactly clean either. Only last summer he (Harry)'d gotten an official warning that had stated quite clearly that if the Ministry got wind of any more magic in Privet Drive, Harry would face expulsion from Hogwarts.

He (Harry) heard the Dursleys leaving the table and hurried upstairs out of the way.

Harry got through the next three days by forcing himself to think about his (Harry) Handbook of Do-It-Yourself Broomcare whenever Aunt Marge started on him (Harry). This worked quite well, though it seemed to give him (Harry) a glazed look, because Aunt Marge started voicing the opinion that he (Harry) was mentally subnormal.

At last, at long last, the final evening of Marge's stay arrived. Aunt Petunia cooked a fancy dinner and Uncle Vernon uncorked several bottles of wine. They got all the way through the soup and the salmon without a single mention of Harry's faults; during the lemon meringue pie, Uncle Vernon bored them A with a long talk about Grunnings, his (Vernon) drill-making company; then Aunt Petunia made coffee and Uncle Vernon brought out a bottle of brandy.

``Can I tempt you, Marge?'' (Aunt)

Aunt Marge had already had quite a lot of wine. Her (Marge) huge face was very red.

``Just a small one, then,'' (she)
she (Marge) chuckled.
``A bit more than that... and a bit more... that's the ticket.'' (Dudley)

Dudley was eating his (Dudley) fourth slice of pie. Aunt Petunia was sipping coffee with her (Petunia) little finger sticking out. Harry really wanted to disappear into his (Harry) bedroom, but he (Harry) met Uncle Vernon's angry little eyes and knew he (Vernon) would have to sit it out.

``Aah,'' (Marge/Aunt Marge/MARGE)
said Aunt Marge, smacking her (Marge) lips and putting the empty brandy glass back down.
``Excellent nosh, Petunia. It's normally just a fry-up for me of an evening, with twelve dogs to look after...'' (She)
She (Marge) burped richly and patted her (Marge) great tweed stomach.
``Pardon me. But I do like to see a healthy-sized boy,'' (she)
she (Marge) went on, winking at Dudley.

She (Marge) jerked her (Marge) head at Harry, who felt his (Harry) stomach clench. The Handbook, he (Harry) thought quickly.

``This one's got a mean, runty look about him (Vernon). You get that with dogs. I had Colonel Fubster drown one last year. Ratty little thing it was- Weak. Underbred.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry was trying to remember page twelve of his (Harry) book: A Charm to Cure Reluctant Reversers. ``It all comes down to blood, as I was saying the other day.

Bad blood will out. Now, I'm saying nothing against your family, Petunia'' she (Marge) patted Aunt Petunia's bony hand with her (Petunia) shovellike one

``but your sister was a bad egg. They turn up in the best families. Then she (sister) ran off with a wastrel and here's the result right in front of us.'' (Petunia)

Harry was staring at his (Harry) plate, a funny ringing in his (Harry) ears. Grasp your broom firmly by the tail, he (Harry) thought. But he (Harry) couldn't remember what came next. Aunt Marge's voice seemed to be boring into him (Harry) like one of Uncle Vernon's drills.

``This Potter, 5-RRB- said Aunt Marge loudly, seizing the brandy bottle and splashing more into her (Marge) glass and over the tablecloth,

Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia were looking extremely tense. Dudley had even looked up from his (Dudley) pie to gape at his (Dudley) parents.

said Harry suddenly. The table went very quiet. Harry was shaking all over. He (Harry) had never felt so angry in his (Harry) life.

``You, boy,'' (he)

``No, Vernon,'' (Aunt)
