``They didn't die in a car crash!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, who found himself on his (Harry) feet.

``They died in a car crash, you nasty little liar, and left you to be a burden on their decent, hardworking relatives!'' (Aunt)
screamed Aunt Marge, swelling with fury.
``You are an insolent, ungrateful little --'' (Aunt)

But Aunt Marge suddenly stopped speaking. For a moment, it looked as though words had failed her (Marge). She (Marge) seemed to be swelling with inexpressible anger -- but the swelling didn't stop. Her (Marge) great red face started to expand, her (Marge) tiny eyes bulged, and her (Marge) mouth stretched too tightly for speech -- next second, several buttons had just burst from her (Marge) tweed jacket and pinged off the walls -- she (Marge) was inflating like a monstrous balloon, her (Marge) stomach bursting free of her (Marge) tweed waistband, each of her (Marge) fingers blowing up like a salami --

``MARGE!'' (she)
yelled Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia together as Aunt Marge's whole body began to rise off her (Aunt) chair toward the ceiling. She (Aunt) was entirely round, now, like a vast life buoy with piggy eyes, and her (Aunt) hands and feet stuck out weirdly as she (Aunt) drifted up into the air, making apoplectic popping noises. Ripper came skidding into the room, barking madly.

``NOOOOOOO!'' (Uncle)

Uncle Vernon seized one of Marge's feet and tried to pull her (Marge) down again, but was almost lifted from the floor himself. A second later, Ripper leapt forward and sank his (Ripper) teeth into Uncle Vernon's leg.

Harry tore from the dining room before anyone could stop him (Harry), heading for the cupboard under the stairs. The cupboard door burst magically open as he (Harry) reached it. In seconds, he (Harry) had heaved his (Harry) trunk to the front door. He (Harry) sprinted upstairs and threw himself under the bed, wrenching up the loose floorboard, and grabbed the pillowcase full of his (Harry) books and birthday presents. He (Harry) wriggled out, seized Hedwig's empty cage, and dashed back downstairs to his (Harry) trunk, just as Uncle Vernon burst out of the dining room, his (Vernon) trouser leg in bloody tatters.

``COME BACK IN HERE!'' (he)
he (Vernon) bellowed.
``COME BACK AND PUT HER RIGHT!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

But a reckless rage had come over Harry. He (Harry) kicked his (Harry) trunk open, pulled out his (Harry) wand, and pointed it at Uncle Vernon.

``She (They) deserved it,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said, breathing very fast.
``She (They) deserved what she (They) got. You keep away from me.'' (He)

He (Harry) fumbled behind him (Harry) for the latch on the door.

``I'm going,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said.
``I've had enough.'' (he)

And in the next moment, he (Harry) was out in the dark, quiet street, heaving his (Harry) heavy trunk behind him (Harry), Hedwig's cage under his (Harry) arm.

CHAPTER THREE

THE KNIGHT BUS

Harry was several streets away before he (Harry) collapsed onto a low wall in Magnolia Crescent, panting from the effort of dragging his (Harry) trunk. He (Harry) sat quite still, anger still surging through him (Harry), listening to the frantic thumping of his (Harry) heart.

But after ten minutes alone in the dark street, a new emotion overtook him (Harry): panic. Whichever way he (Harry) looked at it, he (Harry) had never been in a worse fix. He (Harry) was stranded, quite alone, in the dark Muggle world, with absolutely nowhere to go. And the worst of it was, he (Harry) had just done serious magic, which meant that he (Harry) was almost certainly expelled from Hogwarts. He (Harry) had broken the Decree for the Restriction of Underage Wizardry so badly, he (Harry) was surprised Ministry of Magic representatives weren't swooping down on him (Harry) where he (Harry) sat.

Harry shivered and looked up and down Magnolia Crescent.

What, was going to happen to him (Harry)? Would he (Harry) be arrested, or would he (Harry) simply be outlawed from the wizarding world? He (Harry) thought of Ron and Hermione, and his (Harry) heart sank even lower. Harry was sure that, criminal or not, Ron and Hermione would want to help him (Ron) now, but they were both abroad, and with Hedwig gone, he (Ron) had no means of contacting them.

He (Ron) didn't have any Muggle money, either. There was a little wizard gold in the money bag at the bottom of his (wizard) trunk, but the rest of the fortune his (wizard) parents had left him (wizard) was stored in a vault at Gringotts Wizarding Bank in London. He (wizard)'d never be able to drag his (wizard) trunk all the way to London. Unless...

He (wizard) looked down at his (wizard) wand, which he (wizard) was still clutching in his (wizard) hand. If he (wizard) was already expelled -LRB-his (wizard) heart was. now thumping painfully fast-RRB-, a bit more magic couldn't hurt. He (wizard) had the Invisibility Cloak he (wizard) had inherited from his (wizard) father -- what if he (wizard) bewitched the trunk to make it feather-light, tied it to his (wizard) broomstick, covered himself in the cloak, and flew to London? Then he (wizard) could get the rest of his (wizard) money out of his (wizard) vault and... begin his (wizard) life as an outcast. It was a horrible prospect, but he (wizard) couldn't sit on this wall forever, or he (wizard)'d find himself trying to explain to Muggle police why he (wizard) was out in the dead of night with a trunkful of spellbooks and a broomstick.

Harry opened his (Harry) trunk again and pushed the contents aside, looking for the Invisibility Cloak - but before he (Harry) had found it, he (Harry) straightened up suddenly, looking around him (Harry) once more.

A funny prickling on the back of his (Harry) neck had made Harry feel he (Harry) was being watched, but the street appeared to be deserted, and no lights shone from any of the large square houses.

He (Harry) bent over his (Harry) trunk again, but almost immediately stood up once more, his (Harry) hand clenched on his (Harry) wand. He (Harry) had sensed rather than heard it: someone or something was standing in the narrow gap between the garage and the fence behind him (Harry). Harry squinted at the black alleyway. If only it would move, then he (Harry)'d know whether it was just a stray cat or -- something else.

``Lumos,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry muttered, and a light appeared at the end of his (Harry) wand, almost dazzling him (Harry). He (Harry) held it high over his (Harry) head, and the pebble-dashed walls of number two suddenly sparkled; the garage door gleamed, and between them Harry saw, quite distinctly, the hulking outline of something very big, with wide, gleaming eyes.

Harry stepped backward. His (Harry) legs hit his (Harry) trunk and he (Harry) tripped. His (Harry) wand flew out of his (Harry) hand as he (Harry) flung out an arm to break his (Harry) fall, and he (Harry) landed, hard, in the gutter --

There was a deafening BANG, and Harry threw up his (Harry) hands to shield his (Harry) eyes against a sudden blinding light --

With a yell, he (Harry) rolled back onto the pavement, just in time. A second later, a gigantic pair of wheels and headlights screeched to a halt exactly where Harry had just been lying. They belonged, as Harry saw when he (Harry) raised his (Harry) head, to a triple-decker, violently purple bus, which had appeared out of thin air. Gold lettering over the windshield spelled The Knight Bus.

For a Split second, Harry wondered if he (Harry) had been knocked silly by his (Harry) fall. Then a conductor in a purple uniform leapt out of the bus and began to speak loudly to the night.

``Welcome to the Knight Bus, emergency transport for the stranded witch or wizard. just stick out your wand hand, step on board-RRB- and we can take you anywhere you want to go. My name is Stan Shunpike, and I will be your conductor this eve --'' (The conductor)

The conductor stopped abruptly. He (conductor) had just caught sight of ``Harry, who was still sitting on the ground. Harry snatched up his (Harry) wand again and scrambled to his (Harry) feet. Close up, he (Harry) saw that Stan Shunpike was only a few years older than he (Shunpike) was, eighteen or nineteen at most, with large, protruding ears and quite a few pimples.

``What were you doin' down there?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan, dropping his (Stan) professional manner.

``Fell over,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

''`Choo fall over for?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
sniggered Stan.

``I didn't do it on purpose,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, annoyed. One of the knees in his (Harry) jeans was torn, and the hand he (Harry) had thrown out to break his (Harry) fall was bleeding. He (Harry) suddenly remembered why he (Harry) had fallen over and turned around quickly to stare at the alleyway between the garage and fence. The Knight Bus's headlamps were flooding it with light, and it was empty.

''`Choo lookin' at?'' (Knight)
said Stan.

``There was a big black thing,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, pointing uncertainly into the gap.
``Like a dog... but massive...'' (He)

He (Harry) looked a-round at Stan, whose mouth was slightly open. With a feeling of unease, Harry saw Stan's eyes move to the scar on Harry's forehead.

``Woss that on your `ead?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan abruptly.

``Nothing,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry quickly, flattening his (Harry) hair over his (Harry) scar. If the Ministry of Magic was looking for him (Harry), he (Harry) didn't want to make it too easy for them.

``Woss your name?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
Stan persisted.

``Neville Longbottom,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, saying the first name that came into his (Harry) head.
``So -- so this bus,'' (he)
he (Harry) went on quickly, hoping to distract Stan,
``did you say it goes anywhere?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

``Yep,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan proudly,
``anywhere you like, long's it's on land. Can't do nuffink underwater. `Ere,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
he (Stan) said, looking suspicious again, ,You did flag us down, dincha? Stuck out your wand `and, dincha?''

``Yes,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry quickly.
``Listen, how much would it be to get to London?'' (unknown)

``Eleven Sickles,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan,
``but for fifteen you get `or chocolate, and for fifteen you get an `ot water bottle an' a toofbrush in the color of your choice.'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

Harry rummaged once more in his (Harry) trunk, extracted his (Harry) money bag, and shoved some gold into Stan's hand. He (Stan) and Stan then lifted his (Stan) trunk, with Hedwig's cage balanced on top, up the steps of the bus.

There were no seats; instead, half a dozen brass bedsteads stood beside the curtained windows. Candles were burning in brackets beside each bed, illuminating the wood-paneled walls. A tiny wizard in a nightcap at the rear of the bus muttered,

``Not now, thanks, I'm pickling some slugs'' (A wizard)
and rolled over in his (wizard) sleep.

``You `ave this one,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
Stan whispered, shoving Harry's trunk under the bed right behind the driver, who was sitting in an armchair in front of the steering wheel.
``This is our driver, Ernie Prang. This ,is Neville Longbottom, Ern. '' (Ernie/Ernie Prang)

Ernie Prang, an elderly wizard wearing very thick glasses, nodded to Harry, who nervously flattened his (Harry) bangs again and sat down on his (Harry) bed.

``Take `er away, Ern,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan, sitting down in the armchair next to Ernie's.

There was another tremendous BANG, and the next moment Harry found himself flat on his (Harry) bed, thrown backward by the speed of the Knight Bus. Pulling himself up, Harry stared out of the dark window and saw that they were now bowling along a completely different street. Stan was watching Harry's stunned face with great enjoyment.

``This is where we was before you flagged us down,'' (he)
he (Stan) said.
``Where are we, Ern? Somewhere in Wales?'' (unknown)

``Ar,'' (Ernie/Ernie Prang)
said Ernie.

``How come the Muggles don't hear the bus?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``Them!'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan contemptuously.
``Don' listen properly, do they? Don' look properly either. Never notice nuffink, they don'.'' (unknown)

``Best go wake up Madam Marsh, Stan,'' (unknown)
said Ern.
``We'll be in Abergavenny in a minute.'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

Stan passed Harry's bed and disappeared up a narrow wooden staircase. Harry was still looking out of the window, feeling increasingly nervous. Ernie didn't seem to have mastered the use of a steering wheel. The Knight Bus kept mounting the pavement, but it didn't hit anything; lines of lampposts, mailboxes, and trash cans jumped out of its way as it approached and back into position once it had passed.

Stan came back downstairs, followed by a faintly green witch wrapped in a traveling cloak.

''`Ere you go, Madam Marsh,'' (a witch)
said Stan happily as Ern stamped on the brake and the beds slid a foot or so toward the front of the bus. Madam Marsh clamped a handkerchief to her (Marsh) mouth and tottered down the steps. Stan threw her (Marsh) bag out after her (Marsh) and rammed the doors shut; there was another loud BANG, and they were thundering down a narrow country lane, trees leaping out of the way.

Harry wouldn't have been able to sleep even if he (Harry) had been traveling on a bus that didn't keep banging loudly and jumping a hundred miles at a time. His (Harry) stomach churned as he (Harry) fell back to wondering what was going to happen to him (Harry), and whether the Dursleys had managed to get Aunt Marge off the ceiling yet.

Stan had unfurled a copy of the Daily Prophet and was now reading with his (Stan) tongue between his (Stan) teeth. A large photograph of a sunken-faced man with long, matted hair blinked slowly at Harry from the front page. He (Harry) looked strangely familiar.

``That man!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said, forgetting his (Harry) troubles for a moment.
``He (Stan) was on the Muggle news!'' (Stanley)

Stanley turned to the front page and chuckled.

``Sirius Black,'' (he)
he (Harry) said, nodding.
''`Course 'e was on the Muggle news, Neville, where you been?'' (he)

He (Neville) gave a superior sort of chuckle at the blank look on Harry's face, removed the front page, and handed it to Harry.

``You oughta read the papers more, Neville.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry held the paper up to the candlelight and read:

BLACK STILL AT LARGE

Sirius Black, possibly the most infamous prisoner ever to be held in Azkaban fortress, is still eluding capture, the Ministry of Magic confirmed today.

``We are doing all we can to recapture Black,'' (the Minister Fudge morning)
said the Minister of Magic, Cornelius Fudge, this morning,
``and we beg the magical community to remain calm.'' (Cornelius Fudge/Fudge/Cornelius)

Fudge has been criticized by some members of the International Federation of Warlocks for informing the Muggle Prime Minister of the crisis.

``Well, really, I had to, don't you know,'' (an Fudge)
said an irritable Fudge.
``Black is mad. He (Black)'s a danger to anyone who crosses him (Black), magic or Muggle. I have the Prime Minister's assurance that he (Minister) will not breathe a word of Black's true identity to anyone. And let's face it-who'd believe him (Black) if he (Black) did?'' (Muggles)

While Muggles have been told that Black is carrying a gun -LRB-a kind of metal wand that Muggles use to kill each other-RRB-, the magical community lives in fear of a massacre like that of twelve years ago, when Black murdered thirteen people with a single curse.

Harry looked into the shadowed eyes of Sirius Black, the only part of the sunken face that seemed alive. Harry had never met a vampire, but he (Harry) had seen pictures of them in his (Harry) Defense Against the Dark Arts classes, and Black, with his (Black) waxy white skin, looked just like one.

``Scary-lookin' fing, inee?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan, who had been watching Harry read.

``He (Black) murdered thirteen people?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, handing the page back to Stan,
``with one curse?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

``Yep,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan,
``in front of witnesses an' all. Broad daylight. Big trouble it caused, dinnit, Ern?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

``Ar,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Ern darkly.

Stan swiveled in his (Stan) armchair, his (Stan) hands on the back, the better to look at Harry.

``Black woz a big supporter of You-Know-`Oo,'' (he)
he (Harry) said.

``What, Voldemort?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, without thinking.

Even Stan's pimples went white; Ern jerked the steering wheel so hard that a whole farmhouse had to jump aside to avoid the bus.

``You outta your tree?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
yelped Stan.
''`Choo say `is name for?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

``Sorry,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry hastily.
``Sorry, I -- I forgot --'' (unknown)

``Forgot!'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan weakly.
``Blimey, my `eart's goin' that fast ...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``So -- so Black was a supporter of You-Know-Who?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry prompted apologetically.

``Yeah,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan, still rubbing his (Stan) chest. ``Yeah, that's right. Very close to You-Know-``Oo, they say. Anyway, when little ``Arry Potter got the better of You-Know-
``Oo --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry nervously flattened his (Harry) bangs down again.

''-- all You-Know-``Oo's supporters was tracked down, wasn't they, Ern? Most of 'em knew it was all over, wiv You-Know-``Oo gone, and they came quiet. But not Sirius Black. I `eard he (Black) thought `e'd be second-in-command once You-Know-``Oo `ad taken over.

``Anyway, they cornered Black in the middle of a street full of Muggles an' Black took out `is wand and 'e blasted `alf the street apart, an' a wizard got it, an' so did a dozen Muggles what got in the way.

``Orrible, eh? An' you know what Black did then?'' (unknown)
Stan continued in a dramatic whisper.

``What?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``Laughed,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan. ``Jus' stood there an' laughed. An' when reinforcements from the Ministry of Magic got there, I 'e went wiv em quiet as anyfink, still laughing `is `ead off.
``Cos `e's mad, inee, Ern? Inee mad?'' (unknown)

``If he (Black) weren't when he (Black) went to Azkaban, he (Black) will be now,'' (unknown)
said Ern in his (Stan) slow voice.
``I'd blow meself up before I set foot in that place. Serves him (Black) right, mind you ... after what he (Black) did...'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

``They `ad a job coverin' it up, din' they, Ern?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
Stan said.
''`Ole street blown up an' all them Muggles dead. What was it they said ad `appened, Ern?'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

``Gas explosion,'' (Ernie/Ernie Prang)
grunted Ernie.

``An' now `e's out,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan, examining the newspaper picture of Black's gaunt face again.
``Never been a breakout from Azkaban before, `as there, Ern? Beats me `ow 'e did it. Frightenin', eh? Mind, I don't fancy `is chances against them Azkaban guards, eh, Ern?'' (Ernie/Ernie Prang)

Ernie suddenly shivered.

``Talk about summat else, Stan, there's a good lad. Them Azkaban guards give me the collywobbles.'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

Stan put the paper away reluctantly, and Harry leaned against the window of the Knight Bus, feeling worse than ever. He (Harry) couldn't help imagining what Stan might be telling his (Stan) passengers in a few nights' time.

''`Ear about that ``Arry Potter? Blew up `is aunt! We `ad `im `ere on the Knight Bus, di'n't we, Ern?

``E was tryin' I to run for it...'' (He)

He (Stan), Harry, had broken wizard law just like Sirius Black. Was inflating Aunt Marge bad enough to land him (Black) in Azkaban? Harry didn't know anything about the wizard prison, though everyone he (Harry)'d ever heard speak of it did so in the same fearful tone. Hagrid, the Hogwarts gamekeeper, had spent two months there only last year. Harry wouldn't soon forget the look of terror on Hagrid's face when he (Harry) had been told where he (Harry) was going, and Hagrid was one of the bravest people Harry knew.

The Knight Bus rolled through the darkness, scattering bushes and wastebaskets, telephone booths and trees, and Harry lay, restless and miserable, on his (Harry) feather bed. After a while, Stan remembered that Harry had paid for hot chocolate, but poured it all over Harry's pillow when the bus moved abruptly from Anglesea to Aberdeen. One by one, wizards and witches in dressing gowns and slippers descended from the upper floors to leave the bus. They all looked very pleased to go.

Finally, Harry was the only passenger left.

``Right then, Neville,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan, clapping his (Stan) hands, where abouts in London?''

``Diagon Alley,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``Righto,'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
said Stan.
''`Old tight, then.'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

BANG.

They were thundering along Charing Cross Road. Harry sat up and watched buildings and benches squeezing themselves out of the Knight Bus's way. The sky was getting a little lighter. He (Harry) would lie low for a couple of hours, go to Gringotts the. moment it opened, then set off -- where, he (Harry) didn't know.

Ern slammed on the brakes and the Knight Bus skidded to a halt in front of a small and shabby- looking pub, the Leaky Cauldron, behind which lay the magical entrance to Diagon Alley.

``Thanks,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said to Ern.

He (Harry) jumped down the steps and helped Stan lower his (Harry) trunk and Hedwig's cage onto the pavement.

``Well,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
''`Bye then!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

But Stan wasn't paying attention. Still standing in the doorway to the bus-RRB- he (Stan) was goggling at the shadowy entrance to the Leaky Cauldron.

``There you are, Harry,'' (unknown)
said a voice.

Before Harry could turn, he (Harry) felt a hand on his (Harry) shoulder. At the same time, Stan shouted,

``Blimey! Ern, come `ere! Come `ere I'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)

Harry looked up at the owner of the hand on his (Harry) shoulder and felt a bucketful of ice cascade into his (Harry) stomach -- he (Harry) had walked right into Cornelius Fudge, the Minister of Magic himself.

Stan leapt onto the pavement beside them.

``What didja call Neville, Minister?'' (he)
he (Stan) said excitedly.

Fudge, a portly little man in a long, pinstriped cloak, looked cold and exhausted.

``Neville?'' (he)
he (Stan) repeated, frowning.
``This is Harry Potter.'' (unknown)

``I knew it!'' (Stan/Stan Shunpike)
Stan shouted gleefully. ``Ern! Ern! Guess `oo Neville is, Ern! ``E's
``Arry Potter! I can see `is scar!'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge testily,
``well, I'm very glad the Knight Bus picked Harry up, but he (Harry) and I need to step inside the Leaky Cauldron now...'' (Fudge)

Fudge increased the pressure on Harry's shoulder, and Harry found himself being steered inside the pub. A stooping figure bearing a lantern appeared through the door behind the bar. It was Tom, the wizened, toothless landlord.

``You've got him (Harry), Minister!'' (Tom)
said Tom.
``Will you be wanting anything? Beer? Brandy?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps a pot of tea,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge, who still hadn't let go of Harry.

There was a loud scraping and puffing from behind them, and Stan and Ern appeared, carrying Harry's trunk and Hedwig's cage and looking around excitedly.

''`Ow come you di'n't tell us `oo you are, eh, Neville?'' (Hedwig)
said Stan, beaming at Harry, while Ernie's owlish face peered interestedly over Stan's shoulder.

``And a private parlor, please, Tom,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge pointedly.

`Bye,'' Harry said miserably to Stan and Ern as Tom beckoned Fudge toward the passage that led from the bar.

''`Bye, Neville!'' (Bye)
called Stan.

Fudge marched Harry along the narrow passage after Tom's lantern, and then into a small parlor. Tom clicked his (Tom) fingers, a fire burst into life in the grate, and he (Tom) bowed himself out of the room.

``Sit down, Harry,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge, indicating a chair by the fire.

Harry sat down, feeling goose bumps rising up his (Harry) arms despite the glow of the fire. Fudge took off his (Harry) pinstriped cloak and tossed it aside, then hitched up the trousers of his (Harry) bottle-green suit and sat down opposite Harry.

``I am Cornelius Fudge, Harry. The Minister of Magic.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry already knew this, of course; he (Harry) had seen Fudge once before, but as he (Harry) had been wearing his (Harry) father's Invisibility Cloak at the time, Fudge wasn't to know that.

Tom the innkeeper reappeared, wearing an apron over his (Tom) nightshirt and bearing a tray of tea and crumpets. He (Tom) placed the tray on a table between Fudge and Harry and left the parlor, closing the door behind him (Harry).

``Well, Harry,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge, pouring out tea,
``you've had us all in a right flap, I don't mind telling you. Running away from your aunt and uncle's house like that! I'd started to think... but you're safe, and that's what matters.'' (Fudge)

Fudge buttered himself a crumpet and pushed the plate toward Harry.

``Eat, Harry, you look dead on your feet. Now then... You will be pleased to hear that we have dealt with the unfortunate blowing-up of Miss Marjorie Dursley. Two members of the Accidental Magic Reversal Department were dispatched to Privet Drive a few hours ago. Miss Dursley has been punctured and her (Marjorie) memory has been modified. She (Marjorie) has no recollection of the incident at all. So that's that, and no harm done.'' (Fudge)

Fudge smiled at Harry over the rim of his (Harry) teacup, rather like an uncle surveying a favorite nephew. Harry, who couldn't believe his (Harry) ears, opened his (Harry) mouth to speak, couldn't think of anything to say, and closed it again.

``Ah, you're worrying about the reaction of your aunt and uncle?'' (Fudge)
said Fudge.
``Well, I won't deny that they are extremely angry, Harry, but they are prepared to take you back next summer as long as you stay at Hogwarts for the Christmas and Easter holidays.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry unstuck his (Harry) throat.

``I always stay at Hogwarts for the Christmas and Easter holidays,'' (he)
he (Harry) said,
``and I don't ever want to go back to Privet Drive.'' (he)

``Now, now, I'm sure you'll feel differently once you've calmed down,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge in a worried tone.
``They are your family, after all, and I'm sure you are fond of each other -- er -- very deep down.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

It didn't occur to Harry to put Fudge right. He (Harry) was still waiting to hear what was going to happen to him (Harry) now.

``So all that remains,'' (Cornelius Fudge/Fudge/Cornelius)
said Fudge, now buttering himself a second crumpet, ``is to decide where you're going to spend the last two weeks of your vacation. I suggest you take a room here at the Leaky Cauldron and

``Hang on,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
blurted Harry.
``What about my punishment?'' (Fudge)

Fudge blinked.

``Punishment?'' (unknown)

``I broke the law!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said.
``The Decree for the Restriction of Underage Wizardry!'' (unknown)

``Oh, my dear boy, we're not going to punish you for a little thing like that!'' (Fudge)
cried Fudge, waving his (Harry) crumpet impatiently.
``It was an accident! We don't send people to Azkaban just for blowing up their aunts!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

But this didn't tally at all with Harry's past dealings with the Ministry of Magic.

``Last year, I got an official warning just because a house-elf smashed a pudding in my uncle's house!'' (he)
he (Harry) told Fudge, frowning.
``The Ministry of Magic said I'd be expelled from Hogwarts if there was any more magic there!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Unless Harry's eyes were deceiving him (Harry), Fudge was suddenly looking awkward.

``Circumstances change, Harry... We have to take into account... in the present climate... Surely you don't want to be expelled?'' (unknown)

``Of course I don't,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``Well then, what's A the fuss about?'' (Fudge)
laughed Fudge.
``Now, have a crumpet, Harry, while I go and see if Tom's got a room for you.'' (Fudge)

Fudge strode out of the parlor and Harry stared after him (Harry). There was something extremely odd going on. Why had Fudge been waiting for him (Harry) at the Leaky Cauldron, if not to punish him (Harry) for what he (Harry)'d done? And now Harry came to think of it, surely it wasn't usual for the Minister of Magic himself to get involved in matters of underage magic?

Fudge came back, accompanied by Tom the innkeeper.

``Room eleven's free, Harry,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge.
``I think you'll be very comfortable. just one thing, and I'm sure you'll understand... I don't want you wandering off into Muggle London, all right? Keep to Diagon Alley. And you're to be back here before dark each night. Sure you'll understand. Tom will be keeping an eye on you for me.'' (unknown)

``Okay,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry slowly,
``but why?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``Don't want to lose you again, do we?'' (Fudge)
said Fudge with a hearty laugh.
``No, no... best we know where you are... I mean...'' (Fudge)

Fudge cleared his (Harry) throat loudly and picked up his (Harry) pinstriped cloak.

``Well, I'll be off, plenty to do, you know...

``Have you had any luck with Black yet?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry asked.

Fudge's finger slipped on the silver fastenings of his (Harry) cloak.

``What's that? Oh, you've heard -- well, no, not yet, but it's only a matter of time. The Azkaban guards have never yet failed... and they are angrier than I've ever seen them.'' (Fudge)

Fudge shuddered slightly.

``So, I'll say good-bye.'' (He)

He (Harry) held out his (Harry) hand and Harry, shaking it, had a sudden idea.

``Er -- Minister? Can I ask you something?'' (unknown)

``Certainly,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge with a smile.

``Well, third years at Hogwarts are allowed to visit Hogsmeade, but my aunt and uncle didn't sign the permission form. D'you think you could --?'' (Fudge)

Fudge was looking uncomfortable.

``Ah,'' (he)
he (Harry) said.
``No, no, I'm very sorry, Harry, but as I'm not your parent or guardian --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``But you I re the Minister of Magic,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry eagerly. ``If you gave me permission

``No, I'm sorry, Harry, but rules are rules,'' (Fudge)
said Fudge flatly.

``Perhaps You'll be able to visit Hogsmeade next year. In fact, I think it's best if you don't... yes... well, I'll be off Enjoy your stay, Harry.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

And with a last smile and shake of Harry's hand, Fudge left the room. Tom now moved forward, beaming at Harry.

``If you'll follow me, Mr. Potter,'' (he)
he (Harry) said,
``I've already taken your things up...'' (he)

Harry followed Tom up a handsome wooden staircase to a door with a brass number eleven on it, which Tom unlocked and opened for him (Tom).

Inside was a very comfortable-looking bed, some highly polished oak furniture, a cheerfully crackling fire and, perched on top of the wardrobe -

``Hedwig!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry gasped.

The snowy owl clicked her (Harry) beak and fluttered down onto Harry's arm.

``Very smart owl you've got there, chuckled Tom.

``Arrived about five minutes after you did. If there's anything you need, Mr. Potter, don't hesitate to ask.'' (He)

He (Harry) gave another bow and left.

Harry sat on his (Harry) bed for a long time, absentmindedly stroking Hedwig. The sky outside the window was changing rapidly from deep, velvety blue to cold, steely gray and then, slowly, to pink shot with gold. Harry could hardly believe that he (Harry)'d left Privet Drive only a few hours ago, that he (Harry) wasn't expelled, and that he (Harry) was now facing two completely Dursley-free weeks.

``It's been a very weird night, Hedwig,'' (he)
he (Harry) yawned.

And without even removing his (Harry) glasses, he (Harry) slumped back onto his (Harry) pillows and fell asleep.

CHAPTER FOUR

THE LEAKY CAULDRON

It took Harry several days to get used to his (Harry) strange new freedom. Never before had he (Harry) been able to get up whenever he (Harry) wanted or eat whatever he (Harry) fancied. He (Harry) could even go wherever he (Harry) pleased, as long as it was in Diagon Alley, and as this long cobbled street was packed with the most fascinating wizarding shops in the world, Harry felt no desire to break his (Harry) word to Fudge and stray back into the Muggle world.

Harry ate breakfast each morning in the Leaky Cauldron, where he (Harry) liked watching the other guests: funny little witches from the country, up for a day's shopping; venerable-looking wizards arguing over the latest article in Transfiguration Today; wild-looking warlocks; raucous dwarfs; and once, what looked suspiciously like a hag, who ordered a plate of raw liver from behind a thick woollen balaclava.

After breakfast Harry would go out into the backyard, take out his (Harry) wand, tap the third brick from the left above the trash bit,, and stand back as the archway into Diagon Alley opened in the wall.

Harry spent the long sunny days exploring the shops and eating under the brightly colored umbrellas outside cafes, where his (Harry) fellow diners were showing one another their purchases -LRB-

'' it , s a lunascope, old boy -- no more messing around with moon charts, see?'' (fellow diners)
-RRB- or else discussing the case of Sirius Black -LRB-
``personalty, I won't let any of the children out alone until he (Potter)'s back in Azkaban'' (Black/Sirius/Sirius Black)
-RRB-. Harry didn't have to do his (Harry) homework under the blankets by flashlight anymore; now he (Harry) could sit in the bright sunshine outside Florean Fortescue's Ice Cream Parlor, finishing all his (Harry) essays with occasional help from Florean Fortescue himself, who, apart from knowing a great deal about medieval witch burnings, gave Harry free sundaes every half an hour.

Once Harry had refilled his (Harry) money bag with gold Galleons, silver Sickles, and bronze Knuts from his (Harry) vault at Gringotts, he (Harry) had to exercise a lot of self-control not to spend the whole lot at once. He (Harry) had to keep reminding himself that he (Harry) had five years to go at Hogwarts, and how it would feel to ask the Dursleys for money for spellbooks, to stop himself from buying a handsome set of solid gold Gobstones -LRB-a wizarding game rather like marbles, in which the stones squirt a nasty-smelling liquid into the other player's face when they lose a point-RRB-. He (player) was sorely tempted, too, by the perfect, moving model of the galaxy in a large glass ball, which would have meant he (player) never had to take another Astronomy lesson. But the thing that tested Harry's resolution most appeared in his (Harry) favorite shop, Quality Quidditch Supplies, a week after he (Harry)'d arrived at the Leaky Cauldron.

Curious to know what the crowd in the shop was staring at, Harry edged his (Harry) way inside and squeezed in among the excited witches and wizards until he (Harry) glimpsed a newly erected podium, on which was mounted the most magnificent broom he (Harry) had ever seen in his (Harry) life.

``Just come out -- prototype --'' (a wizard)
a square-jawed wizard was telling his (Harry) companion.

``It's the fastest broom in the world, isn't it, Dad?'' (a boy)
squeaked a boy younger than Harry, who was swinging off his (Harry) father's arm.

``Irish International Side's Just put in an order for seven of these beauties!'' (the proprietor)
the proprietor of the shop told the crowd.
``And they're favorites for the World Cup!'' (A witch)

A large witch in front of Harry moved, and he (Harry) was able to read the sign next to the broom:

** THE FIREBOLT **

THIS STATE-OF-THE-ART PACING BROOM SPORTS A STREAM-LINED, SUPERFINE HANDLE OF ASH, TREATED WITH A DIAMOND-HARD POLISH AND HAND- NUMBERED WITH ITS OWN REGISTRATION NUMBER. EACH INDIVIDUALLY SELECTED BIRCH TWIG IN THE BROOMTAIL HAS BEEN HONED TO AERODYNAMIC PERFECTION, GIVING THE FIREBOLT UNSURPASSABLE BALANCE AND PINPOINT PRECISION. THE FIREBOLT HAS AN ACCELERATION OF 150 MILES AN HOUR IN TEN SECONDS AND INCORPORATES AN UNBREAKABLE BRAKING CHARM. PRICE ON REQUEST.

Price on request... Harry didn't like to think how much gold the Firebolt would cost. He (Harry) had never wanted anything as much in his (Harry) whole life -- but he (Harry) had never lost a Quidditch match on his (Harry) Nim bus Two Thousand, and what was the point in emptying his (Harry) Gringotts vault for the Firebolt, when he (Harry) had a very good broom already? Harry didn't ask for the price, but he (Harry) returned, almost every day after that, just to look at the Firebolt.

There were, however, things that Harry needed to buy. He (Harry) went to the Apothecary to replenish his (Harry) store of potions ingredients, and as his (Harry) school robes were now several inches too short in the arm and leg, he (Harry) visited Madam Malkin's Robes for All Occasions and bought new ones. Most important of all, he (Harry) had to buy his (Harry) new schoolbooks, which would include those for his (Harry) two new subjects, Care of Magical Creatures and Divination.

Harry got a surprise as he (Harry) looked in at the bookshop window. Instead of the usual display of gold- embossed spellbooks the size of paving slabs, there was a large iron cage behind the glass that held about a hundred copies of The Monster Book of Monsters. Torn pages were flying everywhere as the books grappled with each other, locked together in furious wrestling matches and snapping aggressively.

Harry pulled his (Harry) booklist out of his (Harry) pocket and consulted it for the first time. The Monster Book of Monsters was listed as the required book for Care of Magical Creatures. Now Harry understood why Hagrid had said it would come in useful. He (Harry) felt relieved; he (Harry) had been wondering whether Hagrid wanted help with some terrifying new pet.

As Harry entered Flourish and Blotts, the manager came hurrying toward him (Harry).

``Hogwarts?'' (he)
he (Harry) said abruptly.
``Come to get your new books?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry,
``I need --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``Get out of the way,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said the manager impatiently, brushing Harry aside. He (Harry) drew on a pair of very thick gloves, picked up a large, knobbly walking stick, and proceeded toward the door of the Monster Books' cage.

``Hang on,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry quickly,
``I've already got one of those.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``Have you?'' (the manager)
A look of enormous relief spread over the manager's face.
``Thank heavens for that. I've been bitten five times already this morning --'' (unknown)

A loud ripping noise rent the air; two of the Monster Books had seized a third and were pulling it apart.

``Stop it! Stop it!'' (the manager)
cried the manager, poking the walking stick through the bars and knocking the books apart.
``I'm never stocking them again, never! It's been bedlam! I thought we'd seen the worst when we bought two hundred copies of the Invisible Book of Invisibility -cost a fortune, and we never found them... Well... is there anything else I can help you with?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, looking down his (Harry) booklist,
``I need Unfogging the Future by Cassandra Vablatsky.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``Ah, starting Divination, are you?'' (the manager)
said the manager, stripping off his (Harry) gloves and leading Harry into the back of the shop, where there was a corner devoted to fortune-telling. A small table was stacked with volumes such as Predicting the Unpredictable: Insulate Yourself Against Shocks and Broken Balls: When Fortunes Turn Foul.

``Here you are,,'' (the manager)
said the manager, who had climbed a set of steps to take down a thick, black- bound book. ``Unfogging the Future. Very good guide to all your basic fortune-telling methods - palmistry, crystal balls, bird entrails.

But Harry wasn't listening. His (Harry) eyes had fallen on another book, which was among a display on a small table: Death Omens.- What to Do When You Know the Worst Is Coming.

``Oh, I wouldn't read that if I were you,'' (the manager)
said the manager lightly, looking to see what Harry was staring at.
``You'll start seeing death omens everywhere. It's enough to frighten anyone to death. '' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

But Harry continued to stare at the front cover of the book; it showed a black dog large as a bear, with gleaming eyes. It looked oddly familiar...

The manager pressed Unfogging the Future into Harry's hands.

``Anything else?'' (he)
he (Harry) said.

``Yes,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, tearing his (Harry) eyes away from the dog's and dazedly consulting his (Harry) booklist.
``Er -- I need Intermediate Transfiguration and The Standard Book of Spells, Grade Three.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry emerged from Flourish and Blotts ten minutes later with his (Harry) new books under his (Harry) arms and made his (Harry) way back to the Leaky Cauldron, hardly noticing where he (Harry) was going and bumping into several people.

He (Harry) tramped up the stairs to his (Harry) room, went inside, and tipped his (Harry) books onto his (Harry) bed. Somebody had been in to tidy; the windows were open and sun was pouring inside. Harry could hear the buses rolling by in the unseen Muggle street behind him (Harry) and the sound of the invisible crowd below in Diagon Alley. He (Harry) caught sight of himself in the mirror over the basin.

``It can't have been a death omen,'' (he)
he (Harry) told his (Harry) reflection defiantly.
``I was panicking when I saw that thing in Magnolia Crescent... It was probably just a stray dog...'' (He)

He (Harry) raised his (Harry) hand automatically and tried to make his (Harry) hair lie flat

``You're fighting a losing battle there, dear,'' (He)
said his (Harry) mirror in a vvheezy voice.

As the days slipped by, Harry started looking wherever he (Harry) went for a sign of Ron or Hermione. Plenty of Hogwarts students were arriving in Diagon Alley now, with the start of term so near. Harry met Seamus Finnigan and Dean Thomas, his (Harry) fellow Gryffindors, in Quality Quidditch Supplies, where they too were ogling the Firebolt; he (Harry) also ran into the real Neville Longbottom, a round-faced, forgetful boy, outside Flourish and Blotts. Harry didn't stop to chat; Neville appeared to have mislaid his (Harry) booklist and was being told off by his (Harry) very formidable-looking grandmother. Harry hoped she (grandmother) never found out that he (Harry)'d pretended to be Neville while on the run from the Ministry of Magic.

Harry woke on the last day of the holidays, thinking that he (Harry) would at least meet Ron and Hermione tomorrow, on the Hogwarts Express. He (Express) got up, dressed, went for a last look at the Firebolt, and was just wondering where he (Express)'d have lunch, when someone yelled his (Express) name and he (Express) turned.

``Harry! HARRY!'' (Florean Fortescue/Fortescue)

They were there, both of them, sitting outside Florean Fortescue's Ice Cream Parlor -- Ron looking incredibly freckly, Her (Hermione),,one very brown, both waving frantically at him (Ron).

said Ron, grinning at Harry as he (Harry) sat down.

Harry explained.

admitted Harry.

shrugged Ron, still chuckling.

he (Ron) added, placing Scabbers on the table in front of them.

Scabbers was looking thinner than usual, and there was a definite droop to his (Ron) whiskers.

``There's a magical creature shop just over there,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, who knew Diagon Alley very well by now.
``You could see if they've got anything for Scabbers, and Hermione can get her (Hermione) owl,'' (ice cream)

So they paid for their ice cream and crossed the street to the Magical Menagerie.

There wasn't much room inside. Every inch of wall was hidden by cages. It was smelly and very noisy because the occupants Of these cages were all squeaking, squawking, jabbering, or hissing. The witch behind the counter was already advising a wizard on the care of double-ended newts, so Harry, Ron, and Hermione waited, examining the cages.

A pair of enormous purple toads sat gulping wetly and feasting on dead blowflies. A gigantic tortoise with a jewel-encrusted shell was glittering near the window. Poisonous orange snails were oozing slowly up the side of their glass tank, and a fat white rabbit kept changing into a silk top hat and back again with a loud popping noise. Then there were cats of every color, a noisy cage of ravens, a basket of funny custard-colored furballs that were humming loudly, and on the counter, a vast cage of sleek black rats that were playing some sort of skipping game using their long, bald tails.

The double-ended newt wizard left, and Ron approached the counter.

``It's my rat,'' (he)
he (Ron) told the witch.
``He (Errol) been a bit off-color ever since I brought him (Errol) back from Egypt.'' (unknown)

``Bang him (Errol) on the counter,'' (the witch)
said the witch, pulling a pair of heavy black spectacles out of her (witch) pocket.

Ron lifted Scabbers out of his (Ron) inside pocket and placed him (Ron) next to the cage of his (Ron) fellow rats, who stopped their skipping tricks and scuffled to the wire for a better took.

Like nearly everything Ron owned, Scabbers the rat was secondhand -LRB-he (Ron) had once belonged to Ron's brother Percy-RRB- and a bit battered. Next to the glossy rats in the cage, he (Ron) looked especially woebegone.

``Hm,'' (the witch)
said the witch, picking up Scabbers.
``How old is this rat?'' (unknown)

``Dunno,'' (Ron)
said Ron.
``Quite old. He (Errol) used to belong to my brother.'' (unknown)

``What powers does he (Errol) have?'' (the witch)
said the witch, examining Scabbers closely.

``Er --'' (Scabbers)
The truth was that Scabbers had never shown the faintest trace of interesting powers. The witchs eyes moved from Scabbers's tattered left ear to his (Ron) front paw, which had a toe missing, and tutted loudly.

``He (Errol)'s been through the mill, this one,'' (she)
she (witch) said.

``He (Errol) was like that when Percy gave him (Percy) to me,'' (Ron)
said Ron defensively.

``An ordinary common or garden rat like this can't be expected to live longer than three years or so,'' (the witch)
said the witch.
``Now, if you were looking for something a bit more hard-wearing, you might like one of these --'' (She)

She (witch) indicated the black rats, who promptly started skipping again. Ron muttered,

``Show-offs.'' (Ron)

``Well, if you Don't want a replacement, you can try this rat tonic,'' (the witch)
said the witch, reaching under the counter and bringing out a small red bottle.

``Okay,'' (Ron)
said Ron.
``How much -- OUCH!'' (Ron)

Ron buckled as something huge and orange came soaring from the top of the highest cage, landed on his (Ron) head, and then propelled itself, spitting madly, at Scabbers.

``NO, CROOKSHANKS, NO!'' (the witch)
cried the witch, but Scabbers, shot from between her (witch) hands like a bar of soap, landed splay-legged on the floor, and then scampered for the door.

``Scabbers!'' (Ron)
Ron shouted, racing out of the shop after him (Ron); Harry followed.

It took them nearly ten minutes to catch Scabbers, who had taken refuge under a wastepaper bin outside Quality Quidditch Supplies. Ron stuffed the trembling rat back into his (Ron) pocket and straightened up, massaging his (Ron) head.

``What was that?'' (unknown)

``It was either a very big cat or quite a small tiger,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``Probably getting her (Hermione) owl

They made their way back up the crowded street to the Magical Menagerie. As they reached it, Hermione came out, but she (Hermione) wasn't carrying an owl. Her (Hermione) arms were clamped tightly around the enormous ginger cat.

``You bought that monster?'' (Ron)
said Ron, his (Ron) mouth hanging open.

``He (they)'s gorgeous, isn't he (they)?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, glowing.

That was a matter of opinion, thought Harry. The cat's ginger fur was thick and fluffy, but it was definitely a bit bowlegged and its face looked grumpy and oddly squashed, as though it had run headlong into a brick wall. Now that Scabbers was out of sight, however, the cat was purring contentedly in Hermione's arms.

``Herinione, that thing nearly scalped me!'' (Ron)
said Ron.

said Ron sarcastically as they set off toward the Leaky Cauldron.

They found Mr. Weasley sitting in the bar, reading the Daily prophet.

At that moment Mrs. Weasley entered the bar, laden with shopping bags and followed by the twins, Fred and George, who were about to start their fifth year at Hogwarts; the newly elected Head Boy, Percy; and the Weasleys' youngest child and only girl, Ginny.

Ginny, who had always been very taken with Harry, seemed even more heartily embarrassed than usual when she (Ginny) saw him (Harry), perhaps because he (Harry) had saved her (Ginny) life during their previous year at Hogwarts. She (Ginny) went very red and muttered

``hello'' (She)

Dinner that night was a very enjoyable affair. Tom the innkeeper put three tables together in the parlor, and the seven Weasleys, Harry, and Hermione ate their way through five delicious courses.

``How're we getting to King's Cross tomorrow, Dad?'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)

After dinner everyone felt very full and sleepy. One by one they made their way upstairs to their rooms to check their things for the next day. Ron and Percy were next door to Harry. ``But he (Knight)'s not dead, he (Knight)'s fine, so what's the point

It's been three weeks, and no one's seen hide nor hair of him (Black), and I don't care what Fudge keeps telling the Daily Prophet, we're no nearer catching Black than inventing self-spelling wands. The only thing we know for sure is what Black's after

``But Harry will be perfectly safe at Hogwarts.'' (unknown)

``But no one's really sure that Black's after Harry

There was a thud on wood, and Harry was sure Mr. Weasley had banged his (Harry) fist on the table.

``Molly, how many times do I have to tell you? They didn't report it in the press because Fudge wanted it kept quiet, but Fudge went out to Azkaban the night Black escaped. The guards told Fudge that Blacks been talking in his (Fudge) sleep for a while now. Always the same words: ``He (Fudge)'s at Hogwarts... he (Fudge)'s at Hogwarts.

'' Black is deranged, Molly, and he (Black) wants Harry dead. If you ask me, he (Harry) thinks murdering Harry will bring You-Know-Who back to pow er. Black lost everything the night Harry stopped You- Know-Who, and he (Harry)'s had twelve years alone in Azkaban to brood on that...'' (Hogwarts/Hogwarts Express)

There was a silence. Harry leaned still closer to the door, desperate to hear more.

``Well, Arthur, you must do what you think is right. But you're forgetting Albus Dumbledore. I don't think anything could hurt Harry at Hogwarts while Dumbledore's headmaster. I suppose he (Harry) knows about all this?'' (unknown)

``Of course he (Harry) knows. We had to ask him (Harry) if he (Harry) minds the Azkaban guards stationing themselves around the entrances to the school grounds. He (Harry) wasn't happy about it, but he (Harry) agreed.'' (unknown)

``Not happy? Why shouldn't he (Harry) be happy, if they're there to catch Black?'' (unknown)

``Dumbledore isn't fond of the Azkaban guards,'' (Mr. Weasley)
said Mr. Weasley heavily.
``Nor am 1, if it comes to that... but when you're dealing with a wizard like Black, you sometimes have to join forces with those you'd rather avoid.'' (unknown)

``If they save Harry then I will never say another word against them, said Mr. Weasley wearily.

``It's late, Molly, we'd better go up...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry heard chairs move. As quietly as he (Harry) could, he (Harry) hurried down the passage to the bar and out of sight. The parlor door opened, and a few seconds later footsteps told him (Harry) that Mr. and Mrs. Weasley were climbing the stairs.

The bottle of rat tonic was lying under the table they had sat at earlier. Harry waited until he (Harry) heard Mr. and Mrs. Weasley's bedroom door close, then headed back upstairs with the bottle.

Fred and George were crouching in the shadows on the landing, heaving with laughter as they listened to Percy dismantling his (Percy) and Ron's room in search of his (Percy) badge.

``We've got it,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
Fred whispered to Harry.
``We've been improving it.'' (Bighead Boy)

The badge now read Bighead Boy.

Harry forced a laugh, went to give Ron the rat tonic, then shut himself in his (Harry) room and lay down on his (Harry) bed.

So Sirius Black was after him (Black). This explained everything. Fudge had been lenient with him (Black) because he (Black) was so relieved to find him (Black) alive. He (Black)'d made Harry promise to stay in Diagon Alley where there were plenty of wizards to keep an eye on him (Harry). And he (Harry) was sending two Ministry cars to take them all to the station tomorrow, so that the Weasleys could look after Harry until he (Harry) was on the train.

Harry lay listening to the muffled shouting next door and wondered why he (Harry) didn't feel more scared. Sirius Black had murdered thirteen people with one curse; Mr. and Mrs, Weasley obviously thought Harry would be panic-stricken if he (Harry) knew the truth. But Harry happened to agree wholeheartedly with Mrs. Weasley that the safest place on earth was wherever Albus Dumbledore happened to be. Didn't people always say that Dumbledore was the only person Lord Voldemort had ever been afraid of? Surely Black, as Voldemort's right-hand man, would be just as frightened of him (Voldemort)?

And then there were these Azkaban guards everyone kept talking about. They seemed to scare most people senseless, and if they were stationed all around the school, Black's chances of getting inside seemed very remote.

No, all in all, the thing that bothered Harry most was the fact that his (Harry) chances of visiting Hogsmeade now looked like zero. Nobody would want Harry to leave the safety of the castle until Black was caught; in fact, Harry suspected his (Harry) every move would be carefully watched until the danger had passed.

He (Harry) scowled at the dark ceiling. Did they think he (Harry) couldn't look after himself? He (Harry)'d escaped Lord Voldemort three times; he (Harry) wasn't completely useless...

Unbidden, the image of the beast in the shadows of Magnolia Crescent crossed his (Harry) mind. What to do when you know the worst is coming...

``I'm not going to be murdered,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said out loud.

``That's the spirit, dear,'' (unknown)
said his (Harry) mirror sleepily.

CHAPTER FIVE

THE DEMENTOR

Tom woke Harry the next morning with his (Harry) usual toothless grin and a cup of tea. Harry got dressed and was just persuading a disgruntled Hedwig to get back into her (Hedwig) cage when Ron banged his (Ron) way into the room, pulling a sweatshirt over his (Ron) head and looking irritable.

``The sooner we get on the train, the better,'' (he)
he (Ron) said.
``At least I can get away from Percy at Hogwarts. Now he (Percy)'s accusing me of dripping tea on his (Percy) photo of Penelope Clearwater. You know,'' (Ron)
Ron grimaced,
``his (Percy) girlfriend. She (girlfriend)'s hidden her (girlfriend) face under the frame because her (girlfriend) nose has gone all blotchy...'' (Ron)

``I've got something to tell you,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry began, but they were interrupted by Fred and George, who had looked in to congratulate Ron on infuriating Percy again.

They headed down to breakfast, where Mr. Weasley was reading the front page of the Daily Prophet with a furrowed brow and Mrs. Weasley was telling Hermione and Ginny about a love potion she (Ginny)'d made as a young girl. All three of them were rather giggly.

``What were you saying?'' (Ron)
Ron asked Harry as they sat down.

``Later,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry muttered as Percy stormed in.

Harry had no chance to speak to Ron or Hermione in the chaos of leaving; they were too busy heaving all their trunks down the Leaky Cauldron's narrow staircase and piling them up near the door, with Hedwig and Hermes, Percy's screech owl, perched on top in their cages. A small wickerwork basket stood beside the heap of trunks, spitting loudly.

``It's all right, Crookshanks,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
Hermione cooed through the wickerwork.
``I'll let you out on the train.'' (unknown)

``You won't,'' (Ron)
snapped Ron.
``What about poor Scabbers, eh?'' (He)

He (Ron) pointed at his (Ron) chest, where a large lump indicated that Scabbers was curled up in his (Ron) pocket.

Mr. Weasley, who had been outside waiting for the Ministry cars, stuck his (Weasley) head inside.

``They're here, he (Percy) said.

``Harry, come on.'' (Mr. Weasley)

Mr. Weasley marched Harry across the short stretch of pavement toward the first of two old- fashioned dark green cars, each of which was driven by a furtive-looking wizard wearing a suit of emerald velvet.

``In you get, Harry,'' (Mr. Weasley)
said Mr. Weasley, glancing up and down the crowded street.

Harry got into the back of the car and was shortly joined by Hermione, Ron, and, to Ron's disgust, Percy.

The journey to King's Cross was very uneventful compared with Harry's trip on the Knight Bus. The Ministry of Magic cars seemed almost ordinary. though Harry noticed that they could slide through gaps that Uncle Vernon's new company car certainly couldn't have managed. They reached King's Cross with twenty minutes to spare; the Ministry drivers found them trolleys, unloaded their trunks, touched their hats in salute to Mr. Weasley, and drove away, somehow managing to jump to the head of an unmoving line at the traffic lights.

Mr. Weasley kept close to Harry's elbow all the way into the station.

``Right then,'' (he)
he (Harry) said, glancing around them.
``Let's do this in pairs, as there are so many of us. I'll go through first with Harry.'' (Mr. Weasley)

Mr. Weasley strolled toward the barrier between platforms nine and ten, pushing Harry's trolley and apparently very interested in the InterCity 125 that had just arrived at platform nine. With a meaningful look at Harry, he (Harry) leaned casually against the barrier. Harry imitated him (Harry).

In a moment, they had fallen sideways through the solid metal onto platform nine and three- quarters and looked up to see the Hogwarts Express, a scarlet steam engine, puffing smoke over a platform packed with witches and wizards seeing their children onto the train.

Percy and Ginny suddenly appeared behind Harry. They were panting and had apparently taken the barrier at a run.

``Ah, there's Penelope!'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
said Percy, smoothing his (Percy) hair and going Pink again. Ginny caught Harry's eye, and they both turned away to hide their laughter as Percy strode over to a girl with long, curly hair, walking with his (Percy) chest thrown out so that she (girl) couldn't miss his (Percy) shiny badge. stood back to let him (Percy) on. They leaned out of the window and waved at Mr. and Mrs. Weasley until the train turned a corner and blocked them from view.

``I need to talk to you in private,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry muttered to Ron and Hermione as the train picked up speed.

``Go away, Ginny,'' (Ron)
said Ron.

``Oh, that's nice,'' (Ginny)
said Ginny huffily, and she (Ginny) stalked off.

Harry, Ron, and Hermione set off down the corridor, looking for an empty compartment, but all were full except for the one at the very end of the train.

This had only one occupant, a man sitting fast asleep next to the window. Harry, Ron, and Hermione checked on the threshold. The Hogwarts Express was usually reserved for students and they had never seen an adult there before, except for the witch who pushed the food cart.

The stranger was wearing an extremely shabby set of wizard's robes that had been darned in several places. He (stranger) looked ill and exhausted. Though quite young, his (stranger) light brown hair was flecked with gray.

``Who d'you reckon he (Harry) is?'' (Ron)
Ron hissed as they sat down and slid the door shut, taking the seats farthest away from the window.

``Professor R. J. Lupin,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
whispered Hermione at once.

``How d'you know that?'' (unknown)

``It's on his (Harry) case,'' (she)
she (Hermione) replied, pointing at the luggage rack over the man's head, where there was a small, battered case held together with a large quantity of neatly knotted string. The name Professor R. J. Lupin was stamped across one corner in peeling letters.

``Wonder what he (Harry) teaches?'' (Ron)
said Ron, frowning at Professor Lupin's pallid profile.

``That's obvious,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
whispered Hermione.
``There's only one vacancy, isn't there? Defense Against the Dark Arts.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry, Ron, and Hermione had already had two Defense Against the Dark Arts teachers, both of whom had lasted only one year. There were rumors that the job was jinxed.

``well, I hope he (Harry)'s up to it,'' (Ron)
said Ron doubtfully.
``He (Harry) looks like on, good hex would finish him (Harry) off, doesn't he (Harry)? Anyway...'' (He)
He (Ron) turned to Harry.
``What were you going to tell us?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry explained all about Mr. and Mrs. Weasley's argument and the warning Mr. Weasley had just given him (Weasley). \When he (Weasley)'d finished, Ron looked thunderstruck, and Hermione had her (Hermione) hands over her (Hermione) mouth. She (Hermione) finally lowered them to say,

``Sirius Black escaped to come after you? Oh, Harry... you'll have to be really, really careful. don't go looking for trouble, Harry --'' (She)

``I Don't go looking for trouble,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, nettled.
``Trouble usually finds me.'' (unknown)

``How thick would Harry have to be, to go looking for a nutter who wants to kill him (Harry)?'' (Ron)
said Ron shakily.

They were taking the news worse than Harry had expected. Both Ron and Hermione seemed to be much more frightened of Black than he (Ron) was.

``No one knows how he (Harry) got out of Azkaban,'' (Ron)
said Ron uncomfortably.
``No one's ever done it before. And he (Harry) was a top-security prisoner too.'' (unknown)

``But they'll catch him (Harry), won't they?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione earnestly.
``I Mean, they've got all the Muggles looking out for him (Harry) too...'' (unknown)
``What's that noise?'' (Ron)
said Ron suddenly.

A faint, tinny sort of whistle was coming from somewhere. The, looked all around the compartment.

``It's coming from your trunk, Harry,'' (Ron)
said Ron, standing UP and reaching into the luggage rack. A moment later he (Ron) had pulled the Pocket Sneakoscope out from between Harry's robes. It was spinning very fast in the palm of Ron's hand and glowing brilliantly.

``Is that a Sneakoscope?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione interestedly, standing up for a better look.

``Yeah... mind you, it's a very cheap one,'' (Ron)
Ron said.
``It went haywire just as I was tying it to Errol's leg to send it to Harry.'' (unknown)

``Were you doing anything untrustworthy at the time?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione shrewdly.

``No! Well... I wasn't supposed to be using Errol. You know he (Errol)'s not really up to long journeys... but how else was I supposed to get Harry's present to him (Harry)?'' (unknown)

``Stick it back in the trunk,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry advised as the Sneakoscope whistled piercingly,
``or it'll wake him (Harry) up.'' (Sneakoscope)

He (Harry) nodded toward Professor Lupin. Ron stuffed the Sneakoscope into a particularly horrible pair of Uncle Vernon's old socks, which deadened the sound, then closed the lid of the trunk on it.

``We could get it checked in Hogsmeade,'' (Ron)
said Ron, sitting back down.
``They sell that sort of thing in Dervish and Banges, magical instruments and stuff. Fred and George told me.'' (unknown)

``Do you know much about Hogsmeade?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
asked Hermione keenly.
``I've read it's the only entirely non-Muggle settlement in Britain --'' (Ron)

``Yeah, I think it is,'' (Ron)
said Ron in an offhand sort of way.

``But that's not Why I want to go. I just want to get inside Honey Dukes.'' (unknown)

``What's that?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione.

``It's this sweetshop,'' (Ron)
said Ron, a dreamy look coming over his (Ron) face,
``where they've got everything... Pepper Imps -- they make you smoke at the mouth -- and great fat Chocoballs full of strawberry mousse and clotted cream, and really excellent sugar quills, which you can suck in class and just look like you're thinking what to write next --'' (Ron)

``But Hogsmeade's a very interesting place, isn't it?'' (Ron)
Hermione pressed on eagerly.
``In Sites of Historical Sorcery it says the inn was the headquarters for the 1612 goblin rebellion, and the Shrieking Shades supposed to be the most severely haunted building in Britain --'' (Ron)

''-- and massive sherbert balls that make you levitate a few inches off the ground while you're sucking them,'' (Ron)
said Ron, who was plainly not listening to a word Hermione was saying.

Hermione looked around at Harry.

``Won't it be nice to get out of school for a bit and explore Hogsmeade?'' (unknown)

''`Spect it will,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry heavily.
``You'll have to tell me when You've found out.'' (unknown)

``What d'you mean?'' (Ron)
said Ron.

``I can't go. The Dursleys didn't sign my permission form, and Fudge wouldn't either.'' (Ron)

Ron looked horrified.

''

``You're not allowed to come? But -- no way -- McGonagall or someone will give you permission -- '' (unknown)
musclely; Crabbe was taller, with a pudding-bowl haircut and a very thick neck; Goyle had short, bristly hair and long, gorilla-ish arms.

said Malfoy in his (Malfoy) usual lazy drawl, pulling open the compartment door.

Crabbe and Goyle chuckled trollishly.

said Malfoy.
``Did your mother die of shock?'' (Ron)

Ron stood up so quickly he (Ron) knocked Crookshanks's basket to the floor. Professor Lupin gave a snort.

``Who's that?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy, taking an automatic step backward as he (Malfoy) spotted Lupin.

``New teacher,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, who got to his (Harry) feet, too, in case he (Harry) needed to hold Ron back.
``What were you saying, Malfoy?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

Malfoy's pale eyes narrowed; he (Malfoy) wasn't fool enough to pick a fight right under a teacher's nose.

``C'mon,'' (he)
he (Malfoy) muttered resentfully to Crabbe and Goyle, and they disappeared.

Harry and Ron sat down again, Ron massaging his (Ron) knuckles.

``I'm not going to take any crap from Malfoy this year,'' (he)
he (Ron) said angrily.
``I mean it. If he (Malfoy) makes one more crack about my family, I'm going to get hold of his (Malfoy) head and --'' (Ron)

Ron made a violent gesture in midair.

``Ron,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
hissed Hermione, pointing at Professor Lupin,
``be careful...'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)

But Professor Lupin was still fast asleep.

The rain thickened as the train sped yet farther north; the windows were now a solid, shimmering gray, which graduily darkened until lanterns flickered into life all along the corridors and over the luggage racks. The train rattled, the rain hammered, the ind roared, but still, Professor Lupin slept.

``We must be nearly there,'' (Ron)
said Ron, leaning forward to look past Professor Lupin at the now completely black window.

The words had hardly left him (Ron) when the train started to slow down.

``Great,'' (Ron)
said Ron, getting up and walking carefully past Professor Lupin to try and see outside. ``I'm starving. I want to get to the feast...

``We can't be there yet,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, checking her (Hermione) watch.

``So why're we stopping?'' (unknown)

The train was getting slower and slower. As the noise of the pistons fell away, the wind and rain sounded louder than ever against the windows.

Harry, who was nearest the door, got up to look into the corridor. All along the carriage, heads were sticking curiously out of their compartments.

The train came to a stop with a jolt, and distant thuds and bangs told them that luggage had fallen out of the racks. Then, without warning, all the lamps went out and they were plunged into total darkness.

''`What's going on?'' (Ron)
said Ron's voice from behind Harry.

``Ouch!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
gasped Hermione.
``Ron, that was my foot!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry felt his (Harry) way back to his (Harry) seat.

``D'you think we've broken down?'' (unknown)

``Dunno...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

There was a squeaking sound, and Harry saw the dim black outline of Ron, wiping a patch clean on the window and peering out.

``There's something moving out there,'' (Ron)
Ron said.
``I think people are coming aboard...'' (someone)

The compartment door suddenly opened and someone fell painfully over Harry's legs.

``Sorry -- d'you know what's going on? -- Ouch -- sorry

``Hullo, Neville,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, feeling around in the dark and pulling Neville up by his (Neville) cloak.

``Harry? Is that you? What's happening?'' (unknown)

``No idea -- sit down --'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

There was a loud hissing and a yelp of pain; Neville had tried to sit on Crookshanks.

``I'm going to go and ask the driver what's going on,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
came Hermione's voice. Harry felt her (Hermione) pass him (Harry), heard the door slide open again, and then a thud and two loud squeals of pain.

``Who's that?'' (unknown)

``Who's that?'' (unknown)

``Ginny?'' (unknown)

``Hermione?'' (unknown)

``What are you doing?'' (unknown)

``I was looking for Ron --'' (unknown)

``Not here!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry hurriedly.
``I'm here!'' (unknown)

``Ouch!'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville.

``Quiet!'' (unknown)
said a hoarse voice suddenly.

Professor Lupin appeared to have woken up at last. Harry could hear movements in his (Harry) corner.

None of them spoke.

There was a soft, crackling noise, and a shivering light filled the compartment. Professor Lupin appeared to be holding a handful of flames. They illuminated his (Professor) tired, gray face, but his (Professor) eyes looked alert and wary.

``Stay where you are,'' (he)
he (Professor) said in the same hoarse voice, and he (Professor) got slowly to his (Professor) feet with his (Professor) handful of fire held out in front of him (Professor).

But the door slid slowly open before Lupin could reach it.

Standing in the doorway, illuminated by the shivering flames in Lupin's hand, was a cloaked figure that towered to the ceiling. Its face was completely hidden beneath its hood. Harry's eyes darted downward, and what he (Harry) saw made his (Harry) stomach contract. There was a hand protruding from the cloak and it was glistening, grayish, slimy-looking, and scabbed, like something dead that had decayed in water...

But it was visible only for a split second. As though the creature beneath the cloak sensed Harry's gaze, the hand was suddenly withdrawn into the folds of its black cloak.

And then the thing beneath the hood, whatever it was, drew a long, slow, rattling breath, as though it were trying to suck something more than air from its surroundings.

An intense cold swept over them all. Harry felt his (Harry) own breath catch in his (Harry) chest. The cold went deeper than his (Harry) skin. It was inside his (Harry) chest, it was inside his (Harry) very heart...

Harry's eyes rolled up into his (Harry) head. He (Harry) couldn't see. He (Harry) was drowning in cold. There was a rushing in his (Harry) ears as though of water. He (Harry) was being dragged downward, the roaring growing louder. .

And then, from far away, he (Harry) heard screaming, terrible, terrified, pleading screams. He (Harry) wanted to help whoever it was, he (Harry) tried to move his (Harry) arms, but couldn't... a thick white fog was swirling around him (Harry), inside him (Harry) -

``Harry! Harry! Are you all right?'' (him)

Someone was slapping his (Harry) face.

``W -- what?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry opened his (Harry) eyes; there were lanterns above him (Harry), and the floor was shaking -- the Hogwarts Express was moving again and the lights had come back on. He (Express) seemed to have slid out of his (Express) seat onto the floor. Ron and Hermione were kneeling next to him (Ron), and above them he (Ron) could see Neville and Professor Lupin watching. Harry felt very sick; when he (Harry) put up his (Harry) hand to push his (Harry) glasses back on, he (Harry) felt cold sweat on his (Harry) face.

Ron and Hermione heaved him (Ron) back onto his (Ron) seat.

``Are you okay?'' (Ron)
Ron asked nervously.

``Yeah,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, looking quickly toward the door. The hooded creature had vanished.
``What happened? Where's that -- that thing? Who screamed?'' (unknown)

``No one screamed,'' (Ron)
said Ron, more nervously still.

Harry looked around the bright compartment. Ginny and Neville looked back at him (Harry), both very pale.

``But I heard screaming --'' (Professor)

A loud snap made them all jump. Professor Lupin was breaking an enormous slab of chocolate into pieces.

``Here,'' (he)
he (Professor) said to Harry, handing him (Harry) a particularly large piece.
``Eat it. It'll help.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry took the chocolate but didn't eat it.

``What was that thing?'' (he)
he (Harry) asked Lupin.

``A dementor,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, who was now giving chocolate to everyone else.
``One of the dementors of Azkaban.'' (Everyone)

Everyone stared at him (Harry). Professor Lupin crumpled up the empty chocolate wrapper and put it in his (Professor) pocket.

``Eat,'' (he)
he (Professor) repeated. ``It'll help. I need to speak to the driver, excuse me...

He (driver) strolled past Harry and disappeared into the corridor.

``Are you sure you're okay, Harry?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, watching Harry anxiously.

``I Don't get it... What happened?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, wiping more sweat off his (Harry) face.

``Well -- that thing -- the dementor -- stood there and looked around -LRB-I mean, I think it did, I couldn't see its face-RRB- -- and you -- you

``I thought you were having a fit or something,'' (Ron)
said Ron, who still looked scared. ``You went sort of rigid and fell out of your seat and started twitching -- 11

``And Professor Lupin stepped over you, and walked toward the dementor, and pulled out his (Professor) wand,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, ``and he (Professor) said, ``None of us is hiding Sirius Black under our cloaks. Go.
'' But the dementor didn't move, so Lupin muttered something, and a silvery thing shot out of his (Ron) wand at it, and it turned around and sort of glided away... '' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

``It was horrible,'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville, in a higher voice than usual.
``Did YOU feel how cold it got when it came in?'' (I)

I felt weird,'' said Ron, shifting his (Ron) shoulders uncomfortably.

``Like I'd never be cheerful again...'' (Ginny)

Ginny, who was huddled in her (Ginny) corner looking nearly as bad as Harry felt, gave a small sob; Hermione went over and put a comforting arm around her (Hermione).

``But didn't any of you -- fall off your seats?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry awkwardly.

``No,'' (Ron)
said Ron, looking anxiously at Harry again.
``Ginny was shaking like mad, though...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry didn't understand. He (Harry) felt weak and shivery, as though he (Harry) were recovering from a bad bout of flu; he (Harry) also felt the beginnings of shame. Why had he (Harry) gone to pieces like that, when no one else had?

Professor Lupin had come back. He (Professor) paused as he (Professor) entered, looked around, and said, with a small smile,

``I haven't poisoned that chocolate, you know...'' (he)

Harry took a bite and to his (Harry) great surprise felt warmth spread suddenly to the tips of his (Harry) fingers and toes.

``We'll be at Hogwarts in ten minutes,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.
``Are you all right, Harry?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry didn't ask how Professor Lupin knew his (Harry) name.

``Fine,'' (he)
he (Harry) muttered, embarrassed.

They didn't talk much during the remainder of the journey. At long last, the train stopped at Hogsmeade station, and there was a great scramble to get outside; owls hooted, cats meowed, and Neville's pet toad croaked loudly from under his (Neville) hat. It was freezing on the tiny platform; rain was driving down in icy sheets.

``Firs' years this way!'' (unknown)
called a familiar voice. Harry, Ron, and Hermione turned and saw the gigantic outline of Hagrid at the other end of the platform, beckoning the terrified-looking new students forward for their traditional journey across the lake.

``All right, you three?'' (Hagrid)
Hagrid yelled over the heads of the crowd. They waved at him (Harry), but had no chance to speak to him (Harry) because the mass of people around them was shunting them away along the platform. Harry, Ron, and Hermione followed the rest of the school along the platform and out onto a rough mud track, where at least a hundred stagecoaches awaited the remaining students, each pulled, Harry could only assume, by an invisible horse, because when they climbed inside and shut the door, the coach set off all by itself, bumping and swaying in procession.

The coach smelled faintly of mold and straw. Harry felt better since the chocolate, but still weak. Ron and Hermione kept looking at him (Ron) sideways, as though frightened he (Ron) might collapse again.

As the carriage trundled toward a pair of magnificent wrought iron gates, flanked with stone columns topped with winged boars,

Harry saw two more towering, hooded dementors, standing guard on either side. A wave of cold sickness threatened to engulf him (Harry) again; he (Harry) leaned back into the lumpy seat and closed his (Harry) eyes until they had passed the gates. The carriage picked up speed on the long, sloping drive up to the castle; Hermione was leaning out of the tiny window, watching the many turrets and towers draw nearer. At last, the carriage swayed to a halt, and Hermione and Ron got out.

As Harry stepped down, a drawling, delighted voice sounded in his (Harry) ear.

``You fainted, Potter? Is Longbottorn telling the truth? You actualy fainted?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

Malfoy elbowed past Hermione to block Harry's way up the stone steps to the castle, his (Harry) face gleeful and his (Harry) pale eyes glinting maliciously.

``Shove off, Malfoy,'' (Ron)
said Ron, whose jaw was clenched.

``Did you faint as well, Weasley?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy loudly.
``Did the scary old dementor frighten you too, Weasley?'' (unknown)

``Is there a problem?'' (unknown)
said a mild voice. Professor Lupin had just gotten out of the next carriage.
