Malfoy gave Professor Lupin an insolent stare, which took in the patches on his (Malfoy) robes and the delapidated suitcase. With a tiny hint of sarcasm in his (Malfoy) voice, he (Malfoy) said,

``Oh, no -- er -- Professor,'' (he)
then he (Malfoy) smirked at Crabbe and Goyle and led them up the steps into the castle.

Hermione prodded Ron in the back to make him (Ron) hurry, and the three of them joined the crowd swarming up the steps, through the giant oak front doors, into the cavernous entrance hall, which was lit with flaming torches, and housed a magnificent marble staircase that led to the upper floors.

The door into the Great Hall stood open at the right; Harry followed the crowd toward it, but had barely glimpsed the enchanted ceiling, which was black and cloudy tonight, when a voice called,

``Potter! Granger! I want to see you both!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry and Hermione turned around, surprised. Professor McGonagall, Transfiguration teacher and head of Gryffindor House, was calling over the heads of the crowd. She (Hermione) was a sternlooking witch who wore her (Hermione) hair in a tight bun; her (Hermione) sharp eyes were framed with square spectacles. Harry fought his (Harry) way over to her (Hermione) with a feeling of foreboding: Professor McGonagall had a way of making him (Professor) feel he (Professor) must have done something wrong.

``There's no need to look so worried -- I just want a word in MY office,'' (she)
she (Hermione) told them.
``Move along there, Weasley.'' (Ron)

Ron stared as Professor McGonagall ushered Harry and Hermione away from the chattering crowd; they accompanied her (Hermione) across the entrance hall, up the marble staircase, and along a corridor.

Once they were in her (Hermione) office, a small room with a large, welcoming fire, Professor McGonagall motioned Harry and Hermione to sit down. She (Hermione) settled herself behind her (Hermione) desk and said abruptly,

``Professor Lupin sent an owl ahead to say that you were taken ill on the train, Potter.'' (She)

Before Harry could reply, there was a soft knock on the door and Madam Pomfrey, the nurse, came bustling in.

Harry felt himself going red in the face. It was bad enough that he (Harry)'d passed out, or whatever he (Harry) had done, without everyone making all this fuss.

``I'm fine,'' (he)
he (Harry) said, ``I don't need anything

``Oh, it's you, is it?'' (he)
said Madam Pomfrey, ignoring this and bending down to stare closely at him (Harry).
``I suppose you've been doing something dangerous again?'' (unknown)

``It was a dementor, Poppy,'' (Professor)
said Professor McGonagall.

They exchanged a dark look, and Madam Pomfrey clucked disapprovingly.

``Setting dementors around a school, she (MY) muttered, pushing back Harry's hair and feeling his (Harry) forehead. ``He (Harry) won't be the last one who collapses. Yes, he (Harry)'s all clammy. Terrible things, they are, and the effect they have on people who are already delicate

``I'm not delicate!'' (people)
said Harry crossly.

``Of course you're not,'' (Madam Pomfrey)
said Madam Pomfrey absentmindedly, now taking his (Harry) pulse.

``What does he (Harry) need?'' (Professor)
said Professor McGonagall crisply.
``Bed rest? Should he (Harry) perhaps spend tonight in the hospital wing?'' (unknown)

``I'm fine!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, jumping up. The thought of what Draco Malfoy would say if he (Harry) had to go to the hospital wing was torture.

``Well, he (Harry) should have some chocolate, at the very least,'' (Madam Pomfrey)
said Madam Pomfrey, who was now trying to peer into Harry's eyes.

``I've already had some,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
``Professor Lupin gave me some. He (Professor) gave it to all of us.'' (unknown)

``Did he (Professor), now?'' (Madam Pomfrey)
said Madam Pomfrey approvingly.
``So we've finally got a Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher who knows his (Professor) remedies?'' (unknown)

``Are you sure you feel all right, Potter?'' (Professor)
Professor McGonagall said sharply.

``Yes, ``said Harry.

``Very well. Kindly wait outside while I have a quick word with Miss Granger about her (Granger) course schedule, then we can go down to the feast together.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry went back into the corridor with Madam Pomfrey, who left for the hospital wing, muttering to herself He (Harry) had to wait only a few minutes; then Hermione emerged looking very happy about something, followed by Professor McGonagall, and the three of them made their way back down the marble staircase to the Great Hall.

It was a sea of pointed black hats; each of the long House tables was lined with students, their faces glimmering by the light of thousands of candles, which were floating over the tables in midair. Professor Flitwick, who was a tiny little wizard with a shock of white hair, was carrying an ancient hat and a three-legged stool out of the hall.

``Oh,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione softly,
``we've missed the Sorting!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

New students at Hogwarts were sorted into Houses by trying on the sorting Hat, which shouted out the House they were best suited to -LRB-Gryffindor, Ravenclaw, Hufflepuff, or Slytherin-RRB-. Professor McGonagall strode off toward her (Hermione) empty seat at the staff table, and Harry and Hermione set off in the other direction, as quietly as possible, toward the Gryffindor table. People looked around at them as they passed along the back of the hall, and a few of them pointed at Harry. Had the story of his (Harry) collapsing in front of the dementor traveled that fast?

He (Harry) and Hermione sat down on either side of Ron, who had saved them seats.

``What was all that about?'' (he)
he (Ron) muttered to Harry.

Harry started to explain in a whisper, but at that moment the headmaster stood up to speak, and he (Harry) broke off.

Professor Dumbledore, though very old, always gave an impression of great energy. He (Dumbledore) had several feet of long silver hair and beard, half-moon spectacles, and an extremely crooked nose. He (Dumbledore) was often described as the greatest wizard of the age, but that wasn't why Harry respected him (Harry). You couldn't help trusting Albus Dumbledore, and as Harry watched him (Harry) beaming around at the students, he (Harry) felt really calm for the first time since the dementor had entered the train compartment.

``Welcome!'' (Dumbledore/Albus Dumbledore)
said Dumbledore, the candlelight shimmering on his (Dumbledore) beard.
``Welcome to another year at Hogwarts! I have a few things to say to you all, and as one of them is very serious, I think it best to get it out of the way before you become befuddled by our excellent feast...'' (Dumbledore/Albus Dumbledore)

Dumbledore cleared his (Dumbledore) throat and continued,

``As you will all be aware after their search of the Hogwarts Express, our school is presently playing host to some of the dementors of Azkaban, who are here on Ministry of Magic business.'' (Dumbledore/Albus Dumbledore)

He (Dumbledore) paused, and Harry remembered what Mr. Weasley had said about Dumbledore not being happy with the dementors guarding the school.

``They are stationed at every entrance to the grounds,'' (Dumbledore/Albus Dumbledore)
Dumbledore continued,
``and while they are with us, I must make it plain that nobody is to leave school without permission. Dementors are not to be fooled by tricks or disguises -- or even Invisibility Cloaks,'' (Dumbledore/Albus Dumbledore)
he (Dumbledore) added blandly, and Harry and Ron glanced at each other.
``It is not in the nature of a dementor to understand pleading or excuses. I therefore warn each and every one of you to give them no reason to harm you. I look to the prefects, and our new Head Boy and Girl, to make sure that no student runs afoul of the dementors,'' (he)
he (Harry) said.

Percy, who was sitting a few seats down from Harry, puffed out his (Harry) chest again and stared around impressively. Dumbledore paused again; he (Dumbledore) looked very seriously around the hall, and nobody moved or made a sound.

``On a happier note,'' (he)
he (Dumbledore) continued, I am pleased to welcome two new teachers to our ranks this year.

``First, Professor Lupin, who has kindly consented to fill the post of Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher.'' (unknown)

There was some scattered, rather unenthusiastic applause. Only those who had been in the compartment on the train with Professor Lupin clapped hard, Harry among them. Professor Lupin looked particularly shabby next to all the other teachers in their best robes.

``Look at Snape!'' (Ron)
Ron hissed in Harry's ear.

Professor Snape, the Potions master, was staring along the staff table at Professor Lupin. It was common knowledge that Snape ,anted the Defense Against the Dark Arts job, but even Harry, who hated Snape, was startled at the expression twisting his (Harry) thin, sallow face. it was beyond anger: it was loathing. Harry knew that expression only too well; it was the look Snape wore every time he (Snape) set eyes on Harry.

``As to our second new appointment,'' (Dumbledore/Albus Dumbledore)
Dumbledore continued as the lukewarm applause for Professor Lupin died away.
``Well, I am sorry to tell you that Professor Kettleburn, our Care of Magical Creatures teacher, retired at the end of last year in order to enjoy more time with his (Professor) remaining limbs. However, I am delighted to say that his (Professor) place will be filled by none other than Rubeus Hagrid, who has agreed to take on this teaching job in addition to his (Professor) gamekeeping duties.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry, Ron, and Hermione stared at one another, stunned. Then they joined in with the applause, which was tumultuous at the Gryffindor table in particular. Harry leaned forward to see Hagrid, who was ruby-red in the face and staring down at his (Harry) enormous hands, his (Harry) wide grin hidden in the tangle of his (Harry) black beard.

``We should've known!'' (Ron)
Ron roared, pounding the table.
``Who else would have assigned us a biting book?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry, Ron, and Hermione were the last to stop clapping, and as Professor Dumbledore started speaking again, they saw that Hagrid was wiping his (Dumbledore) eyes on the tablecloth.

``Well, I think that's everything of importance,'' (Dumbledore/Albus Dumbledore)
said Dumbledore.
``Let the feast begin!'' (unknown)

The golden plates and goblets before them filled suddenly with food and drink. Harry, suddenly ravenous, helped himself to everything he (Harry) could reach and began to eat.

It was a delicious feast; the hall echoed with talk, laughter, and the clatter of knives and forks. Harry, Ron, and Hermione, however, were eager for it to finish so that they could talk to Hagrid. They knew how much being made a teacher would mean to him (Harry). Hagrid wasn't a fully qualified wizard; he (wizard) had been expelled from Hogwarts in his (wizard) third year for a crime he (wizard) had not committed. It had been Harry, Ron, and Hermione who had cleared Hagrid's name last year.

At long last, when the last morsels of pumpkin tart had melted from the golden platters, Dumbledore gave the word that it was time for them all to go to bed, and they got their chance.

``Congratulations, Hagrid!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
Hermione squealed as they reached the teachers' table.

``All down ter you three,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, wiping his (Dumbledore) shining face on his (Dumbledore) napkin as he (Dumbledore) looked up at them.,
``Can' believe it... great man, Dumbledore... came straight down to me hut after Professor Kettleburn said he (Professor)'d had enough... It's what I always wanted. --'' (he)

Overcome with emotion, he (Dumbledore) buried his (Dumbledore) face in his (Dumbledore) napkin, and Professor McGonagall shooed them away.

Harry, Ron, and Hermione joined the Gryffindors streaming up the marble staircase and, very tired now, along more corridors, UP more and more stairs, to the hidden entrance to Gryffindor Tower's large portrait of a fat lady in a pink dress asked them,

``Password?'' (a lady)

``Coming through, coming through!'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
Percy called from behind the crowd. ``The new password's
``Fortuna Major'!'' (unknown)

``Oh no,'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville Longbottom sadly. He (Longbottom) always had trouble remembering the passwords.

Through the portrait hole and across the common room, the girls and boys divided toward their separate staircases. Harry climbed the spiral stair with no thought in his (Harry) head except how glad he (Harry) was to be back. They reached their familiar, circular dormitory with its five four-poster beds, and Harry, looking around, felt he (Harry) was home at last.

CHAPTER SIX

TALONS AND TEA LEAVES

When Harry, Ron, and Hermione entered the Great Hall for breakfast the next day, the first thing they saw was Draco Malfoy, who seemed to be entertaining a large group of Slytherins with a very funny story. As they passed, Malfoy did a ridiculous impression of a swooning fit and there was a roar of laughter.

``Ignore him (Major),'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, who was right behind Harry.
``Just ignore him (Major), it's not worth it...'' (unknown)

``Hey, Potter!'' (Pansy/Pansy Parkinson)
shrieked Pansy Parkinson, a Slytherin girl with a face like a pug.
``Potter! The dementors are coming, Potter! Woooooooooo!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry dropped into a seat at the Gryffindor table, next to George Weasley.

``New third-year course schedules,'' (George/George Weasley/Weasley)
said George, passing then, over.
``What's up with you, Harry?'' (unknown)

``Malfoy,'' (Ron)
said Ron, sitting down on George's other side and glaring over at the Slytherin table.

George looked up in time to see Malfoy pretending to faint with terror again.

``That little git,'' (he)
he (Malfoy) said calmly.
``He (Malfoy) wasn't so cocky last night when the dementors were down at our end of the train. Came runing into our compartment, didn't he (Malfoy), Fred?'' (unknown)

``Nearly wet himself,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred, with a contemptuous glance at Malfoy.

``I wasn't too happy myself,'' (George/George Weasley/Weasley)
said George.
``They're horrible things, those dementors...'' (unknown)

``Sort of freeze your insides, don't they?'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred.

``You didn't pass out, though, did you?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry in a low voice.

``Forget it, Harry,'' (George/George Weasley/Weasley)
said George bracingly.
``Dad had to go out to Azkaban one time, remember, Fred? And he (Fred) said it was the worst place he (Fred)'d ever been, he (Fred) came back all weak and shaking... They suck the happiness out of a place, dementors. Most of the prisoners go mad in there.'' (unknown)

``Anyway, we'll see how happy Malfoy looks after our first Quidditch match,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred.
``Gryffindor versus Slytherin, first game of the season, remember?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

The only time Harry and Malfoy had faced each other in a Quidditch match, Malfoy had definitely come off worse. Feeling slightly more cheerful, Harry helped himself to sausages and fried tomatoes.

Hermione was examining her (Hermione) new schedule.

'' Ooh, good, we're starting some new subjects today,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
she (Hermione) said happily. villains are these, that trespass upon my private lands! Come I. scorn at my fall, perchance? Draw, you knaves, you dogs!''

They watched in astonishment as the little knight tugged his (knight) sword out of its scabbard and began brandishing it violently, hopping up and down in rage. But the sword was too long for him (knight); a particularly wild swing made him (knight) overbalance, and he (knight) landed facedown in the grass.

``Are you all right?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, moving closer to the picture.

``Get back, you scurvy braggart! Back, you rogue!'' (The knight)

The knight seized his (Harry) sword again and used it to push himself back up, but the blade sank deeply into the grass and, though he (Harry) pulled with all his (Harry) might, he (Harry) couldn't get it out again. Finally, he (Harry) had to flop back down onto the grass and push up his (Harry) visor to mop his (Harry) sweating face.

``Listen,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, taking advantage of the knight's exhaustion,
``we're looking for the North Tower. You don't know the way, do you?'' (the knight)

``A quest!'' (The knight)
The knight's rage seemed to vanish instantly. He (Harry) clanked to his (Harry) feet and shouted,
``Come follow me, dear friends, and we shall find our goal, or else shall perish bravely in the charge!'' (He)

He (Harry) gave the sword another fruitless tug, tried and failed to mount the fat pony, gave up, and cried,

``On foot then, good sirs and gentle lady! On! On!'' (He)

And he (Harry) ran, clanking loudly, into the left side of the frame and out of sight.

They hurried after him (Harry) along the corridor, following the sound of his (Harry) armor. Every now and then they spotted him (Harry) running through a picture ahead.

``Be of stout heart, the worst is yet to come!'' (the knight)
yelled the knight, and they saw him (knight) reappear in front of an alarmed group of women in crinolines, whose picture hung on the wall of a narrow spiral staircase.

Puffing loudly, Harry, Ron, and Hermione climbed the tightly spiraling steps, getting dizzier and dizzier, until at last they heard the murmur of voices above them and knew they had reached the classroom.

``Farewell!'' (the knight)
cried the knight, popping his (knight) head into a painting of some sinister-looking monks.
``Farewell, my comrades-in-arms! If ever you have need of noble heart and steely sinew, call upon Sir Cadogan!'' (unknown)

``Yeah, we'll call you,'' (Ron)
muttered Ron as the knight disappeared,
``if we ever need someone mental.'' (the knight)

They climbed the last few steps and emerged onto a tiny landing, where most of the class was already assembled. There were no doors off this landing, but Ron nudged Harry and pointed at the ceiling, where there was a circular trapdoor with a brass plaque on it.

''`Sibyll Trelawney, Divination teacher,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
' Harry read.
``How're we supposed to get up there?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

As though in answer to his (Harry) question, the trapdoor suddenly opened, and a silvery ladder descended right at Harry's feet. Everyone got quiet.

``After you,'' (Ron)
said Ron, grinning, so Harry climbed the ladder first.

He (Harry) emerged into the strangest-looking classroom he (Harry) had ever seen. In fact, it didn't look like a classroom at all, more like a cross between someone's attic and an old-fashioned tea shop. At leasttwenty small, circular tables were crammed inside it, all surrounded by chintz armchairs and fat little poufs. Everything was lit with a dim, crimson light; the curtains at the windows were all closed, and the many lamps were draped with dark red scarves. it was stiflingly warm, and the fire that was burning under the crowded mantelpiece was giving off a heavy, sickly sort of perfume as it heated a large copper kettle. The shelves running around the circular walls were crammed with dusty-looking feathers, stubs of candles, many packs of tattered playing cards, countless silvery crystal balls, and a huge array of teacups.

Ron appeared at Harry's shoulder as the class assembled around them, all talking in whispers.

``Where is she (lady)?'' (Ron)
Ron said.

A voice came suddenly out of the shadows, a soft, misty sort of voice.

``Welcome,'' (unknown)
it said.
``How nice to see you in the physical world at last.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry's immediate impression was of a large, glittering insect. Professor Trelawney moved into the firelight, and they saw that she (Professor) was very thin; her (Professor) large glasses magnified her (Professor) eyes to several times their natural size, and she (Professor) was draped in a gauzy spangled shawl. Innumerable chains and beads hung around her (Professor) spindly neck, and her (Professor) arms and hands were encrusted with bangles and rings.

``Sit, my children, sit,'' (she)
she (Professor) said, and they all climbed awkwardly into armchairs or sank onto poufs. Harry, Ron, and Hermione sat themselves around the same round table.

``Welcome to Divination,'' (Professor)
said Professor Trelawney, who had seated herself in a winged armchair in front of the fire.
``My name is professor Trelawney. You may not have seen me before. I find that descending too often into the hustle and bustle of the main school clouds my Inner Eye.'' (Nobody)

Nobody said anything to this extraordinary pronouncement. Professor Trelawney delicately rearranged her (Hermione) shawl and continued,

``So you have chosen to study Divination, the most difficult of all magical arts. I must warn you at the outset that if you do not have the Sight, there is very little I will be able to teach you.. Books can take you only so far in this field...'' (Trelawney/Sibyll/Sibyll Trelawney)

At these words, both Harry and Ron glanced, grinning, at Hermione, who looked startled at the news that books wouldn't be much help in this subject.

``Many witches and wizards, talented though they are in the area of loud bangs and smells and sudden disappearings, are yet unable to penetrate the veiled mysteries of the future,'' (Professor)
Professor Trelawney went on, her (Hermione) enormous, gleaming eyes moving from face to nervous face.
``It is a Gift granted to few. You, boy,'' (she)
she (Hermione) said suddenly to Neville, who almost toppled off his (Neville) pouf.
``Is your grandmother well?'' (unknown)

``I think so,'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville tremulously.

``I wouldn't be so sure if I were you, dear,'' (Professor)
said Professor Trelawney, the firelight glinting on her (Hermione) long emerald earrings. Neville gulped. Professor Trelawney continued placidly.
``We will be covering the basic methods of Divination this year. The first term will be devoted to reading the tea leaves. Next term we shall progress to palmistry. By the way, my dear,'' (she)
she (Hermione) shot suddenly at Parvati Patil,
``beware a red-haired man.'' (Parvati/Parvati Patil)

Parvati gave a startled look at Ron, who was right behind her (Parvati) and edged her (Parvati) chair away from him (Ron).

``In the second term,'' (Professor)
Professor Trelawney went on,
``we shall progress to the crystal ball -- if we have finished with fire omens, that is. Unfortunately, classes will be disrupted in February by a nasty bout of flu. I myself will lose my voice. And around Easter, one of our number will leave us forever.'' (Trelawney/Sibyll/Sibyll Trelawney)

A very tense silence followed this pronouncement, but Professor Trelawney seemed unaware of it.

``I wonder, dear,'' (she)
she (Parvati) said to Lavender Brown, who was nearest and shrank back in her (Parvati) chair,
``if you could pass me the largest silver teapot?'' (Lavender Brown)

Lavender, looking relieved, stood up, took an enormous teapot from the shelf, and put it down on the table in front of Professor Trelawney.

``Thank you, my dear. Incidentally, that thing you are dreading -- it will happen on Friday the sixteenth of October.'' (unknown)

Lavender trembled.

``Now, I want you all to divide into pairs. Collect a teacup from the shelf, come to me, and I will fill it. Then sit down and drink, drink until only the dregs remain. Swill these around the cup three times with the left hand, then turn the cup upside down on its saucer, wait for the last of the tea to drain away, then give your cup to your partner to read. You will interpret the patterns using pages five and six of Unfogging the Future. I shall move among you, helping and instructing. Oh, and dear'' (she)
-- she (Parvati) caught Neville by the arm as he (Neville) made to stand up --
``after you've broken your first cup, would you be so kind as to select one of the blue patterned ones? I'm rather attached to the pink.'' (he)

Sure enough, Neville had no sooner reached the shelf of teacups when there was a tinkle of breaking china. Professor Trelawney swept over to him (Professor) holding a dustpan and brush and said,

``One of the blue ones, then, dear, if you wouldn't mind... thank you. ... '' (him)

When Harry and Ron had had their teacups filled, they went back to their table and tried to drink the scalding tea quickly. They swilled the dregs around as Professor Trelawney had instructed, then drained the cups and swapped over.

``Right,'' (Ron)
said Ron as they both opened their books at pages five and six.
``What can you see in mine?'' (unknown)

``A load of soggy brown stuff,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry. The heavily perfumed smoke in the room was making him (Harry) feel sleepy and stupid.

``Broaden your minds, my dears, and allow your eyes to see past the mundane!'' (Professor)
Professor Trelawney cried through the gloom.

Harry tried to pull himself together.

``Right, you've got a crooked sort of cross... '' (He)
He (Harry) consulted Unfogging the Future.
``That means you're going to have `trials and suffering' -- sorry about that -- but there's a thing that could be the sun... hang on... that means `great happiness'... so you're going to suffer but be very happy...'' (Ron)

``You need your Inner Eye tested, if you ask me,'' (Ron)
said Ron, and they both had to stifle their laughs as Professor Trelawney gazed in their direction.

``My turn...'' (Ron)
Ron peered into Harry's teacup, his (Ron) forehead wrinkled with effort.
``There's a blob a bit like a bowler hat,'' (he)
he (Ron) said. ``Maybe you're going to work for the Ministry of Magic...

He (bowler) turned the teacup the other way up.

``But this way it looks more like an acorn... What's that?'' (He)
He (Ron) scanned his (Ron) copy of Unfogging the Future.
'''A windfall, unexpected gold.'' (He)
Excellent, you can lend me some... and there's a thin, here,'' he (Ron) turned the cup again,
``that looks like an animal... yeah, if that was its head... it looks like a hippo... no, a sheep...'' (me)

Professor Trelawney whirled around as Harry let out a snort of laughter.

``Let me see that, my dear,'' (she)
she (Harry) said reprovingly to Ron, sweeping over and snatching Harry's cup from him (Harry). Everyone went quiet to watch.

Professor Trelawney was staring into the teacup, rotating it counterclockwise.

``The falcon... my dear, you have a deadly enemy.'' (unknown)

``But everyone knows that, '' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione in a loud whisper. Professor Trelawney stared at her (Hermione).

``Well, they do,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione.
``Everybody knows about Harry and You-Know-Who.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry and Ron stared at her (Hermione) with a mixture of amazement and admiration. They had never heard Hermione speak to a teacher like that before. Professor Trelawney chose not to reply. She (Hermione) lowered her (Hermione) huge eyes to Harry's cup again and continued to turn it.

``The club... an attack. Dear, dear, this is not a happy cup...

I thought that was a bowler hat,'' (unknown)

said Ron sheepishly.

``The skull... danger in your path, my dear...'' (Everyone)

Everyone was staring, transfixed, at Professor Trelawney, who gave the cup a final turn, gasped, and then screamed.

There was another tinkle of breaking china; Neville had smashed his (Neville) second cup. Professor Trelawney sank into a vacant armchair, her (Hermione) glittering hand at her (Hermione) heart and her (Hermione) eyes closed.

``My dear boy... my poor, dear boy no it is kinder not to say.. . no... don't ask me...'' (unknown)

``What is it, Professor?'' (Dean Thomas/Dean)
said Dean Thomas at once. Everyone had got to their feet, and slowly they crowded around Harry and Ron's table, pressing close to Professor Trelawney's chair to get a

good look at Harry's cup.

``My dear,'' (Professor)
Professor Trelawney's huge eyes opened dramatically,

``You have the Grim.'' (Trelawney/Sibyll/Sibyll Trelawney)

``The what?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

He (Harry) could tell that he (Harry) wasn't the only one who didn't understand; Dean Thomas shrugged at him (Thomas) and Lavender Brown looked puzzled, but nearly everybody else clapped their hands to their mouths in horror.

``The Grim, my dear, the Grim!'' (Professor)
cried Professor Trelawney, who looked shocked that Harry hadn't understood.
``The giant, spectral dog that haunts churchyards! My dear boy, it is an omen -- the worst omen -- of death!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry's stomach lurched. That dog on the cover of Death Omens in Flourish and Blotts -the dog in the shadows of Magnolia Crescent... Lavender Brown clapped her (Crescent) hands to her (Crescent) mouth too. Everyone was looking at Harry, everyone except Hermione, who had gotten up and moved around to the back of Professor Trelawney's chair.

``I don't think it looks like a Grim,'' (she)
she (Hermione) said flatly.

Professor Trelawney surveyed Hermione with mounting dislike.

``You'll forgive me for saying so, my dear, but I perceive very little aura around you. Very little receptivity to the resonances of the future.'' (Seamus Finnigan/Seamus)
Seamus Finnigan was tilting his (Finnigan) head from side to side.

``It looks like a Grim if you do this,'' (he)
he (Finnigan) said, with his (Finnigan) eyes almost shut,
``but it looks more like a donkey from here,'' (he)
he (Finnigan) said, leaning to the left.

``When you've all finished deciding whether I'm going to die Or not!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, taking even himself by surprise. Now nobody seemed to want to look at him (Harry).

``I think we will leave the lesson here for today,'' (Professor)
said Professor Trelawney in her (Hermione) mistiest voice.
``Yes... please pack away your things...'' (Professor)

Silently the class took their teacups back to Professor Trelawney, packed away their books, and closed their bags. Even Ron was avoiding Harry's eyes.

``Until we meet again,'' (Professor)
said Professor Trelawney faintly,
``fair fortune be yours. Oh, and dear'' (Trelawney/Sibyll/Sibyll Trelawney)
-- she (Hermione) pointed at Neville --
``you'll be late next time, so mind you work extra-hard to catch up.'' (Neville)

Harry, Ron, and Hermione descended Professor Trelawney's ladder and the winding stair in silence, then set off for Professor McGonagall's Transfiguration lesson. It took them so long to find her (Hermione) classroom that, early as they had left Divination, they were only just in time.

Harry chose a seat right at the back of the room, feeling as though he (Harry) were sitting in a very bright spotlight; the rest of the class kept shooting furtive glances at him (Harry), as though he (Harry) were about to drop dead at any moment. He (Harry) hardly heard what Professor McGonagall was telling them about Animagi -LRB-wizards who could transform at will into animals-RRB-, and wasn't even watching when she (Hermione) transformed herself in front of their eyes into a tabby cat with spectacle markings around her (Hermione) eyes.

``Really, what has got into you all today?'' (Professor)
said Professor McGonagall, turning back into herself with a faint pop, and staring around at them all.
``Not that it matters, but that's the first time my transformation's not got applause from a class.'' (Everybody)

Everybody's heads turned toward Harry again, but nobody spoke. Then Hermione raised her (Hermione) hand.

``Please, Professor, we've just had our first Divination class, and we were reading the tea leaves, and --'' (Professor)

``Ah, of course,'' (Professor)
said Professor McGonagall, suddenly frowning.

``There is no need to say any more, Miss Granger. Tell me, which of you will be dying this year?'' (Everyone)

Everyone stared at her (Hermione).

``Me,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, finally.

``I see,'' (Professor)
said Professor McGonagall, fixing Harry with her (Hermione) beady eyes.
``Then you should know, Potter, that Sibyll Trelawney has predicted the death of one student a year since she (Granger) arrived at this school. None of them has died yet. Seeing death omens is her (Granger) favorite way of greeting a new class. If it were not for the fact that I never speak ill of my colleagues --'' (Professor)

Professor McGonagall broke off, and they saw that her (Hermione) nostrils had gone white. She (Hermione) went on, more calmly,

``Divination is one of the most imprecise branches of magic. I shall not conceal from you that I have very little patience with it. True Seers are very rare, and Professor Trelawney --'' (She)

She (Hermione) stopped again, and then said, in a very matter-of-fact tone,

``You look in excellent health to me, Potter, so you will excuse me if I don't let you off homework today. I assure you that if you die, you need not hand it in.'' (She)

Hermione laughed. Harry felt a bit better. It was harder to feel scared of a lump of tea leaves away from the dim red light and befuddling perfume of Professor Trelawney's classroom. Not everyone was convinced, however. Ron still looked worried, and Lavender whispered,

``But what about Neville's cup?'' (Ron)

When the Transfiguration class had finished, they joined the crowd thundering toward the Great Hall for lunch.

``Ron, cheer up,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, pushing a dish of stew toward him (Great).
``You heard what Professor McGonagall said.'' (Ron)

Ron spooned stew onto his (Ron) plate and picked up his (Ron) fork but didn't start.

``Harry,'' (he)
he (Ron) said, in a low, serious voice,
``You haven't seen a great black dog anywhere, have you?'' (he)

``Yeah, I have,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
``I saw one the night I left the Dursleys'. '' (Ron)

Ron let his (Harry) fork fall with a clatter.

``Probably a stray,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione calmly.

Ron looked at Hermione as though she (Hermione) had gone mad.

``Hermione, if Harry's seen a Grim, that's -- that's bad,'' (he)
he (Ron) said.
``My -- my uncle Bilius saw one and -- and he (Harry) died twenty-four hours later!'' (unknown)

``Coincidence,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione airily, pouring herself some pumpkin juice.

``You don't know what you're talking about!'' (Ron)
said Ron, starting to get angry.
``Grims scare the living daylights out of most wizards!'' (unknown)

``There you are, then,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione in a superior tone.
``They see the Grim and die of fright. The Grim's not an omen, it's the cause of death! And Harry's still with us because he (Harry)'s not stupid enough to see one and think, right, well, I'd better kick the bucket then!'' (Ron)

Ron mouthed wordlessly at Hermione, who opened her (Hermione) bag, took out her (Hermione) new Arithmancy book, and propped it open against the juice jug.

``I think Divination seems very woolly,'' (she)
she (Hermione) said, searching for her (Hermione) page.
``A lot of guesswork, if you ask me.'' (unknown)

``There was nothing woolly about the Grim in that cup!'' (Ron)
said Ron hotly.

``You didn't seem quite so confident when you were telling Harry it was a sheep,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione coolly.

``Professor Trelawney said you didn't have the right aura! You just don't like being bad at something for a change!'' (He)

He (Ron) had touched a nerve. Hermione slammed her (Hermione) Arithmancy book down on the table so hard that bits of meat and carrot flew everywhere.

``If being good at Divination means I have to pretend to see death omens in a lump of tea leaves, I'm not sure I'll be studying it much longer! That lesson was absolute rubbish compared with my Arithmancy class!'' (She)

She (Hermione) snatched up her (Hermione) bag and stalked away.

Ron frowned after her (Hermione).

``What's she (You) talking about?'' (he)
he (Ron) said to Harry.
``She (You) hasn't been to an Arithmancy class yet.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry was pleased to get out of the castle after lunch. Yesterday's rain had cleared; the sky was a clear, pale gray, and the grass was springy and damp underfoot as they set off for their first ever Care of Magical Creatures class.

Ron and Hermione weren't speaking to each other. Harry walked beside them in silence as they went down the sloping lawns to Hagrid's hut on the edge of the Forbidden Forest. It was only when he (Harry) spotted three only-too- familiar backs ahead of them that he (Harry) realized they must be having these lessons with the Slytherins. Malfoy was talking animatedly to Crabbe and Goyle, who were chortling. Harry was quite sure he (Harry) knew what they were talking about.

Hagrid was waiting for his (Harry) class at the door of his (Harry) hut. He (Harry) stood in his (Harry) moleskin overcoat, with Fang the boarhound at his (Harry) heels, looking impatient to start.

``C'mon, now, get a move on!'' (he)
he (Harry) called as the class approached.
``Got a real treat for yeh today! Great lesson comin' up! Everyone here? Right, follow me!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

For one nasty moment, Harry thought that Hagrid was going to lead them into the forest; Harry had had enough unpleasant experiences in there to last him (Harry) a lifetime. However, Hagrid strolled off around the edge of the trees, and five minutes later, they found themselves outside a kind of paddock. There was nothing in there.

``Everyone gather `round the fence here!'' (he)
he (Harry) called.
``That's it -- make sure yeh can see -- now, firs' thing yeh'll want ter do is open yer books --'' (unknown)

``How?'' (Draco)
said the cold, drawling voice of Draco Malfoy.

``Eh?'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid.

``How do we open our books?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
Malfoy repeated. He (Malfoy) took out his (Malfoy) copy of The Monster Book of Monsters, which he (Malfoy) had bound shut with a length of rope. Other people took theirs out too; some, like Harry, had belted their book shut; others had crammed them inside tight bags or clamped them together with binder clips.

``Hasn' -- hasn' anyone bin able ter open their books?'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, looking crestfallen.

The class all shook their heads.

``Yeh've got ter stroke 'em,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, as though this was the most obvious thing in the world.
``Look --'' (He)

He (Harry) took Hermione's copy and ripped off the Spellotape that bound it. The book tried to bite, but Hagrid ran a giant forefinger down its spine, and the book shivered, and then fell open and lay quiet in his (Harry) hand.

``Oh, how silly we've all been!'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
Malfoy sneered.
``We should have stroked them! why didn't we guess!'' (unknown)

``I -- I thought they were funny,'' (Hagrid)
Hagrid said uncertainly to Hermione.

``Oh, tremendously funny!'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy.
``Really witty, giving us books that try and rip our hands off!'' (unknown)

``Shut up, Malfoy,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry quietly. Hagrid was looking downcast and Harry wanted Hagrid's first lesson to be a success.

``Righ' then,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, who seemed to have lost his (Harry) thread,
``so -- so yeh've got yer books an' -- an' - - now yeh need the Magical Creatures. Yeah. So I'll go an' get 'em. Hang on... '' (Hagrid)

He (Harry) strode away from them into the forest and out of sight.

``God, this place is going to the dogs,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy loudly. ``That oaf teaching classes, my father'll have a fit when I tell him (father)

``Shut up, Malfoy,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry repeated.

``Careful, Potter, there's a dementor behind you

``Oooooooh!'' (Lavender Brown)
squealed Lavender Brown, pointing toward the opposite side of the paddock.

Trotting toward them were a dozen of the most bizarre creatures Harry had ever seen. They had the bodies, hind legs, and tails of horses, but the front legs, wings, and heads of what seemed to be giant eagles, with cruel, steel-colored beaks and large, brilliantly, orange eyes. The talons on their front legs were half a foot long and deadly looking. Each of the beasts had a thick leather collar around its neck, which was attached to a long chain, and the ends of all of these were held in the vast hands of Hagrid, who came jogging into the paddock behind the creatures.

``Gee up, there!'' (he)
he (their) roared, shaking the chains and urging the creatures toward the fence where the class stood. Everyone drew back slightly as Hagrid reached them and tethered the creatures to the fence.

``Hippogriffs!'' (Hagrid)
Hagrid roared happily, waving a hand at them.
``Beau'iful, aren' they?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry could sort of see what Hagrid meant. Once you got over the first shock of seeing something that was, half horse, half bird, you started to appreciate the hippogriffs' gleaming coats, changing smoothly from feather to hair, each of them a different color: stormy gray, bronze, pinkish roan, gleaming chestnut, and inky black.

``So,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, rubbing his (Harry) hands together and beaming around,
``if yeh wan' ter come a bit nearer --'' (Hagrid)

No one seemed to want to. Harry, Ron, and Hermione, however, approached the fence cautiously.

``Now, firs' thing yeh gotta know abou' hippogriffs is, they're proud,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid.
``Easily offended, hippogriffs are. Don't never insult one, 'cause it might be the last thing yeh do.'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle weren't listening; they were talking in an undertone and Harry had a nasty feeling they were plotting how best to disrupt the lesson.

``Yeh always wait fer the hippogriff ter make the firs' move,'' (Hagrid)
Hagrid continued. ``It's polite, see? Yeh walk toward him (they), and yeh bow, an' yeh wait. If he (they) bows back, yeh're allowed ter touch him (they). If he (they) doesn' bow, then get away from him (they) sharpish, 'cause those talons hurt.

``Right -- who wants ter go first?'' (unknown)

Most of the class backed farther away in answer. Even Harry, Ron, and Hermione had misgivings. The hippogriffs were tossing their fierce heads and flexing their powerful wings; they didn't seem to like being tethered like this.

``No one?'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, with a pleading look.

``I'll do it,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

There was an intake of breath from behind him (Harry), and both Lavender and Parvati whispered,

``Oooh, no, Harry, remember your tea leaves!'' (Parvati/Parvati Patil)

Harry ignored them. He (Harry) climbed over the paddock fence.

``Good man, Harry!'' (Hagrid)
roared Hagrid.
``Right then -- let's see how yeh get on with Buckbeak.'' (He)

He (Harry) untied one of the chains, pulled the gray hippogriff away from its fellows, and slipped off its leather collar. The class on the other side of the paddock seemed to be holding its breath. Malfoy's eyes were narrowed maliciously.

``Easy-RRB- now, Harry,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid quietly.
``Yeh've got eye contact, now try not ter blink... Hippogriffs don' trust yeh if yeh blink too much...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry's eyes immediately began to water, but he (Harry) didn't shut thern. Buckbeak had turned his (Harry) great, sharp head and was staring at Harry with one fierce orange eye.

``Tha's it,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid.
``Tha's it, Harry... now, bow.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry didn't feel much like exposing the back of his (Harry) neck to Buckbeak, but he (Harry) did as he (Harry) was told. He (Harry) gave a short bow and then looked up.

The hippogriff was still staring haughtily at him (Harry). It didn't move.

``Ah,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, sounding worried. ``Right -- back away, now, Harry, easy does it

But then, to Harry's enormous surprise, the hippogriff suddenly bent its scaly front knees and sank into what was an unmistakable bow.

``Well done, Harry!'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, ecstatic.
``Right -- yeh can touch him (Harry)! Pat his (Harry) beak, go on!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Feeling that a better reward would have been to back away, Harry moved slowly toward the hippogriff and reached out toward it. He (Harry) patted the beak several times and the hippogriff closed its eyes lazily, as though enjoying it.

The class broke into applause, all except for Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle, who were looking deeply disappointed.

``Righ' then, Harry,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid.
``I reckon he (Harry) might' let yeh ride him (Harry)!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

This was more than Harry had bargained for. He (Harry) was used to a broomstick; but he (Harry) wasn't sure a hippogriff would be quite the same.

``Yeh climb up there, jus' behind the wing joint,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid,
``an' mind yeh don' pull any of his (Harry) feathers out, he (Harry) won' like that...'' (Hagrid)

Harry put his (Harry) foot on the top of Buckbeaks wing and hoisted himself onto its back. Buckbeak stood up. Harry wasn't sure where to hold on; everything in front of him (Harry) was covered with feathers.

``Go on, then''' (Hagrid)
roared Hagrid, slapping the hippogriffs hindquarters.

Without warning, twelve-foot wings flapped open on either side of Harry, he (Harry) just had time to seize the hippogriff around the neck before he (Harry) was soaring upward. It was nothing like a broomstick, and Harry knew which one he (Harry) preferred; the hippogriff's wings beat uncomfortably on either side of him (Harry), catching him (Harry) under his (Harry) legs and making him (Harry) feel he (Harry) was about to be thrown off; the glossy feathers slipped under his (Harry) fingers and he (Harry) didn't dare get a stronger grip; instead of the smooth action of his (Harry) Nimbus Two Thousand, he (Harry) now felt himself rocking backward and forward as the hindquarters of the hippogriff rose and fell with its wings.

Buckbeak flew him (Harry) once around the paddock and then headed back to the ground; this was the bit Harry had been dreading; he (Harry) leaned back as the smooth neck lowered, feeling he (Harry) was going to slip off over the beak, then felt a heavy thud as the four ill-assorted feet hit the ground. He (Harry) just managed to hold on and push himself straight again.

``Good work, Harry!'' (Hagrid)
roared Hagrid as everyone except Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle cheered.
``Okay, who else wants a go?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Emboldened by Harry's success, the rest of the class climbed cautiously into the paddock. Hagrid untied the hippogriffs one by one, and soon people were bowing nervously, all over the paddock. Neville ran repeatedly backward from his (Neville), which didn't seem to want to bend its knees. Ron and Hermione practiced on the chestnut, while Harry watched.

Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle had taken over Buckbeak. He (Harry) had bowed to Malfoy, who was now patting his (Malfoy) beak, looking disdainful.

``This is very easy,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
Malfoy drawled, loud enough for Harry to, hear him (Harry).
``I knew it must have been, if Potter could do it... I bet you're not dangerous at all, are you?'' (he)
he (Harry) said to the hippogriff.
``Are you, you great ugly brute?'' (unknown)

It happened in a flash of steely talons; Malfoy let out a highpitched scream and next moment, Hagrid was wrestling Buckbeak back into his (Malfoy) collar as he (Malfoy) strained to get at Malfoy, who lay curled in the grass, blood blossoming over his (Malfoy) robes.

``I'm dying!'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
Malfoy yelled as the class panicked.
``I'm dying, look at me! It's killed me!'' (unknown)

``Yer not dyin'!'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, who had gone very white.
``Someone help me -- gotta get him (Potter) outta here --'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

Hermione ran to hold open the gate as Hagrid lifted Malfoy easily. As they passed, Harry saw that there was a long, deep gash on Malfoy's arm; blood splattered the grass and Hagrid ran with him (Malfoy), up the slope toward the castle.

Very shaken, the Care of Magical Creatures class followed at a walk. The Slytherins were all shouting about Hagrid.

``They should fire him (Potter) straight away!'' (Pansy/Pansy Parkinson)
said Pansy Parkinson, who was in tears.

``It was Malfoy's fault!'' (Dean Thomas/Dean)
snapped Dean Thomas. Crabbe and Goyle flexed their muscles threateningly.

They all climbed the stone steps into the deserted entrance hall.

``I'm going to see if he (Malfoy)'s okay!'' (Pansy/Pansy Parkinson)
said Pansy, and they all watched her (Pansy) run up the marble staircase. The Slytherins, still muttering about Hagrid, headed away in the direction of their dungeon common room; Harry, Ron, and Hermione proceeded upstairs to Gryffindor Tower.

``You think he (Malfoy)'ll be all right?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione nervously.

``Course he (Malfoy) will. Madam Pomfrey can mend cuts in about a second,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, who had had far worse injuries mended magically by the nurse.

``That was a really bad thing to happen in Hagrid's first class, though, wasn't it?'' (Ron)
said Ron, looking worried.
``Trust Malfoy to mess things up for him (Malfoy)...'' (Great)

They were among the first to reach the Great Hall at dinnertime, hoping to see Hagrid, but he (Great) wasn't there.

``They wouldn't fire him (Malfoy), would they?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione anxiously, not touching her (Hermione) steak-and- kidney pudding.

``They'd better not,'' (Ron)
said Ron, who wasn't eating either.

Harry was watching the Slytherin table. A large group including Crabbe and Goyle was huddled together, deep in conversation. Harry was sure they were cooking up their own version of how Malfoy had been injured.

``Well, you can't say it wasn't an interesting first day back,'' (Ron)
said Ron gloomily.

They went up to the crowded Gryffindor common room after dinner and tried to do the homework Professor McGonagall had given them, but all three of them kept breaking off and glancing Out of the tower window.

``There's a light on in Hagrid's window,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said suddenly.

Ron looked at his (Ron) watch.

``If we hurried, we could go down and see him (Malfoy). It's still quite early...'' (I)

I don't know,'' Hermione said slowly, and Harry saw her (Hermione) glance at him (Harry).

``I'm allowed to walk across the grounds, '' (he)
he (Harry) said Pointedly.
``Sirius Black hasn't got past the dementors yet, has he (Black)?'' (nobody)

So they put their things away and headed out of the portrait hole, glad to meet nobody on their way to the front doors, as they weren't entirely sure they were supposed to be out.

The grass was still wet and looked almost black in the twilight. When they reached Hagrid's hut, they knocked, and a voice growled,

``C'min.'' (Hagrid)

Hagrid was sitting in his (Harry) shirtsleeves at his (Harry) scrubbed wooden table; his (Harry) boarhound, Fang, had his (Harry) head in Hagrid's lap. One look told them that Hagrid had been drinking a lot; there was a pewter tankard almost as big as a bucket in front of him (Harry), and he (Harry) seemed to be having difficulty getting them into focus.

''`Spect it's a record,'' (he)
he (Harry) said thickly, when he (Harry) recognized them.
``Don' reckon they've ever had a teacher who lasted on'y a day before.'' (unknown)

``You haven't been fired, Hagrid!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
gasped Hermione.

``Not yet,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid miserably, taking a huge gulp of whatever was in the tankard.
``But's only a matter o' time, i' n't it, after Malfoy...'' (unknown)

``How is he (Malfoy)?'' (Ron)
said Ron as they all sat down.
``It wasn't serious, was it?'' (unknown)

``Madam Pomfrey fixed him (Malfoy) best she (Hagrid) could,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid dully, ``but he (Malfoy)'s sayin' it's still agony... covered in bandages... moanin'..

``He (Malfoy)'s faking it, '' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry at once.
``Madam Pomfrey can mend anything. She (Hagrid) regrew half my bones last year. Trust Malfoy to milk it for all it's worth.'' (unknown)

``School gov`nors have bin told, o' course,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid miseribly.
``They reckon I started too big. Shoulda left hippogriffs fer later... done flobberworms or summat... Jus' thought itdmake a good firs' lessons all my fault...'' (unknown)

``It's all Malfoy's fault, Hagrid!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione earnestly.

``We're witnesses,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
``You said hippogriffs attack if you insult them. It's Malfoy's problem that he (Malfoy) wasn't listening. We'll tell Dumbledore what really happened.'' (unknown)

``Yeah, don't worry, Hagrid, we'll back you up,'' (Ron)
said Ron.

Tears leaked out of the crinkled corners of Hagrid's beetle-black eyes. He (Ron) grabbed both Harry and Ron and pulled them into a bone-breaking hug.

``I think you've had enough to drink, Hagrid,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione firmly. She (Hermione) took the tankard from the table and went outside to empty it.

``At, maybe she (them)'s right,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, letting go of Harry and Ron, who both staggered away, rubbing their ribs. Hagrid heaved himself out of his (Ron) chair and followed Hermione unsteadily outside. They heard a loud splash.

``What's he (Dumbledore) done?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry nervously as Hermione came back in with the empty tankard.

``Stuck his (Dumbledore) head in the water barrel,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, putting the tankard away.

Hagrid came back, his (Harry) long hair and beard sopping wet, wiping the water out of his (Harry) eyes.

``That's better,'' (he)
he (Harry) said, shaking his (Harry) head like a dog and drenching them all. ``Listen, it was good of yeh ter come an' see me, I really --

Hagrid stopped dead, staring at Harry as though he (Harry)'d only just realized he (Harry) was there.

``WHAT D``YEH THINK YOU

``RE DOIN', EH?'' (he)
he (Harry) roared, so suddenly that they jumped a foot in the air.
``YEH'RE NOT TO GO WANDERIN' AROUND AFTER DARK, HARRY! AN, YOU TWO! LETTIN' HIM!'' (Hagrid)

Hagrid strode over to Harry, grabbed his (Harry) arm, and pulled him (Harry) to the door.

``C'mon!'' (Hagrid)
Hagrid said angrily.
``I'm takin' yer all back up ter school, an' don' let me catch yeh walkin' down ter see me after dark again. I'm not worth that!'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

CHAPTER SEVEN

THE BOGGART IN THE WARDROBE

Malfoy didn't reappear in classes until late on Thursday morning, when the Slytherins and Gryffindors were halfway through double Potions. He (Malfoy) swaggered into the dungeon, his (Malfoy) right arm covered in bandages and bound up in a sling, acting, in Harry's opinion, as though he (Harry) were the heroic survivor of some dreadful battle.

``How is it, Draco?'' (Pansy)
simpered Pansy Parkinson.
``Does it hurt much?'' (unknown)

``Yeah,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy, putting on a brave sort of grimace. But Harry saw him (Harry) wink at Crabbe and Goyle when Pansy had looked away.

``Settle down, settle down,'' (Professor)
said Professor Snape idly.

Harry and Ron scowled at each other; Snape wouldn't have said

``settle down'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
if they'd walked in late, he (Harry)'d have given them detention. But Malfoy had always been able to get away with anything in Snape's classes; Snape was head of Slytherin House, and generality favored his (Snape) own students above all others.

They were making a new potion today, a Shrinking Solution. Malfoy set up his (Malfoy) cauldron right next to Harry and Ron, so that they were preparing their ingredients on the same table.

``Sir,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
Malfoy called,
``sir, I'll need help cutting up these daisy roots, because of my arm --'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

``Weasley, cut up Malfoy's roots for him (Malfoy),'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Snape without looking up.

Ron went brick red.

``There's nothing wrong with your arm,'' (he)
he (Ron) hissed at Malfoy.

Malfoy smirked across the table.

``Weasley, you heard Professor Snape; cut up these roots.'' (Ron)

Ron seized his (Ron) knife, pulled Malfoy's roots toward him (Malfoy), and began to chop them roughly, so that they were all different sizes.

``Professor,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
drawled Malfoy,
``Weasley's mutilating my roots, sit.'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

Snape approached their table, stared down his (Snape) hooked nose at the roots, then gave Ron an unpleasant smile from beneath his (Ron) long, greasy black hair.

``Change roots with Malfoy, Weasley.'' (unknown)

``But, sit --!'' (Ron)

Ron had spent the last quarter of an hour carefully shredding his (Ron) own roots into exactly equal pieces.

``Now,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape in his (Snape) most dangerous voice.

Ron shoved his (Ron) own beautifully cut roots across the table a, Malfoy, then took up the knife again.

``And, sir, I'll need this shrivelfig skinned,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy, his (Malfoy) voice full of malicious laughter.

``Potter, you can skin Malfoy's shrivelfig,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape, giving Harry the look of loathing he (Snape) always reserved just for him (Snape).

Harry took Malfoy's shrivelfig as Ron began trying to repair the damage to the roots he (Ron) now had to use. Harry skinned the shrivelfig as fast as he (Harry) could and flung it back across the table at Malfoy without speaking. Malfoy was smirking more broadly than ever.

``Seen your pal Hagrid lately?'' (he)
he (Malfoy) asked them quietly.

``None of your business,'' (Ron)
said Ron jerkily, without looking up.

``I'm afraid he (Malfoy) won't be a teacher much longer,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy in a tone of mock sorrow.
``Father's not very happy about my injury --'' (Ron)

``Keep talking, Malfoy, and I'll give you a real injury,'' (Ron)
snarled Ron.

''- he (Malfoy)'s complained to the school governors. And to the Ministry of Magic. Father's got a lot of influence, you know. And a lasting injury like this'' (Ron)
-- he (Father) gave a huge, fake sigh --
``who knows if my arm'll ever be the same again?'' (he)

``So that's why you're putting it on,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, accidentally beheading a dead caterpillar because his (Harry) hand was shaking in anger.
``To try to get Hagrid fired.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy, lowering his (Malfoy) voice to a whisper,
``partly, Potter. But there are other benefits too. Weasley, slice my caterpillars for me.'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

A few cauldrons away, Neville was in trouble. Neville regularly went to pieces in Potions lessons; it was his (Neville) worst subject, and his (Neville) great fear of Professor Snape made things ten times worse. His (Snape) potion, which was supposed to be a bright, acid green, had turned --

``Orange, Longbottom,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape, ladling some up and allowing to splash back into the cauldron, so that everyone could see.

``Orange. Tell me, boy, does anything penetrate that thick skull of yours? Didn't you hear me say, quite clearly, that only one -tat spleen was needed? Didn't I state plainly that a dash of leech juice would suffice? What do I have to do to make you understand, Longbottom?'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

Neville was pink and trembling. He (Neville) looked as though he (Neville) was on the verge of tears.

``Please, sir,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione,
``please, I could help Neville put it right --'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

``I don't remember asking you to show off, Miss Granger,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Snape coldly, and Hermione went as pink as Neville.
``Longbottom, at the end of this lesson we will feed a few drops of this potion to your toad and see what happens. Perhaps that will encourage you to do it properly.'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

Snape moved away, leaving Neville breathless with fear.

``Help me!'' (he)
he (Neville) moaned to Hermione.

``Hey, Harry,'' (Seamus Finnigan/Seamus)
said Seamus Finnigan, leaning over to borrow Harry's brass scales,
``have you heard? Daily Prophet this morning -- they reckon Sirius Black's been sighted.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``Where?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry and Ron quickly. On the other side of the table, Malfoy looked up, listening closely.

``Not too far from here,'' (Seamus Finnigan/Seamus)
said Seamus, who looked excited. ``It was a Muggle who saw him (Black).
``Course, she (Granger) didn't really understand. The Muggles think he (Black)'s just an ordinary criminal, don't they? So she (Granger) phoned the telephone hot line. By the time the Ministry of Magic got there, he (Black) was gone.'' (unknown)

``Not too far from here... '' (Ron)
Ron repeated, looking significantly at Harry. He (Harry) turned around and saw Malfoy watching closely.
``What, Malfoy? Need something else skinned?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

But Malfoy's eyes were shining malevolently, and they were fixed Harry. He (Harry) leaned across the table.

Black single-handed, Potter?''

``Thinking Of trying to catch

``Yeah, that's right,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry offhandedly.

Malfoys thin mouth was curving in a mean smile.

``Of course, if it was me,'' (he)
he (Harry) said quietly,
``I'd have done something before now. I wouldn't be staying in school like a good boy, I'd be out there looking for him (boy).'' (he)

``What are you talking about, Malfoy?'' (Ron)
said Ron roughly.

``Don't you know, Potter?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
breathed Malfoy, his (Malfoy) pate eyes narrowed.

``Know what?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

Malfoy let out a low, sneering laugh.

``Maybe you'd rather not risk your neck,'' (he)
he (Malfoy) said.
``Want to leave it to the dementors, do you? But if it was me, I'd want revenge. I'd hunt him (Potter) down myself.'' (unknown)

``What are you talking about?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry angrily, but at that moment Snape called,
``You should have finished adding your ingredients by now; this potion needs to stew before it can be drunk, so clear away while it simmers and then we'll test Longbottom's... '' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

Crabbe and Goyle laughed openly, watching Neville sweat as he (Neville) stirred his (Neville) potion feverishly. Hermione was muttering instructions to him (Neville) out of the corner of her (Hermione) mouth, so that Snape wouldn't see. Harry and Ron packed away their unused ingredients and went to wash their hands and ladles in the stone basin in the corner.

``What did Malfoy mean?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry muttered to Ron as he (Harry) stuck his (Harry) hands under the icy jet that poured from the gargoyle's mouth ``Why would I want revenge on Black? He (Malfoy) hasn't done anything to me -- yet.

``He (Malfoy)'s making it up,'' (Ron)
said Ron savagely.
``He (Malfoy)'s trying to make you do something stupid...'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

The end of the lesson in sight, Snape strode over to Neville, who was cowering by his (Snape) cauldron.

``Everyone gather `round,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape, his (Snape) black eyes glittering, and watch what happens to Longbottom's toad. If he (Longbottom) has managed to produce a Shrinking Solution, it will shrink to a tadpole. If, as I don't doubt, he (Longbottom) has done it wrong, his (Longbottom) toad is likely to be poisoned.''

The Gryffindors watched fearfully. The Slytherins looked excited. Snape picked up Trevor the toad in his (Snape) left hand and dipped a small spoon into Neville's potion, which was now green. He (Neville) trickled a few drops down Trevor's throat.

There was a moment of hushed silence, in which Trevor gulped; then there was a small pop, and Trevor the tadpole was wriggling in Snape's palm.

The Gryffindors burst into applause. Snape, looking sour, pulled a small bottle from the pocket of his (Snape) robe, poured a few drops on top of Trevor, and he (Trevor) reappeared suddenly, fully grown.

``Five points from Gryffindor,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape, which wiped the smiles from every face.
``I told you not to help him (Malfoy), Miss Granger. Class dismissed.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry, Ron, and Hermione climbed the steps to the entrance hall. Harry was still thinking about what Malfoy had said, while Ron was seething about Snape.

``Five points from Gryffindor because the potion was all right!

Why didn't You lie, Hermione? You should've said Neville did it all by himself!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

Hermione didn't answer. Ron looked around.

``Where is she (Hermione)?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry turned too. They were at the top of the steps now, watching the rest of the class pass them, heading for the Great Hall and lunch.

``She (Hermione) was right behind us,'' (Ron)
said Ron, frowning.

Malfoy passed them, walking between Crabbe and Goyle. He (Ron) smirked at Harry and disappeared.

``There she (Hermione) is,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

Hermione was panting slightly, hurrying up the stairs; one hand clutched her (Hermione) bag, the other seemed to be tucking something down the front of her (Hermione) robes.

``How did you do that?'' (Ron)
said Ron.

``What?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, joining them.

``One minute you were right behind us, the next moment, you were back at the bottom of the stairs again.'' (unknown)

``What?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
Hermione looked slightly confused.
``Oh -- I had to go back for something. Oh no --'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

A seam had split on Hermione's bag. Harry wasn't surprised; he (Harry) could see that it was crammed with at least a dozen large and heavy books.

``Why are you carrying all these around with you?'' (Ron)
Ron asked her (Hermione).

``You know how many subjects I'm taking,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione breathlessly.
``Couldn't hold these for me, could you?'' (unknown)

``But --'' (Ron)
Ron was turning over the books she (Hermione) had handed him (Ron), looking at the covers.
``You havent got any of these subjects today. It's only Defense Against the Dark Arts this afternoon.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione vaguely, but she (Hermione) packed all the books back into her (Hermione) bag just the same. I hope there's something good for lunch, I'm starving,'' she (Hermione) added, and she (Hermione) marched off toward the Great Hall.

``D'you get the feeling Hermione's not telling us something?Ron asked Harry.

Professor Lupin wasn't there when they arrived at his (Harry) first Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson. They all sat down, took out their books, quills, and parchment, and were talking when he (Harry) finally entered the room. Lupin smiled vaguely and placed his (Harry) tatty old briefcase on the teacher's desk. He (Harry) was as shabby as ever but looked healthier than he (Harry) had on the train, as though he (Harry) had had a few square meals.

``Good afternoon,'' (he)
he (Great) said.
``Would you please put all your books back in your bags. Today's will be a practical lesson. You will need only your wands.'' (unknown)

A few curious looks were exchanged as the class put away their books. They had never had a practical Defense Against the Dark Arts before, unless you counted the memorable class last year when their old teacher had brought a cageful of pixies -to class and set them loose.

``Right then,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, when everyone was ready.
``If you'd follow me.'' (Professor)

Puzzled but interested, the class got to its feet and followed Professor Lupin out of the classroom. He (Professor) led them along the deserted corridor and around a corner, where the first thing they saw was Peeves the Poltergeist, who was floating upside down in midair and stuffing the nearest keyhole with chewing gum.

Peeves didn't look up until Professor Lupin was two feet away; ,hen he (Professor) wiggled his (Professor) curly-toed feet and broke into song.

``Loony, loopy Lupin,'' (unknown)
Peeves sang.
``Loony, loopy Lupin, loony, loopy Lupin --'' (Rude)

Rude and unmanageable as he (Rude) almost always was, Peeves usually showed some respect toward the teachers. Everyone looked quickly at Professor Lupin to see how he (Professor) would take this; to their surprise, he (Professor) was still smiling.

``I'd take that gum out of the keyhole if I were you, Peeves,'' (he)
he (Professor) said pleasantly.
``Mr. Filch won't be able to get in to his (Filch) brooms.'' (Hogwarts/Hogwarts Express)

Filch was the Hogwarts caretaker, a bad-tempered, failed wizard who waged a constant war against the students and, indeed, Peeves. However, Peeves paid no attention to Professor Lupin's words, except to blow a loud wet raspberry.

Professor Lupin gave a small sigh and took out his (Professor) wand.

``This is a useful little spell, he (Filch) told the class over his (Filch) shoulder.

``Please watch closely.'' (He)

He (Professor) raised the wand to shoulder height, said, ``Waddiwasi! ``and pointed it at Peeves.

With the force of a bullet, the wad of chewing gum shot out of the keyhole and straight down Peeves's left nostril; he (Filch) whirled upright and zoomed away, cursing.

``Cool, sit!'' (Dean Thomas/Dean)
said Dean Thomas in amazement.

``Thank you, Dean,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, putting his (Professor) wand away again.
``Shall we proceed?'' (Professor)

They set off again, the class looking at shabby Professor Lupin with increased respect. He (Professor) led them down a second corridor and stopped, right outside the staffroom door.

``Inside, please,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, opening it and standing back.

The staffroom, a long, paneled room full of old, mismatched chairs, was empty except for one teacher. Professor Snape was sitting in a low armchair, and he (Professor) looked around as the class filed in. His (Professor) eyes were glittering and there was a nasty sneer playing around his (Professor) mouth. As Professor Lupin came in and made to close the door behind him (Professor), Snape said,

``Leave it open, Lupin. I'd rather not witness this.'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

He (Snape) got to his (Snape) feet and strode past the class, his (Snape) black robes billowing behind him (Snape). At the doorway he (Snape) turned on his (Snape) heel and said,

``Possibly no one's warned you, Lupin, but this class contains Neville Longbottom. I would advise you not to entrust him (Longbottom) with anything difficult. Not unless Miss Granger is hissing instructions in his (Longbottom) ear.'' (he)

Neville went scarlet. Harry glared at Snape; it was bad enough that he (Harry) bullied Neville in his (Harry) own classes, let alone doing it in front of other teachers.

Professor Lupin had raised his (Professor) eyebrows.

``I was hoping that Neville would assist me with the first stage of the operation,'' (he)
he (Professor) said,
``and I am sure he (Neville) will perform it admirably.'' (he)

Neville's face went, if possible, even redder. Snape's lip curled, but he (Snape) left, shutting the door with a snap.

``Now, then,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, beckoning the class toward the end of the room, where there was nothing but an old wardrobe where the teachers kept their spare robes. As Professor Lupin went to stand next to it, the wardrobe gave a sudden wobble, banging off the wall.

``Nothing to worry about,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin calmly because a few people had jumped backward in alarm.
``There's a boggart in there.'' (people)

Most people seemed to feel that this was something to worry about. Neville gave Professor Lupin a look of pure terror, and Seamus Finnigan eyed the now rattling doorknob apprehensively.

``Boggarts like dark, enclosed spaces,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin. ``Wardrobes, the gap beneath beds, the cupboards under sinks -- I've even met one that had lodged itself in a grandfather clock. This one moved in yesterday afternoon, and I asked the headmaster if the staff would leave it to give my third years some practice.

``So, the first question we must ask ourselves is, what is a boggart?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

Hermione put up her (Hermione) hand.

``It's a shape-shifter,'' (she)
she (Hermione) said.
``It can take the shape of whatever it thinks will frighten us most.'' (unknown)

``Couldn't have put it better myself,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, and Hermione glowed. ``So the boggart sitting in the darkness within has not yet assumed a form. He (headmaster) does not yet know what will frighten the person on the other side of the door. Nobody knows what a boggart looks like when he (headmaster) is alone, but when I let him (headmaster) out, he (headmaster) will immediately become whatever each of us most fears.

``This means,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, choosing to ignore Neville's `mall sputter of terror,
``that we have a huge advantage over the boggart before we begin. Have you spotted it, Harry?'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

Trying to answer a question with Hermione next to him (Neville), bobbing up and down on the balls of her (Hermione) feet with her (Hermione) hand in the air, was very off-putting, but Harry had a go.

``Er -- because there are so many of us, it won't know what shape it should be?'' (unknown)

``Precisely,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, and Hermione put her (Hermione) hand down, looking a little disappointed. ``It's always best to have com pany when you're dealing with a boggart. He (Harry) becomes confused. Which should he (Harry) become, a headless corpse or a flesh-eating slug? I once saw a boggart make that very mistake -- tried to frighten two people at once and turned himself into half a slug. Not remotely frightening.

``The charm that repels a boggart is simple, yet it requires force of mind. You see, the thing that really finishes a boggart is laughter. What you need to do is force it to assume a shape that you find amusing.

``We will practice the charm without wands first. After me, please ... Riddikulus!'' (unknown)

``Riddikulus!'' (unknown)
said the class together.

``Good,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.
``Very good. But that was the easy part, I'm afraid. You see, the word alone is not enough. And this is where you come in, Neville.'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

The wardrobe shook again, though not as much as Neville, who walked forward as though he (Neville) were heading for the gallows.

``Right, Neville,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.
``First things first: what would you say is the thing that frightens you most in the world?'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

Neville's lips moved, but no noise came out.

``didn't catch that, Neville, sorry,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin cheerfully.

Neville looked around rather wildly, as though begging someone to help him (Neville), then said, in barely more than a whisper,

``Professor Snape.'' (him)

Nearly everyone laughed. Even Neville grinned apologetically. Professor Lupin, however, looked thoughtful.

``Professor Snape... hmmm... Neville, I believe you live with your grandmother?'' (unknown)

``Er -- yes,'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville nervously.
``But -- I don't want the boggart to turn into her (grandmother) either.'' (unknown)

``No, no, you misunderstand me,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, now smiling.
``I wonder, could you tell us what sort of clothes your grandmother usually wears?'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

Neville looked startled, but said,

``Well... always the same hat. A tall one with a stuffed vulture on top. And a long dress... green, normally... and sometimes a fox-fur scarf.'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

``And a handbag?'' (Professor)
prompted Professor Lupin.

``A big red one,'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville.

``Right then,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.
``Can you picture those clothes very clearly, Neville? Can you see them in your mind's eye?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville uncertainty, plainly wondering what was coming next.

``When the boggart bursts out of this wardrobe, Neville, and sees You, it will assume the form of Professor Snape,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin. ``And You will raise your wand -- thus -- and cry
``Riddikulus' -- and concentrate hard on your grandmother's clothes. If all goes well, Professor Boggart Snape will be forced into that vulture-topped hat, and that green dress, with that big red handbag.'' (unknown)

There was a great shout of laughter. The wardrobe wobbled more violently.

``If Neville is successful, the boggart is likely to shift his (Neville) attention to each of us in turn,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.
``I would like all of you to take a moment now to think of the thing that scares you most, and imagine how you might force it to look comical...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

The room went quiet. Harry thought... ``What scared him (Neville) most in the world?

His (Neville) first thought was Lord Voldemort -- a Voldemort returned to full strength. But before he (Voldemort) had even started to plan a possible counterattack on a boggart-Voldemort, a horrible image came floating to the surface of his (Voldemort) mind...

A rotting, glistening hand, slithering back beneath a black cloak ... a long, rattling breath from an unseen mouth... then a cold so penetrating it felt like drowning...

Harry shivered, then looked around, hoping no one had noticed. Many people had their eyes shut tight. Ron was muttering to himself,

``Take its legs off '' (Ron)
Harry was sure he (Harry) knew what that was about. Ron's greatest fear was spiders.

``Everyone ready?'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.

Harry felt a lurch of fear. He (Harry) wasn't ready. How could you make a dementor less frightening? But he (Harry) didn't want to ask for more time; everyone else was nodding and rolling up their sleeves.

``Neville, we're going to back away,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.
``Let you have a clear field, all right? I'll call the next person forward... Everyone back, now, so Neville can get a clear shot --'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

They all retreated, backed against the walls, leaving Neville alone beside the wardrobe. He (Neville) looked pale and frightened, but he (Neville) had pushed up the sleeves of his (Neville) robes and was holding his (Neville) wand ready.

``On the count of three, Neville,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin, who was

pointing his (Professor) own wand at the handle of the wardrobe.

``One two -- three -- now!'' (Professor)

A jet of sparks shot from the end of Professor Lupin's wand and hit the doorknob. The wardrobe burst open. Hook-nosed and menacing, Professor Snape stepped out, his (Snape) eyes flashing at Neville.

Neville backed away, his (Neville) wand up, mouthing wordlessly. Snape was bearing down upon him (Snape), reaching inside his (Snape) robes.

``R -- r -- riddikulus! ``squeaked Neville.

There was a noise like a whip crack. Snape stumbled; he (Snape) was wearing a long, lace-trimmed dress and a towering hat topped with a moth-eaten vulture, and he (Snape) was swinging a huge crimson handbag.

There was a roar of laughter; the boggart paused, confused, and Professor Lupin shouted,

``Parvati! Forward!'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)

Parvati walked forward, her (Parvati) face set. Snape rounded on her (Parvati).
