There was another crack, and where he (Snape) had stood was a bloodstained, bandaged mummy; its sightless face was turned to Parvati and it began to walk toward her (Parvati) very slowly, dragging its feet, its stiff arms rising --

``Riddikulus!'' (Parvati)
cried Parvati.

A bandage unraveled at the mummy's feet; it became entangled, fell face forward, and its head rolled off.

``Seamus!'' (Professor)
roared Professor Lupin.

Seamus darted past Parvati.

Crack! Where the mummy had been was a woman with floorlength black hair and a skeletal, green-tinged face -- a banshee. She (woman) opened her (woman) mouth wide and an unearthly sound filled the room, a long, wailing shriek that made the hair on Harry's head stand on end -- `Riddikulus!'' shouted Seamus.

The banshee made a rasping noise and clutched her (woman) throat; her (woman) voice was gone.

Crack! The banshee turned into a rat, which chased its tail in a circle, then -- crack!- became a rattlesnake, which slithered and writhed before -- crack! -- becoming a single, bloody eyeball.

``It's confused!'' (Lupin)
shouted Lupin.
``We're getting there! Dean!'' (Dean)

Dean hurried forward.

Crack! The eyeball became a severed hand, which flipped over and began to creep along the floor like a crab.

``Riddikulus!'' (Dean)
yelled Dean.

``There was a snap, and the hand was trapped in a mousetrap.

``Excellent! Ron, you next!'' (Ron)

Ron leapt forward.

Crack!

Quite a few people screamed. A giant spider, six feet tall and covered in hair, was advancing on Ron, clicking its pincers menacingly. For a moment, Harry thought Ron had frozen. Then --

``Riddikulus!'' (Ron)
bellowed Ron, and the spider's legs vanished; it rolled over and over; Lavender Brown squealed and ran out of its way and it came to a halt at Harry's feet. He (Harry) raised his (Harry) wand, ready, but --

``Here!'' (He)
shouted Professor Lupin suddenly, hurrying forward. Crack!

The legless spider had vanished. For a second, everyone looked wildly around to see where it was. Then they saw a silvery-white orb hanging in the air in front of Lupin, who said,

``Riddikulus!'' (Lupin)
almosi lazily.

Crack!

``Forward, Neville, and finish him (Neville) off!'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin as the boggart landed on the floor as a cockroach. Crack! Snape was back. This time Neville charged forward looking determined.

``Riddikulus!'' (he)
he (Neville) shouted, and they had a split second's view of Snape in his (Snape) lacy dress before Neville let out a great
``Ha!'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
of laughter, and the boggart exploded, burst into a thousand tiny wisps of smoke, and was gone.

``Excellent!'' (Professor)
cried Professor Lupin as the class broke into applause.
``Excellent-RRB- Neville. Well done, everyone... Let me See... five points to Gryffindor for every person to tackle the boggart -- ten for Neville because he (Neville) did it twice... and five each to Hermione and Harry.'' (unknown)

``But I didn't do anything,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``You and Hermione answered my questions correctly at the start of the class, Harry,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
Lupin said lightly.
``Very well, everyone, an excellent lesson. Homework, kindly read the chapter on boggarts and summarize it for me... to be handed in on Monday. That will be all.'' (unknown)

Talking excitedly, the class left the staffroom. Harry, however, wasn't feeling cheerful. Professor Lupin had deliberately stopped him (Harry) from tackling the boggart. Why? Was it because he (Harry)'d seen Harry collapse on the train, and thought he (Harry) wasn't up to much? Had he (Harry) thought Harry would pass out again?

But no one else seemed to have noticed anything.

``Did you see me take that banshee?'' (Seamus Finnigan/Seamus)
shouted Seamus.
``And the hand!'' (Dean Thomas/Dean)
said Dean, waving his (Dean) own around.

``And Snape in that hat!'' (unknown)
``And my mummy!'' (I)

I wonder why Professor Lupin's frightened of crystal balls?'' said Lavender thoughtfully.

``That was the best Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson we've ever had, wasn't it?'' (Ron)
said Ron excitedly as they made their way back to the classroom to get their bags.

``He (Snape) seems like a very good teacher,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione approvingly.
``But I wish I could have had a turn with the boggart --'' (unknown)

``What would it have been for you?'' (Ron)
said Ron, sniggering.
``A piece of homework that only got nine out of ten?'' (people)

CHAPTER EIGHT

FLIGHT OF THE FAT FADY

In no time at all, Defense Against the Dark Arts had become most people's favorite class. Only Draco Malfoy and his (Malfoy) gang of Slytherins had anything bad to say about Professor Lupin.

``Look at the state of his (Snape) robes,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
Malfoy would say in a loud whisper as Professor Lupin passed.
``He (Snape) dresses like our old houseelf '' (Professor)
***** But no one else cared that Professor Lupin's robes were patched and frayed. His (Professor) next few lessons were just as interesting as the first. After boggarts, they studied Red Caps, nasty little goblin like creatures that lurked wherever there had been bloodshed: in the dungeons of castles and the potholes of deserted battlefields, waiting to bludgeon those who had gotten lost. From Red Caps they moved on to kappas, creepy. water-dwellers that looked like scaly monkeys, with webbed hands itching to strangle unwitting waders in their ponds.

Harry only wished he (Harry) was as happy with some of his (Harry) other classes. Worst of all was Potions. Snape was in a particularly vindictive mood these days, and no one was in any doubt why. The story of the boggart assuming Snape's shape, and the way that Neville had dressed it in his (Neville) grandmother's clothes, had traveled through the school like wildfire. Snape didn't seem to find it funny. His (Snape) eyes flashed menacingly at the very mention of Professor Lupin's name, and he (Professor) was bullying Neville worse than ever.

Harry was also growing to dread the hours he (Harry) spent in Professor Trelawney's stifling tower room, deciphering lopsided shapes and symbols, trying to ignore the way Professor Trelawney's enormous eyes filled with tears every time she (grandmother) looked at him (Professor). He (Professor) couldn't like Professer Trelawney, even though she (grandmother) was treated with respect bordering on reverence by many of the class. Parvati Patil and Lavender Brown had taken to haunting Professor Trelawney's tower room at lunch times, and always returned with annoyingly superior looks on their faces, as though they knew things the others didn't. They had also started using hushed voices whenever they spoke to Harry, as though he (Harry) were on his (Harry) deathbed.

Nobody really liked Care of Magical Creatures, which, after the action-packed first class, had become extremely dull. Hagrid seemed to have lost his (Harry) confidence. They were now spending lesson after lesson learning how to look after flobberworms, which had to be some of the most boring creatures in existence.

``Why would anyone bother looking after them?'' (Ron)
said Ron, after yet another hour of poking shredded lettuce down the flobberworms' throats.

At the start of October, however, Harry had something else to occupy him (Harry), something so enjoyable it more than made up for his (Harry) unsatisfactory classes. The Quidditch season was approaching, and O1iver Wood, Captain of the Gryffindor team, called a meeting on Thursday evening to discuss tactics for the new season.

There were seven people on a Quidditch team: three Chasers, whose job it was to score goals by putting the Quaffle -LRB-a red, soccer-sized ball-RRB- through one of the fifty-foot-high hoops at each

end of the field; two Beaters, who were equipped with heavy bats to repel the Bludgers -LRB-two heavy black balls that zoomed around trying to attack the players-RRB-; a Keeper, who defended the goal

posts, and the Seeker, who had the hardest job of all, that of catching the Golden Snitch, a tiny, winged, walnut-sized ball, whose capture ended the game and earned the Seeker's team an extra one hundred and fifty points.

Oliver Wood was a burly seventeen-year-old, now in his (Wood) seventh and final year at Hogwarts. There was a quiet sort of desperation in his (Wood) voice a's he (Wood) addressed his (Wood) six fellow team members in the chilly locker rooms on the edge of the darkening Quidditch field.

``This is our last chance -- my last chance -- to win the Quidditch Cup,'' (he)
he (Wood) told them, striding up and down in front of them.
``I'll be leaving at the end of this year. I'll never get another shot at it.'' (unknown)

``Gryffindor hasn't won for seven years now. Okay, so we've had the worst luck in the world -- injuries -- then the tournamentgetting called off last year Wood swallowed, as though the memory still brought a lump to his (Wood) throat. ``But we also know we've got the best-ruddy-team-in-the-school,'' he (Wood) said, punching a fist into his (Wood) other hand, the old manic glint back in his (Wood) eye.

``We've got three superb Chasers.'' (Wood)

Wood pointed at Alicia Spinner, Angelina Johnson, and Katie Bell.

``We've got two unbeatable Beaters.'' (unknown)

``Stop it, Oliver, you're embarrassing us,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred and George Weasley together, pretending to blush.

``And we've got a Seeker who has never failed to win us a match!'' (Wood)
Wood rumbled, glaring at Harry with a kind of furious pride.
``And me,'' (he)
he (Wood) added as an afterthought.

``We think you're very good too, Oliver,'' (George/George Weasley/Weasley)
said George.

``Spanking good Keeper,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred.

``The point is,'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
Wood went on, resuming his (Wood) pacing,
``the Quidditch Cup should have had our name on it these last two years. Ever since Harry joined the team, I've thought the thing was in the bag. But we haven't got it, and this year's the last chance we'll get to finally see our name on the thing...'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)

Wood spoke so dejectedly that even Fred and George looked sympathetic.

``Oliver, this year's our year,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred.

``We'll do it, Oliver!'' (Angelina)
said Angelina.

``Definitely,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

Full of determination, the team started training sessions, three evenings a week. The weather was getting colder and wetter, the nights darker, but no amount of mud, wind, or rain could tarnish Harry's wonderful vision of finally winning the huge, silver Quidditch Cup.

Harry returned to the Gryffindor common room one evening after training, cold and stiff but pleased with the way practice had gone, to find the room buzzing excitedly.

``What's happened?'' (he)
, he (Harry) asked Ron and Hermione, who were sitting in two of the best chairs by the fireside and completing some star charts for Astronomy.

``First Hogsmeade weekend,'' (Ron)
said Ron, pointing at a notice that had appeared on the battered old bulletin board.
``End of October. Halloween.'' (unknown)

``Excellent,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred, who had followed Harry through the portrait hole.
``I need to visit Zonko's. I'm nearly out of Stink Pellets.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry threw himself into a chair beside Ron, his (Harry) high spirits ebbing away. Hermione seemed to read his (Harry) mind.

``Harry, I'm sure you'll be able to go next time,'' (she)
she (Hermione) said.
``They're bound to catch Black soon. He (Harry)'s been sighted once already.'' (unknown)

``Black's not fool enough to try anything in Hogsmeade,'' (Ron)
said Ron.
``Ask McGonagall if you can go this time, Harry. The next one might not be for ages --'' (unknown)

``Ron!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione.
``Harry's supposed to stay in school-'' (Ron)

``He (Harry) can't be the only third year left behind,'' (Ron)
said Ron.
``Ask McGonagall, go on, Harry --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``Yeah, I think I will,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, making up his (Harry) mind.

Hermione opened her (Hermione) mouth to argue, but at that moment Crookshanks leapt lightly onto her (Hermione) lap. A large, dead spider was dangling from his (Harry) mouth.

``Does he (Harry) have to eat that in front of us?'' (Ron)
said Ron, scowling.

``Clever Crookshanks, did you catch that all by yourself?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione.

Crookshanks; slowly chewed up the spider, his (Ron) yellow eyes fixed insolently on Ron.

``Just keep him (Harry) over there, that's all,'' (Ron)
said Ron irritably, turning back to his (Ron) star chart.
``1've got Scabbers asleep in my bag.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry yawned. He (Harry) really wanted to go to bed, but he (Harry) still had his (Harry) own star chart to complete. He (Harry) pulled his (Harry) bag toward him (Harry), took out parchment, ink, and quill, and started work.

``You can copy mine, if you like,'' (Ron)
said Ron, labeling his (Ron) last star with a flourish and shoving the chart toward Harry.

Hermione, who disapproved of copying, pursed her (Hermione) lips but didn't say anything. Crookshanks was still staring unblinkingly at Ron, flicking the end of his (Ron) bushy tail. Then, without warning, he (Ron) pounced.

``OY!'' (Ron)
Ron roared, seizing his (Ron) bag as Crookshanks sank four sets of claws deep inside it and began tearing ferociously.
``GET OFF, YOU STUPID ANIMAL!'' (Ron)

Ron tried to pull the bag away from Crookshanks, but Crookshanks clung on, spitting and slashing.

``Ron, don't hurt him (Ron)!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
squealed Hermione; the whole common room was watching; Ron whirled the bag around, Crookshanks still clinging to it, and Scabbers came flying out of the top -

``CATCH THAT CAR' Ron yelled as Crookshanks freed himself from the remnants of the bag, sprang over the table, and chased after the terrified Scabbers.

George Weasley made a lunge for Crookshanks but missed; Scabbers streaked through twenty pairs of legs and shot beneath an old chest of drawers. Crookshanks skidded to a halt, crouched low on his (Weasley) bandy legs, and started making furious swipes beneath it with his (Weasley) front paw.

Ron and Hermione hurried over; Hermione grabbed Crookshanks around the middle and heaved him (Ron) away; Ron threw himself onto his (Ron) stomach and, with great difficulty, pulled Scabbers out by the tail.

``Look at him (Ron)!'' (he)
he (Ron) said furiously to Hermione, dangling Scabbers in front of her (Hermione).
``He (Ron)'s skin and bone! You keep that cat away from him (Ron)!'' (unknown)

``Crookshanks doesn't understand it's wrong!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, her (Hermione) voice shaking.
``All cats chase rats, Ron!'' (unknown)

``There's something funny about that animal!'' (Ron)
said Ron, who was trying to persuade a frantically wiggling Scabbers back into his (Ron) pocket.
``It heard me say that Scabbers was in my bag!'' (unknown)

``Oh, what rubbish,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione impatiently.
``Crookshanks could smell him (Ron), Ron, how else d'you think --'' (unknown)

``That cat's got it in for Scabbers!'' (Ron)
said Ron, `ignoring the people around him (Ron), who were starting to giggle.
``And Scabbers was here first, and he (Ron)'s ill!'' (Ron)

Ron marched through the common room and out of sight up the stairs to the boys' dormitories.

Ron was still in a bad mood with Hermione next day. He (Ron) barely talked to her (Hermione) all through Herbology, even though he (Ron), Harry, and Hermione were working together on the same puffapod.

``How's Scabbers?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
Hermione asked timidly as they stripped fat pink pods from the plants and emptied the shining beans into a wooden pail.

``He (Ron)'s hiding at the bottom of my bed, shaking, '' (Ron)
said Ron angrily, missing the pail and scattering beans over the greenhouse floor.

``Careful, Weasley, careful!'' (Professor)
cried Professor Sprout as the beans burst into bloom before their very eyes.

They had Transfiguration next. Harry, who had resolved to ask Professor McGonagall after the lesson whether he (Professor) could go into Hogsmeade with the rest, joined the line outside the class trying to decide how he (Professor) was going to argue his (Professor) case. He (Professor) was distracted, however, by a disturbance at the front of the line.

Lavender Brown seemed to be crying. Parvati had her (Parvati) arm around her (Parvati) and was explaining something to Seamus Finnigan and Dean Thomas, who were looking very serious.

``What's the matter, Lavender?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione anxiously as she (Hermione), Harry, and Ron went to join the group.

``She (Scabbers) got a letter from home this morning,'' (Parvati)
Parvati whispered.
``It's her (Scabbers) rabbit, Binky. He (Weasley)'s been killed by a fox.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione,
``I'm sorry, Lavender.'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

``I should have known!'' (unknown)
said Lavender tragically.
``You know what day it is?'' (unknown)

``Er --'' (unknown)

``The sixteenth of October! ``That thing you're dreading, it will happen on the sixteenth of October!

'' Remember? She (Hermione) was right, she (Hermione) was right!'' (unknown)

The whole class was gathered around Lavender now. Seamus shook his (Seamus) head seriously. Hermione hesitated; then she (Hermione) said,

``You -- you were dreading Binky being killed by a fox?'' (she)

``Well, not necessarily by a fox,'' (Hermione)
said Lavender, looking up at Hermione with streaming eyes,
``but I was obviously dreading him (fox) dying, wasn't l?'' (Hermione)

``Oh,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione. She (Hermione) paused again. Then

``Was Binky an old rabbit?'' (unknown)

``N -- no!'' (unknown)
sobbed Lavender.
``H -- he (fox) was only a baby!'' (Parvati/Parvati Patil)

Parvati tightened her (Hermione) arm around Lavender's shoulders.

said Hermione.

Parvati glared at her (Hermione).

``Well, look at it logically,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, turning to the rest of the group-
``I mean, Binky didn't even die today, did he (fox)? Lavender just got the news today-'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
Lavender wailed loudly.
''- and she (Hermione) can't have been dreading it, because it's come as a real shock --'' (Ron)

``Don't mind Hermione, Lavender,'' (Ron)
said Ron loudly,
``she (Hermione) doesn't think other people's pets matter very much.'' (Ron)

Professor McGonagall opened the classroom door at that moment, which was perhaps lucky; Hermione and Ron were looking daggers at each other, and when they got into class, they seated themselves on either side of Harry and didn't talk to each other for the whole class.

Harry still hadn't decided what he (Harry) was going to say to Professor McGonagall when the bell rang at the end of the lesson, but it was she (Hermione) who brought up the subject of Hogsmeade first.

``One moment, please !'' (she)
she (Hermione) called as the class made to leave.

Neville put up his (Neville) hand.

``Please, Professor, I -- I think I've lost

Ron hissed at Harry.

``Oh. but --'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
Hermione began.

``Go for it, Harry,'' (Ron)
said Ron stubbornly.

Harry waited for the rest of the class to disappear, then headed nervously for Professor McGonagall's desk.

``Yes, Potter?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry took a deep breath.

``Professor, my aunt and uncle -- er -- forgot to sign my form,'' (he)
he (Harry) said.

Professor McGonagall looked over her (Hermione) square spectacles at him (Professor) but didn't say anything.

``So -- er d'you think it would be all right mean, will It be okay if I -- if I go to Hogsmeade?'' (Professor)

Professor McGonagall looked down and began shuffling papers on her (Hermione) desk.

``I'm afraid not, Potter,'' (she)
she (Hermione) said.
``You heard what I said. No form, no visiting the village. That's the rule.'' (unknown)

``But -- Professor, my aunt and uncle -- you know, they're Muggles, they don't really understand about -- about Hogwarts forms and stuff,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said, while Ron egged him (Harry) on with vigorous nods.
``If you said I could go --'' (Professor)

``But I don't say so,'' (Professor)
said Professor McGonagall, standing up and piling her (Hermione) papers neatly into a drawer.
``The form clearly states that the parent or guardian must give permission.'' (She)
She (Hermione) turned to look at him (Professor), with an odd expression on her (Hermione) face. Was it pity?
``I'm sorry, Potter, but that's my final word. You had better hurry, or you'll be late for your next lesson.'' (unknown)

There was nothing to be done. Ron called Professor McGonagall a lot of names that greatly annoyed Hermione; Hermione assumed an

``all-for-the-best'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
expression that made Ron even angrier, and Harry had to endure everyone in the class talking loudly and happily about what they were going to do first, once they got into Hogsmeade.

``There's always the feast,'' (Ron)
said Ron, in an effort to cheer Harry UP.
``You know, the Halloween feast, in the evening.'' (unknown)

``Yeah,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry gloomily,
``great.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

The Halloween feast was always good, but it would taste a lot better if he (Harry) was coming to it after a day in Hogsmeade with everyone else. Nothing anyone said made him (Harry) feel any better about being left behind. Dean Thomas, who was good with a quill, had offered to forge Uncle Vernon's signature on the form, but as Harry had already told Professor McGonagall he (Professor) hadn't had it signed, that was no good. Ron halfheartedly suggested the Invisibility Cloak, but Hermione stamped on that one, reminding Ron what Dumbledore had told them about the dementors being able to see through them. Percy had what were possibly the least helpful words of comfort.

``They make a fuss about Hogsmeade, but I assure you, Harry, it's not all it's cracked up to be,'' (he)
he (Percy) said seriously.
``All right, the sweetshop's rather good, and Zonko's Joke Shop's frankly dangerous, and yes, the Shrieking Shack's always worth a visit, but really, Harry, apart from that, you're not missing anything.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

On Halloween morning, Harry awoke with the rest and went down to breakfast, feeling thoroughly depressed, though doing his (Harry) best to act normally.

``We'll bring you. lots of sweets back from Honeydukes,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, looking desperately sorry for him (Harry).

``Yeah, loads,'' (Ron)
said Ron. He (Ron) and Hermione had finally forgotten their squabble about Crookshanks in the face of Harry's difficulties.

``Don't worry about me,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, in what he (Harry) hoped was at, offhand voice,
``I'll see you at the feast. Have a good time.'' (he)

He (Harry) accompanied them to the entrance hall, where Filch, the caretaker, was standing inside the front doors, checking off names against a long list, peering suspiciously into every face, and making sure that no one was sneaking out who shouldn't be going.

``Staying here, Potter?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
shouted Malfoy, who was standing in line with Crabbe and Goyle.
``Scared of passing the dementors?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry ignored him (Harry) and made his (Harry) solitary way up the marble staircase, through the deserted corridors, and back to Gryffindor Tower.

``Password?'' (Fat)
said the Fat Lady, jerking out of a doze.

``Fortuna Major,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry listlessly.

The portrait swung open and he (Harry) climbed through the hole into the common room. It was full of chattering first and second years, and a few older students, who had obviously visited Hogsmeade so often the novelty had worn off

``Harry! Harry! Hi, Harry!'' (Hogsmeade)

It was Colin Creevey, a second year who was deeply in awe of Harry and never missed an opportunity to speak to him (Harry).

``Aren't you going to Hogsmeade, Harry? Why not? Hey'' (Colin)
-- Colin looked eagerly around at his (Colin) friends --

said Harry, who wasn't in the mood to have a lot of people staring avidly at the scar on his (Harry) forehead.
``I -- I've got to go to the library, got to get some work done.'' (he)

After that, he (Harry) had no choice but to turn right around and head back out of the portrait hole again.

``What was the point waking me up?'' (Fat)
the Fat Lady called grumpily after him (Harry) as he (Harry) walked away.

Harry wandered dispiritedly toward the library, but halfway there he (Harry) changed his (Harry) mind; he (Harry) didn't feel like working. He (Harry) turned around and came face-to-face with Filch, who had obviously just seen off the last of the Hogsmeade visitors.

``What are you doing?'' (unknown)
Filch snarled suspiciously.

``Nothing,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry truthfully.

``Nothing!'' (unknown)
spat Filch, his (Harry) jowls quivering unpleasantly.
``A likely story! Sneaking around on your own -- why aren't you in Hogsmeade buying Stink Pellets and Belch Powder and Whizzing Worms like the rest of your nasty little friends?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry shrugged.

``Well, get back to your common room where you belong!'' (he)
snapped Filch, and he (Harry) stood glaring until Harry had passed out of sight.

But Harry didn't go back to the common room; he (Harry) climbed a staircase, thinking vaguely of visiting the Owlery to see Hedwig, and was walking along another corridor when a voice from inside one of the rooms said,

``Harry?'' (Hedwig)

Harry doubled back to see who had spoken and met Professor Lupin, looking around his (Harry) office door.

``What are you doing?'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, though in a very different voice from Filch.

``Hogsmeade,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

said Lupin. He (Harry) considered Harry for a moment.

``A what?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry. I

He (Harry) followed Lupin into his (Harry) office. In the corner stood a very large tank of water. A sickly green creature with sharp little horns had its face pressed against the glass, pulling faces and flexing its long, spindly fingers.

``Water demon,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, surveying the grindylow thoughtfully.
``We shouldn't have much difficulty with him (demon), not after the kappas. The trick is to break his (demon) grip. You notice the abnormally long fingers? Strong, but very brittle.'' (unknown)

The grindylow bared its green teeth and then buried itself in a tangle of weeds in a corner.

``Cup of tea?'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
Lupin said, looking around for his (Harry) kettle.
``I was just thinking of making one.'' (unknown)

said Harry awkwardly.

Lupin tapped the kettle with his (Harry) wand and a blast of steam issued suddenly from the spout.

``Sit down,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, taking the lid off a dusty tin.

Harry looked at him (Harry). Lupin's eyes were twinkling.

``How did you know about that?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry asked.

``Professor McGonagall told me,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, passing Harry a chipped mug of tea.

``No,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

He (Harry) thought for a moment of telling Lupin about the dog he (Harry)'d seen in Magnolia Crescent but decided not to. He (Harry) didn't want Lupin to think he (Harry) was a coward, especially since Lupin alreadv seemed to think he (Harry) couldn't cope with a boggart.

Something of Harry's thoughts seemed to have shown on his (Harry) face, because Lupin said,

``Anything worrying you, Harry?'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)

``No,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry lied. He (Harry) drank a bit of tea and watched the grindylow brandishing a fist at him (Harry).

he (Harry) said suddenly, putting his (Harry) tea down on Lupin's desk.

``Yes,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)

``Why didn't you let me fight it?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Lupin raised his (Harry) eyebrows.

``I would have thought that was obvious, Harry,'' (he)
he (Harry) said, sounding surprised.

Harry, who had expected Lupin to deny that he (Harry)'d done any such thing, was taken aback.

he (Harry) said again.

``Well,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, frowning slightly,
``I assumed that if the boggart faced you, it would assume the shape of Lord Voldemort.'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)

Harry stared. Not only was this the last answer he (Harry)'d expected, but Lupin had said Voldemort's name. The only person Harry had ever heard say the name aloud -LRB-apart from himself-RRB- was Professor Dumbledore.

fie smiled slightly at the look of surprise on Harry's face.

Harry didn't know what to say to that, so he (Harry) drank some mot,, tea.

said Harry. He (Harry) was suddenly feeling a lot happier.
``Professor Lupin, you know the dementors --'' (He)

He (Harry) was interrupted by a knock on the door.
