said Harry.
``Id better put it upstairs.'' (unknown)

``I'll take it!'' (Ron)
said Ron eagerly.
``I've got to give Scabbers his (Harry) rat tonic.'' (He)

He (Harry) took the Firebolt and, holding it as if it were made of glass, carried it away up the boys' staircase.

``Can I sit down, then?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry asked Hermione.

``I suppose so,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, moving a great stack of parchment off a chair.

Harry looked around at the cluttered table, at the long Arithmancy essay on which the ink was still glistening, at the even longer Muggle Studies essay -LRB-

``Explain Why Muggles Need Electricity'' (Muggle)
and at the rune translation Hermione was now poring over.

``How are you getting through all this stuff?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry asked her (Hermione).

``Oh, well -- you know -- working hard,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione. Close-up, Harry saw that she (Hermione) looked almost as tired as Lupin.

``Why don't you just drop a couple of subjects?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry asked, watching her (Hermione) lifting books as she (Hermione) searched for her (Hermione) rune dictionary.

``I couldn't do that!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, looking scandalized.

``Arithmancy looks terrible,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, picking up a very complicated-looking number chart.

``Oh no, it's wonderful!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione earnestly.
``It's my favorite subject! It's --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

But exactly what was wonderful about Arithmancy, Harry never found out. At that precise moment, a strangled yell echoed down the boys' staircase. The whole common room fell silent, staring, petrified, at the entrance. Then came hurried footsteps, growing louder and louder -- and then Ron came leaping into view, dragging with him (Ron) a bedsheet.

``LOOK!'' (he)
he (Ron) bellowed, striding over to Hermione's table.

``LOOK!'' (he)
he (Ron) yelled, shaking the sheets in her (Hermione) face.

``Ron, what --?'' (unknown)

``SCABBERS! LOOK! SCABBERS!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

Hermione was leaning away from Ron, looking utterly bewildered. Harry looked down at the sheet Ron was holding. There was something red on it. Something that looked horribly like --

``BLOOD!'' (Ron)
Ron yelled into the stunned silence.
``HE (Ron)'S GONE! AND YOU KNOW WHAT WAS ON THE FLOOR?'' (unknown)

``N -- no,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione in a trembling voice.

Ron threw something down onto Hermione's rune translation. Hermione and Harry leaned forward. Lying on top of the weird, spiky shapes were several long, ginger cat hairs.

CHAPTER THIRTEEN

GRYFFINDOR VERSUS RAVENCLAW

It looked like the end of Ron and Hermione's friendship. Each was so angry with the other that Harry couldn't see how they'd ever make up.

Ron was enraged that Hermione had never taken Crookshanks's attempts to eat Scabbers seriously, hadn't bothered to keep a close enough watch on him (Ron), and was still trying to pretend that Crookshanks was innocent by suggesting that Ron look for Scabbers under all the boys' beds. Hermione, meanwhile, maintained fiercely that Ron had no proof that Crookshanks had eaten Scabbers, that the ginger hairs might have been there since Christmas, and that Ron had been prejudiced against her (Hermione) cat ever since Crookshanks had landed on Ron's head in the Magical Menagerie.

Personally, Harry was sure that Crookshanks had eaten Scabbers, and when he (Harry) tried to point out to Hermione that the evidence all pointed that way, she (Hermione) lost her (Hermione) temper with Harry too.

``Okay, side with Ron, I knew you would!'' (she)
she (Hermione) said shrilly.
``First the Firebolt, now Scabbers, everything's my fault, isn't it! just leave me alone, Harry, I've got a lot of work to do!'' (Ron)

Ron had taken the loss of his (Ron) rat very hard indeed.

``Come on, Ron, you were always saying how boring Scabbers was,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred bracingly.
``And he (Ron)'s been off-color for ages, he (Ron) was wasting away. It was probably better for him (Ron) to snuff it quickly -- one swallow -- he (Ron) probably didn't feel a thing.'' (unknown)

``Fred!'' (Ginny)
said Ginny indignantly.

``All he (Fred) did was eat and sleep, Ron, you said it yourself,'' (George/George Weasley/Weasley)
said George.

``He (Ron) bit Goyle for us once!'' (Ron)
Ron said miserably.
``Remember, Harry?'' (unknown)

``Yeah, that's true,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``His (Harry) finest hour,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred, unable to keep a straight face.
``Let the scar on Goyle's finger stand as a lasting tribute to his (Harry) memory. Oh, come on, Ron, get yourself down to Hogsmeade and buy a new rat, what's the point of moaning?'' (Ron)

In a last-ditch attempt to cheer Ron up, Harry persuaded him (Harry) to come along to the Gryffindor team's final practice before the Ravenclaw match, so that he (Harry) could have a ride on the Firebolt after they'd finished. This did seem to take Ron's mind off Scabbers for a moment -LRB-

``Great! Can I try and shoot a few goals on it?'' (Ron)
-RRB- so they set off for the Quidditch field together.

Madam Hooch, who was still overseeing Gryffindor practices to keep an eye on Harry, was just as impressed with the Firebolt as everyone else had been. She (Hooch) took it in her (Hooch) hands before takeoff and gave them the benefit of her (Hooch) professional opinion.

``Look at the balance on it! If the Nimbus series has a fault, it's a slight list to the tail end -- you often find they develop a drag after a few years. They've updated the handle too, a bit slimmer than the Cleansweeps, reminds me of the old Silver Arrows -- a Pity they've stopped making them. I learned to fly on one, and a very fine old broom it was too...'' (She)

She (Hooch) continued in this vein for some time, until Wood said,

``Er -- Madam Hooch? Is it okay if Harry has the Firebolt back? We need to practice...'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)

``Oh -- right -- here you are, then, Potter,'' (Madam Hooch)
said Madam Hooch.
``I'll sit over here with Weasley...'' (She)

She (Hooch) and Ron left the field to sit in the stadium, and the Gryffindor team gathered around Wood for his (Wood) final instructions for tomorrow's match.

``Harry, I've just found out who Ravenclaw is playing as Seeker. It's Cho Chang. She (Hooch)'s a fourth year, and she (Hooch)'s pretty good... I really hoped she (Hooch) wouldn't be fit, she (Hooch)'s had some problems with injuries...'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
Wood scowled his (Wood) displeasure that Cho Chang had made a full recovery, then said,
``On the other hand, she (Hooch) rides a Comet Two Sixty, which is going to look like a joke next to the Firebolt.'' (Cho/Cho Chang/Chang)
He (Chang) gave Harry's broom a look of fervent admiration, then said,
``Okay, everyone, let's go -- '' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

And at long last, Harry mounted his (Harry) Firebolt, and kicked off from the ground.

It was better than he (Harry)'d ever dreamed. The Firebolt turned with the lightest touch; it seemed to obey his (Harry) thoughts rather than his (Harry) grip; it sped across the field at such speed that the stadium turned into a green-and-gray blur; Harry turned it so sharply that Alicia Spinnet screamed, then he (Harry) went into a perfectly controlled dive, brushing the grassy field with his (Harry) toes before rising thirty, forty, fifty feet into the air again.

``Harry, I'm letting the Snitch out!'' (Wood)
Wood called.

Harry turned and raced a Bludger toward the goal posts; he (Harry) outstripped it easily, saw the Snitch dart out from behind Wood, and within ten seconds had caught it tightly in his (Wood) hand.

The team cheered madly. Harry let the Snitch go again, gave it a minute's head start, then tore after it, weaving in and out of the others; he (Harry) spotted it lurking near Katie Bell's knee, looped her (Bell) easily, and caught it again.

It was the best practice ever; the team, inspired by the presence of the Firebolt in their midst, performed their best moves faultlessly, and by the time they hit the ground again, Wood didn't have a single criticism to make, which, as George Weasley pointed out, was a first.

``I can't see what's going to stop us tomorrow!'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
said Wood.
``Not unless -- Harry, you've sorted out your dementor problem, haven't you?'' (unknown)

``Yeah,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, thinking of his (Harry) feeble Patronus and wishing it were stronger.

``The dementors won't turn up again, Oliver. Dumbledore'd go ballistic,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred confidently.

``Well, let's hope not,'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
said Wood.
``Anyway -- good work, everyone. Let's get back to the tower... turn in early --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``I'm staying out for a bit; Ron wants a go on the Firebolt,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry told Wood, and while the rest of the team headed off to the locker rooms, Harry strode over to Ron, who vaulted the barrier to the stands and came to meet him (Harry). Madam Hooch had fallen asleep in her (Hooch) seat.

``Here you go,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, handing Ron the Firebolt.

Ron, an expression of ecstasy on his (Ron) face, mounted the broom and zoomed off into the gathering darkness while Harry walked around the edge of the field, watching him (Harry). Night had fallen before Madam Hooch awoke with a start, told Harry and Ron off for not waking her (Hooch), and insisted that they go back to the castle.

Harry shouldered the Firebolt and he (Harry) and Ron walked out of the shadowy stadium, discussing the Firebolt's superbly smooth action, its phenomenal acceleration, and its pinpoint turning. They were halfway toward the castle when Harry, glancing to his (Harry) left, saw something that made his (Harry) heart turn over -- a pair of eyes, gleaming out of the darkness.

Harry stopped dead, his (Harry) heart banging against his (Harry) ribs.

``What's the matter?'' (Ron)
said Ron.

Harry pointed. Ron pulled out his (Harry) wand and muttered,

``Lumos!'' (Ron)

A beam of light fell across the grass, hit the bottom of a tree, and illuminated its branches; there, crouching among the budding leaves, was Crookshanks.

``Get out of here!'' (Ron)
Ron roared, and he (Ron) stooped down and seized a stone lying on the grass, but before he (Ron) could do anything else, Crookshanks had vanished with one swish of his (Ron) long ginger tail.

``See?'' (Ron)
Ron said furiously, chucking the stone down again.
``She (Oliver)'s still letting him (Ron) wander about wherever he (Ron) wants -- probably washing down Scabbers with a couple of birds now...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry didn't say anything. He (Harry) took a deep breath as relief seeped through him (Harry); he (Harry) had been sure for a moment that those eyes had belonged to the Grim. They set off for the castle once more. slightly ashamed of his (Grim) moment of panic, Harry didn't say anything to Ron -- nor did he (Harry) look left or right until they had reached the well-lit entrance hall.

Harry went down to breakfast the next morning with the rest of the boys in his (Harry) dormitory, all of whom seemed to think the Firebolt deserved a sort of guard of honor. As Harry entered the Great Hall, heads turned in the direction of the Firebolt, and there was a good deal of excited muttering. Harry saw, with enormous satisfaction, that the Slytherin team were all looking thunderstruck.

``Did you see his (Ron) face?'' (Ron)
said Ron gleefully, looking back at Malfay.
``He (Ron) can't believe it! This is brilliant!'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)

Wood, too, was basking in the reflected glory of the Firebolt.

``Put it here, Harry,'' (he)
he (Ron) said, laying the broom in the middle of the table and carefully turning it so that its name faced upward. People from the Ravenclaw and Hufflepuff tables were soon coming over to look. Cedric Diggory came over to congratulate Harry on having acquired such a superb replacement for his (Harry) Nimbus, and Percy's Ravenclaw girlfriend, Penelope Clearwater, asked if she (Clearwater) could actually hold the Firebolt.

``Now, now, Penny, no sabotage!'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
said Percy heartily as she (Clearwater) examined the Firebolt closely.
``Penelope and I have got a bet on,'' (he)
he (Percy) told the team.
``Ten Galleons on the outcome of the match!'' (Penelope/Penelope Clearwater)

Penelope put the Firebolt down again, thanked Harry, and went back to her (Penelope) table.

``Harry -- make sure you win,'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
said Percy, in an urgent whisper.
``I haven't got ten Galleons. Yes, I'm coming, Penny!'' (her)
And-he bustled off to join her (Penelope) in a piece of toast.

``Sure you can manage that broom, Potter?'' (unknown)
said a cold, drawling voice.

Draco Malfoy had arrived for a closer look, Crabbe and Coyle right behind him (Coyle).

``Yeah, reckon so,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry casually.

``Got plenty of special features, hasn't it?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy, eyes glittering maliciously.
``Shame it doesn't come with a parachute -- in case you get too near a dementor.'' (Crabbe)

Crabbe and Goyle sniggered.

``Pity you can't attach an extra arm to yours, Malfoy,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
``Then it could catch the Snitch for you.'' (Gryffindor)

The Gryffindor team laughed loudly. Malfoy's pale eyes narrowed, and he (Harry) stalked away. They watched him (Harry) rejoin the rest of the Slytherin team, who put their heads together, no doubt asking Malfoy whether Harry's broom really was a Firebolt.

At a quarter to eleven, the Gryffindor team set off for the locker rooms. The weather couldn't have been more different from their match against Hufflepuff. It was a clear, cool day with a very light breeze; there would be no visibility problems this time, and Harry, though nervous, was starting to feel the excitement only a Quidditch match could bring. They could hear the rest of the school moving into the stadium beyond. Harry took off his (Harry) black school robes, removed his (Harry) wand from his (Harry) pocket, and stuck it inside the T-shirt he (Harry) was going to wear under his (Harry) Quidditch robes. He (Harry) only hoped he (Harry) wouldn't need it. He (Harry) wondered suddenly whether Professor Lupin was in the crowd, watching.

``You know what we've got to do,'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
said Wood as they prepared to leave the locker rooms.
``If we lose this match, we're out of the running. just -- just fly like you did in practice yesterday, and we'll be okay!'' (unknown)

They walked out onto the field to tumultuous applause. The Ravenclaw team, dressed in blue, were already standing in the middle of the field. Their Seeker, Cho Chang, was the only girl on their team. She (girl) was shorter than Harry by about a head, and Harry couldn't help noticing, nervous as he (Harry) was, that she (girl) was extremely pretty. She (girl) smiled at Harry as the teams faced each other behind their captains, and he (Harry) felt a slight lurch in the region of his (Harry) stomach that he (Harry) didn't think had anything to do with nerves.

``Wood, Davies, shake hands,'' (Madam Hooch)
Madam Hooch said briskly, and Wood shook hands with the Ravenclaw Captain.

``Mount your brooms... on my whistle... three -- two -- one --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry kicked off into the air and the Firebolt zoomed higher and faster than any other broom; he (Harry) soared around the stadium and began squinting around for the Snitch, listening all the while to the commentary, which was being provided by the Weasley twins' friend Lee Jordan.

``They're off, and the big excitement this match is the Firebolt that Harry Potter is flying for Gryffindor. According to Which Broomstick, the Firebolt's going to be the broom of choice for the national teams at this year's World Championship --'' (unknown)

``Jordan, would you mind telling us what's going on in the match?'' (Professor)
interrupted Professor McGonagall's voice.

``Right you are, Professor -- just giving a bit of background information -- the Firebolt, incidentally, has a built-in auto-brake and --'' (unknown)

``Jordan!'' (unknown)

``Okay, okay, Gryffindor in possession, Katie Bell of Gryffindor, heading for goal...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry streaked past Katie in the opposite direction, gazing around for a glint of gold and noticing that Cho Chang was tailing him (Chang) closely. She (Katie) was undoubtedly a very good flier -- she (Katie) kept cutting across him (Chang), forcing him (Chang) to change direction.

``Show her (Bell) your acceleration, Harry!'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
Fred yelled as he (Fred) whooshed past in pursuit of a Bludger that was aiming for Alicia.

Harry urged the Firebolt forward as they rounded the Ravenclaw goal posts and Cho fell behind. Just as Katie succeeded in scoring the first goal of the match, and the Gryffindor end of the field went wild, he (Cho) saw it -- the Snitch was close to the ground, flitting near one of the barriers.

Harry dived; Cho saw what he (Harry) was doing and tore after him (Harry) -- Harry was speeding up, excitement flooding him (Harry); dives were his (Harry) speciality, he (Harry) was ten feet away --

Then a Bludger, hit by one of the Ravenclaw Beaters, came pelting out of nowhere; Harry veered off course, avoiding it by an inch, and in those few, crucial seconds, the Snitch had vanished.

There was a great

``Ooooooh'' (Gryffindor)
of disappointment from the Gryffindor supporters, but much applause for their Beater from the Ravenclaw end. George Weasley vented his (Weasley) feelings by hitting the second Bludger directly at the offending Beater, who was forced to roll right over in midair to avoid it.

``Gryffindor leads by eighty points to zero, and look at that Firebolt go! Potter's really putting it through its paces now, see it turn -- Chang's Comet is just no match for it, the Firebolt's precision- balance is really noticeable in these long --'' (unknown)

``JORDAN! ARE YOU BEING PAID TO ADVERTISE FIREBOLTS? GET ON WITH THE COMMENTARY!'' (Ravenclaw)

Ravenclaw was pulling back; they had now scored three goals, which put Gryffindor only fifty points ahead -- if Cho got the Snitch before him (Cho), Ravenclaw would win. Harry dropped lower, narrowly avoiding a Ravenclaw Chaser, scanning the field frantically -- a glint of gold, a flutter of tiny wings -- the Snitch was circling the Gryffindor goal post --

Harry accelerated, eyes fixed on the speck of gold ahead -- but just then, Cho appeared out of thin air, blocking him (Harry) --

``HARRY, THIS IS NO TIME TO BE A GENTLEMAN!'' (him)
Wood roared as Harry swerved to avoid a collision.
``KNOCK HER OFF HER BROOM IF YOU HAVE TO!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry turned and caught sight of Cho; she (Harry) was grinning. The Snitch had vanished again. Harry turned his (Harry) Firebolt upward and was soon twenty feet above the game. Out of the corner of his (Harry) eye, he (Harry) saw Cho following him (Cho)... She (Harry)'d decided to mark him (Cho) rather than search for the Snitch herself... All right, then... if she (Harry) wanted to tail him (Cho), she (Harry)'d have to take the consequences...

He (Cho) dived again, and Cho, thinking he (Cho)'d seen the Snitch, tried to follow; Harry pulled out of the dive very sharply; she (Harry) hurtled downward; he (Harry) rose fast as a bullet once more, and then saw it, for the third time -- the Snitch was glittering way above the field at the Ravenclaw end.

He (Harry) accelerated; so, many feet below, did Cho. He (Cho) was winning, gaining on the Snitch with every second -- then --

``Oh!'' (He)
screamed Cho, pointing.

Distracted, Harry looked down.

Three dementors, three tall, black, hooded dementors, were looking up at him (Harry).

He (Harry) didn't stop to think. Plunging a hand down the neck of his (Harry) robes, he (Harry) whipped out his (Harry) wand and roared,

``Expecto patronum!'' (he)

Something silver-white, something enormous, erupted from the end of his (Harry) wand. He (Harry) knew it had shot directly at the dementors but didn't pause to watch; his (Harry) mind still miraculously clear, he (Harry) looked ahead -- he (Harry) was nearly there. He (Harry) stretched out the hand still grasping his (Harry) wand and just managed to close his (Harry) fingers over the small, struggling Snitch.

Madam Hooch's whistle sounded. Harry turned around in midair and saw six scarlet blurs bearing down on him (Harry); next moment, the whole team was hugging him (Harry) so hard he (Harry) was nearly pulled off his (Harry) broom. Down below he (Harry) could hear the roars of the Gryffindors in the crowd.

``That's my boy!'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
Wood kept yelling. Alicia, Angelina, and Katie had all kissed Harry; Fred had him (Harry) in a grip so tight Harry felt as though his (Harry) head would come off In complete disarray, the team managed to make its way back to the ground. Harry got off his (Harry) broom and looked up to see a gaggle of Gryffindor supporters sprinting onto the field, Ron in the lead. Before he (Harry) knew it, he (Harry) had been engulfed by the cheering crowd.

``Yes!'' (Ron)
Ron yelled, yanking Harry's arm into the air.
``Yes! Yes!'' (unknown)

``Well done, Harry!'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
said Percy, looking delighted.
``Ten Galleons to me! Must find Penelope, excuse me --'' (unknown)

``Good for you, Harry!'' (Seamus Finnigan/Seamus)
roared Seamus Finnigan.

``Ruddy brilliant!'' (Hagrid)
boomed Hagrid over the heads of the milling Gryffindors.

``That was quite some Patronus,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said a voice in Harry's ear.

Harry turned around to see Professor Lupin, who looked both shaken and pleased.

``The dementors didn't affect me at all!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said excitedly.
``I didn't feel a thing!'' (unknown)

``That would be because they -- er -- weren't dementors,'' (Professor)
said Professor Lupin.
``Come and see -- '' (He)

He (Harry) led Harry out of the crowd until they were able to see the edge of the field.

``You gave Mr. Malfoy quite a fright,'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin.

Harry stared. Lying in a crumpled heap on the ground were Malfoy, Crabbe, Goyle, and Marcus Flint, the Slytherin team Captain, all struggling to remove themselves from long, black, hooded robes. It looked as though Malfoy had been standing on Goyle's shoulders. Standing over them, with an expression of the utmost fury on her (them) face, was Professor McGonagall.

``An unworthy trick!'' (she)
she (them) was shouting.
``A low and cowardly attempt to sabotage the Gryffindor Seeker! Detention for all of you, and fifty points from Slytherin! I shall be speaking to Professor Dumbledore about this, make no mistake! Ah, here he (Professor) comes now!'' (Gryffindor)

If anything could have set the seal on Gryffindor's victory, it was this. Ron, who had fought his (Ron) way through to Harry's side, doubled up with laughter as they watched Malfoy fighting to extricate himself from the robe, Goyle's head still stuck inside it.

``Come on, Harry!'' (George/George Weasley/Weasley)
said George, fighting his (George) way over.
``Party! Gryffindor common room, now!'' (unknown)

``Right,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, and feeling happier than he (Harry) had in ages, he (Harry) and the rest of the team led the way, still in their scarlet robes, out of the stadium and back up to the castle.

It felt as though they had already won the Quidditch Cup; the party went on all day and well into the night. Fred and George Weasley disappeared for a couple of hours and returned with armfuls of bottles of butterbeer, pumpkin fizz, and several bags full of Honeydukes sweets.

``How did you do that?'' (Johnson/Angelina Johnson)
squealed Angelina Johnson as George started throwing Peppermint Toads into the crowd.

``With a little help from Moony, Wormtail, Padfoot, and Prongs,'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
Fred muttered in Harry's ear.

Only one person wasn't joining in the festivities. Hermione, incredibly, was sitting in a corner, attempting to read an enormous book entitled Home Life and Social Habits of British Muggles. Harry broke away from the table where Fred and George had started juggling butterbeer bottles and went over to her (Hermione).

``Did you even come to the match?'' (he)
he (Harry) asked her (Hermione).

``Of course I did,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione in a strangely high-pitched voice, not looking up.
``And I'm very glad we won, and I think you did really well, but I need to read this by Monday.'' (unknown)

``Come on, Hermione, come and have some food,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said, looking over at Ron and wondering whether he (Harry) was in a good enough mood to bury the hatchet.

``I can't, Harry. I've still got four hundred and twenty-two pages to read!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione, now sounding slightly hysterical.
``Anyway...'' (She)
She (Hermione) glanced over at Ron too.
``He (Harry) doesn't want me to join in.'' (Ron)

There was no arguing with this, as Ron chose that moment to say loudly,

``If Scabbers hadn't just been eaten, he (Harry) could have had some of those Fudge Flies. He (Harry) used to really like them --'' (Ron)

Hermione burst into tears. Before Harry could say or do anything, she (Hermione) tucked the enormous book under her (Hermione) arm, and, still sobbing, ran toward the staircase to the girls' dormitories and out of sight.

``Can't you give her (Hermione) a break?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry asked Ron quietly.

``No,'' (Ron)
said Ron flatly.
``If she (Hermione) just acted like she (Hermione) was sorry -- but she (Hermione)'ll never admit she (Hermione)'s wrong, Hermione. She (Hermione)'s still acting like Scabbers has gone on vacation or something.'' (Gryffindor)

The Gryffindor party ended only when Professor McGonagall turned up in her (Hermione) tartan dressing gown and hair net at one in the morning, to insist that they all go to bed. Harry and Ron climbed the stairs to their dormitory, still discussing the match. At last, exhausted, Harry climbed into bed, twitched the hangings of his (Harry) four-poster shut to block out a ray of moonlight, lay back, and felt himself almost instantly drifting off to sleep...

He (Harry) had a very strange dream. He (Harry) was walking through a forest, his (Harry) Firebolt over his (Harry) shoulder, following something silvery-white. It was winding its way through the trees ahead, and he (Harry) could only catch glimpses of it between the leaves. Anxious to catch up with it, he (Harry) sped up, but as he (Harry) moved faster, so did his (Harry) quarry. Harry broke into a run, and ahead he (Harry) heard hooves gathering speed. Now he (Harry) was running flat out, and ahead he (Harry) could hear galloping. Then he (Harry) turned a corner into a clearing and -

``AAARRGGHH! NOOO!'' (he)

Harry woke as suddenly as though he (Harry)'d been hit in the face. Disoriented in the total darkness, he (Harry) fumbled with his (Harry) hangings, he (Harry) could hear movements around him (Harry), and Seamus Finnigan's voice from the other side of the room:

``What's going on?'' (Seamus Finnigan/Seamus)

Harry thought he (Harry) heard the dormitory door slam. At last finding the divide in his (Harry) curtains, he (Harry) ripped them back, and at the same moment, Dean Thomas lit his (Thomas) lamp.

Ron was sitting up in bed, the hangings torn from one side, a look of utmost terror on his (Ron) face.

``Black! Sirius Black! With a knife!'' (unknown)

``What?'' (unknown)

``Here! Just now! Slashed the curtains! Woke me up!'' (unknown)

``You sure you weren't dreaming, Ron?'' (Dean Thomas/Dean)
said Dean.

``Look at the curtains! I tell you, he (Ron) was here!'' (unknown)

They all scrambled out of bed; Harry reached the dormitory door first, and they sprinted back down the staircase. Doors opened behind them, and sleepy voices called after them.

``Who shouted?'' (unknown)

``What're you doing?'' (the party)

The common room was lit with the glow of the dying fire, still littered with the debris from the party. It was deserted.

``Are you sure you weren't dreaming, Ron?'' (unknown)

``I'm telling you, I saw him (Ron)!'' (unknown)

``What's all the noise?'' (unknown)

``Professor McGonagall told us to go to bed!'' (the girls)

A few of the girls had come down their staircase, pulling or, dressing gowns and yawning. Boys, too, were reappearing.

``Excellent, are we carrying on?'' (Fred/Fred Weasley)
said Fred Weasley brightly.

``Everyone back upstairs!'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
said Percy, hurrying into the common room and pinning his (Percy) Head Boy badge to his (Percy) pajamas as he (Percy) spoke.

``Perce -- Sirius Black!'' (Ron)
said Ron faintly.
``In our dormitory! With a knife! Woke me up!'' (unknown)

The common room went very still.

``Nonsense!'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
said Percy, looking startled.
``You had too much to eat, Ron -- had a nightmare --'' (Professor)

``I'm telling you --'' (Professor)

``Now, really, enough's enough!'' (Professor)

Professor McGonagall was back. She (Percy) slammed the portrait behind her (Percy) as she (Percy) entered the common room and stared furiously around.

``I am delighted that Gryffindor won the match, but this is getting ridiculous! Percy, I expected better of you!'' (unknown)

``I certainly didn't authorize this, Professor!'' (Percy/Weasley/Percy Weasley)
said Percy, puffing himself up indignantly.
``I was just telling them all to get back to bed! My brother Ron here had a nightmare --'' (unknown)

``IT WASN``T A NIGHTMARE!'' Ron yelled.

``PROFESSOR, I WOKE UP, AND SIRIUS BLACK WAS STANDING OVER ME, HOLDING A KNIFE!'' (Professor)

Professor McGonagall stared at him (Ron).

``Don't be ridiculous, Weasley, how could he (Weasley) possibly have gotten through the portrait hole?'' (unknown)

``Ask him (Weasley)!'' (Ron)
said Ron, pointing a shaking finger at the back of Sir Cadogan's picture.
``Ask him (Weasley) if he (Weasley) saw --'' (Ron)

Glaring suspiciously at Ron, Professor McGonagall pushed the Portrait back open and went outside. The whole common room listened with bated breath.

``Sir Cadogan, did you just let a man enter Gryffindor Tower?'' (unknown)
``Certainly, good lady!'' (Cadogan)
cried Sir Cadogan.

There was a stunned silence, both inside and outside the common room.

``You -- you did?'' (Professor)
said Professor McGonagall.
``But -- but the password!'' (unknown)

``He (Weasley) had 'em!'' (Cadogan)
said Sir Cadogan proudly.
``Had the whole week's, my lady! Read 'em off a little piece of paper!'' (Professor)

Professor McGonagall pulled herself back through the portrait hole to face the stunned crowd. She (Ron) was white as chalk.

``Which person,'' (she)
she (Ron) said, her (Ron) voice shaking,
``which abysmally foolish person wrote down this week's passwords and left them lying around?'' (she)

There was utter silence, broken by the smallest of terrified squeaks. Neville Longbottom, trembling from head to fluffy slippered toes, raised his (Longbottom) hand slowly into the air.

CHAPTER FOURTEEN

SNAPE``S GRUDGE

No one in Gryffindor Tower slept that night. They knew that the castle was being searched again, and the whole House stayed awake in the common room, waiting to hear whether Black had been caught. Professor McGonagall came back at dawn, to tell them that he (Professor) had again escaped.

Throughout the day, everywhere they went they saw signs of tighter security; Professor Flitwick could be seen teaching the front doors to recognize a large picture of Sirius Black; Filch was suddenly bustling up and down the corridors, boarding up everything from tiny cracks in the walls to mouse holes. Sir Cadogan had been fired. His (Black) portrait had been taken back to its lonely landing on the seventh floor, and the Fat Lady was back. She (Lady) had been expertly restored, but was still extremely nervous, and had agreed to return to her (Lady) job only on condition that she (Lady) was given extra protection. A bunch of surly security trolls had been hired to guard her (Lady). They paced the corridor in a menacing group, talking in grunts and comparing the size of their clubs.

Harry couldn't help noticing that the statue of the one-eyed witch on the third floor remained unguarded and unblocked. It seemed that Fred and George had been right in thinking that they -- and now Harry, Ron, and Hermione -- were the only ones who knew about the hidden passageway within it.

``D'you reckon we should tell someone?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry asked Ron.

``We know he (Ron)'s not coming in through Honeyduke's,'' (Ron)
said Ron dismissively.
``We'd've heard if the shop had been broken into.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry was glad Ron took this view. If the one-eyed witch was boarded up too, he (Ron) would never be able to go into Hogsmeade again.

Ron had become an instant celebrity. For the first time in his (Ron) life, people were paying more attention to him (Ron) than to Harry, and it was clear that Ron was rather enjoying the experience. Though still severely shaken by the night's events, he (Ron) was happy to tell anyone who asked what had happened, with a wealth of detail.

''... I was asleep, and I heard this ripping noise, and I thought it was in my dream, you know? But then there was this draft... I woke up and one side of the hangings on my bed had been pulled down... I rolled over... and I saw him (Ron) standing over me... like a skeleton, with loads of filthy hair ... holding this great long knife, must've been twelve inches... and he (Ron) looked at me, and I looked at him (Ron), and then I yelled, and he (Ron) scampered.

``Why, though?'' (Ron)
Ron added to Harry as the group of secondyear girls who had been listening to his (Ron) chilling tale departed.
``Why did he (Ron) run?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry had been wondering the same thing. Why had Black, having got the wrong bed, not silenced Ron and proceeded to Harry? Black had proved twelve years ago that he (Black) didn't mind murdering innocent people, and this time he (Black) had been facing five unarmed boys, four of whom were asleep.

``He (Ron) must've known he (Ron)'d have a job getting back out of the castle once you'd yelled and woken people up,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry thoughtfully.
``He (Ron)'d've had to kill the whole House to get back through the portrait hole... then he (Ron) would' ve met the teachers...'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)

Neville was in total disgrace. Professor McGonagall was so furious with him (Harry) she (Harry) had banned him (Harry) from all future Hogsmeade visits, given him (Harry) a detention, and forbidden anyone to give him (Harry) the password into the tower. Poor Neville was forced to wait. outside the common room every night for somebody to let him (Neville) in, while the security trolls leered unpleasantly at him (Neville). None of these punishments, however, came close to matching the one his (Neville) grandmother had in store for him (Neville). Two days after Black's break-in, she (grandmother) sent Neville the very worst thing a Hogwarts student could receive over breakfast -- a Howler.

The school owls swooped into the Great Hall carrying the mail as usual, and Neville choked as a huge barn owl landed in front of him (Neville), a scarlet envelope clutched in its beak. Harry and Ron, who were sitting opposite him (Harry), recognized the letter as a Howler at once -- Ron had got one from his (Ron) mother the year before.

``Run for it, Neville,'' (Ron)
Ron advised.

Neville didn't need telling twice. He (Neville) seized the envelope, and holding it before him (Neville) like a bomb, sprinted out of the hall, while the Slytherin table exploded with laughter at the sight of him (Neville). They heard the Howler go off in the entrance hall -- Neville's grandmother's voice, magically magnified to a hundred times its Usual volume, shrieking about how he (Neville) had brought shame on the whole family.

Harry was too busy feeling sorry for Neville to notice immediately that he (Neville) had a letter too. Hedwig got his (Neville) attention by nipping him (Neville) sharply on the wrist.

``Ouch! Oh -- thanks, Hedwig.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry tore open the envelope while Hedwig helped herself to some of Neville's cornflakes. The note inside said:

Dear Harry and Ron, How Abut having tea with me this afternoon `round six? I'll come collect you from the castle. WAIT FOR ME IN THE ENTRANCE HALL; YOU``RE NOT ALLOWED OUT ON YOUR OWN. Cheers, Hagrid

``He (Neville) probably wants to hear all about Black!'' (Ron)
said Ron.

So at six o'clock that afternoon, Harry and Ron left Gryffindor Tower, passed the security trolls at a run, and headed down to the entrance hall.

Hagrid was already waiting for them.

``All right, Hagrid!'' (Ron)
said Ron.
``S'pose you want to hear about Saturday night, do you?'' (unknown)

``I've already heard all abou' it,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, opening the front doors and leading them outside.

``Oh,'' (Ron)
said Ron, looking slightly put out.

The first thing they saw on entering Hagrid's cabin was Buckbeak, who was stretched out on top of Hagrid's patchwork quilt, his (Ron) enormous wings folded tight to his (Ron) body, enjoying a large plate of dead ferrets. Averting his (Ron) eyes from this unpleasant sight, Harry saw a gigantic, hairy brown suit and a very horrible yellow-and-orange tie hanging from the top of Hagrid's wardrobe door.

``What are they for, Hagrid?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``Buckbeaks case against the Committee fer the Disposal o' Dangerous Creatures,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid.
``This Friday. Him (Black) an' me'll be goin' down ter London together. I've booked two beds on the Knight Bus...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry felt a nasty pang of guilt. He (Harry) had completely forgotten that Buckbeak's trial was so near, and judging by the uneasy look on Ron's face, he (Ron) had too. They had also forgotten their promise about helping him (Ron) prepare Buckbeak's defense; the arrival of the Firebolt had driven it clean out of their minds.

Hagrid poured them tea and offered them a plate of Bath buns but they knew better than to accept; they had had too much experience with Hagrid's cooking.

I got somethin' ter discuss with you two,'' said Hagrid, sitting himself between them and looking uncharacteristically serious.

``What?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.

``Hermione,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid.

``What about her (Hermione)?'' (Ron)
said Ron.

``She (Hermione)'s in a righ' state, that's what. She (Hermione)'s bin comin' down ter visit me a lot since Chris`mas. Bin feelin' lonely. Firs' yeh weren' talking to her (Hermione) because o' the Firebolt, now yer not talkin' to her (Hermione) because her (Hermione) cat --'' (Ron)

''-- ate Scabbers!'' (Ron)
Ron interjected angrily.

``Because her (Hermione) cat acted like all cats do,'' (Hagrid)
Hagrid continued doggedly.
``She (Hermione)'s cried a fair few times, yeh know. Goin' through a rough time at the moment. Bitten off more'n she (Hermione) can chew, if yeh ask me, all the work she (Hermione)'s tryin' ter do. Still found time ter help me with Buckbeak's case, mind... She (Hermione)'s found some really good stuff fer me... reckon he (Goin)'ll stand a good chance now...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``Hagrid, we should've helped as well -- sorry --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry began awkwardly.

``I'm not blamin' yeh!'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid, waving Harry's apology aside.
``Gawd knows yeh've had enough ter be gettin' on with. I've seen yeh practicin' Quidditch ev'ry hour o' the day an' night -- but I gotta tell yeh, I thought you two'd value yer friend more'n broomsticks or rats. Tha's all.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry and Ron exchanged uncomfortable looks.

``Really upset, she (I) was, when Black nearly stabbed yeh, Ron. She (I)'s got her (I) heart in the right place, Hermione has, an' you two not talkin' to her (Hermione) --'' (Ron)

``If she (Hermione)'d just get rid of that cat, I'd speak to her (Hermione) again!'' (Ron)
Ron said angrily.
``But she (Hermione)'s still sticking up for it! It's a maniac, and she (Hermione) won't hear a word against it!'' (unknown)

``Ah, well, people can be a bit stupid abou' their pets,'' (Hagrid)
said Hagrid wisely. Behind him (Ron), Buckbeak spat a few ferret bones onto Hagrid's pillow.

They spent the rest of their visit discussing Gryffindor's improved chances for the Quidditch Cup. At nine o'clock, Hagrid walked them back up to the castle.

A large group of people was bunched around the bulletin board when they returned to the common room.

``Hogsmeade, next weekend!'' (Ron)
said Ron, craning over the heads to read the new notice.
``What d'you reckon?'' (he)
he (Ron) added quietly to Harry as they went to sit down.

``Well, Filch hasn't done anything about the passage into Honeydukes...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said, even more quietly.

``Harry!'' (unknown)
said a voice in his (Harry) right ear. Harry started and looked around at Hermione, who was sitting at the table right behind them and clearing a space in the wall of books that had been hiding her (Hermione).

``Harry, if you go into Hogsmeade again... I'll tell Professor McGonagall about that map!'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
said Hermione.

``Can you hear someone talking, Harry?'' (Ron)
growled Ron, not looking at Hermione.

``Ron, how can you let him (Ron) go with you? After what Sirius Black nearly did to you! I mean it, I'll tell --'' (unknown)

``So now you're trying to get Harry expelled!'' (Ron)
said Ron furiously.
``Haven't you done enough damage this year?'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)

Hermione opened her (Hermione) mouth to respond, but with a soft hiss, Crookshanks leapt onto her (Hermione) lap. Hermione took one frightened look at the expression on Ron's face, gathered up Crookshanks, and hurried away toward the girls' dormitories.

``So how about it?'' (Ron)
Ron said to Harry as though there had been no interruption.
``Come on, last time we went you didn't see anything. You haven't even been inside Zonko's yet!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry looked around to check that Hermione was well out of earshot.

``Okay,'' (he)
he (Harry) said.
``But I'm taking the Invisibility Cloak this time.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

On Saturday morning, Harry packed his (Harry) Invisibility Cloak in his (Harry) bag, slipped the Marauder's Map into his (Harry) pocket, and went down to breakfast with everyone else. Hermione kept shooting suspicious looks down the table at him (Harry), but he (Harry) avoided her (Hermione) eye and was careful to let her (Hermione) see him (Harry) walking back up the marble staircase in the entrance hall as everybody else proceeded to the front doors.

''`Bye!'' (everybody)
Harry called to Ron.
``See you when you get back!'' (Ron)

Ron grinned and winked.

Harry hurried up to the third floor, slipping the Marauder's Map out of his (Harry) pocket as he (Harry) went. Crouching behind the one-eyed witch, he (Harry) smoothed it out. A tiny dot was moving in his (Harry) direction. Harry squinted at it. The minuscule writing next to it read Neville Longbottom.

Harry quickly pulled out his (Harry) wand, muttered,

``Dissendium!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
and shoved his (Harry) bag into the statue, but before he (Harry) could climb in himself, Neville came around the corner.

``Harry! I forgot you weren't going to Hogsmeade either!'' (unknown)

``Hi, Neville,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, moving swiftly away from the statue and pushing the map back into his (Harry) pocket.
``What are you up to?'' (unknown)

``Nothing,'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
shrugged Neville.
``Want a game of Exploding Snap?'' (unknown)

``Er -- not now -- I was going to go to the library and do that vampire essay for Lupin --'' (unknown)

``I'll come with you!'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville brightly. I haven't done it either!''

``Er -- hang on -- yeah, I forgot, I finished it last night!'' (unknown)

``Great, you can help me!'' (Neville/Neville Longbottom/Longbottom)
said Neville, his (Neville) round face anxious.
``I don't understand that thing about the garlic at all -- do they have to eat it, or --'' (He)

He (Neville) broke off with a small gasp, looking over Harry's shoulder.

It was Snape. Neville took a quick step behind Harry.

``And what are you two doing here?'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape, coming to a halt and looking from one to the other.
``An odd place to meet --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

To Harry's immense disquiet, Snape's black eyes flicked to the doorways on either side of them, and then to the one-eyed witch.

``We're not -- meeting here,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
``We just -- met here.'' (unknown)

``Indeed?'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape.
``You have a habit of turning up in unexpected places, Potter, and you are very rarely there for no good reason... I suggest the pair of you return to Gryffindor Tower, where you belong.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry and Neville set off without another word. As they turned the corner, Harry looked back. Snape was running one of his (Harry) hands over the one-eyed witch's head, examining it closely.

Harry managed to shake Neville off at the Fat Lady by telling him (Harry) the password, then pretending he (Harry)'d left his (Harry) vampire essay in the library and doubling back. Once out of sight of the security trolls, he (Harry) pulled out the map again and held it close to his (Harry) nose.

The third floor corridor seemed to be deserted. Harry scanned the map carefully and saw, with a leap of relief, that the tiny dot labeled Severus Snape was now back in its office.

He (Snape) sprinted back to the one-eyed witch, opened her (witch) hump, heaved himself inside, and slid down to meet his (Snape) bag at the bottom of the stone chute. He (Snape) wiped the Marauder's Map blank again, then set off at a run.

Harry, completely hidden beneath the Invisibility Cloak, emerged into the sunlight outside Honeydukes and prodded Ron in the back.

It's me,'' he (Harry) muttered.

``What kept you?'' (Ron)
Ron hissed.

``Snape was hanging around.'' (unknown)

They set off up the High Street.

``Where are you?'' (Ron)
Ron kept muttering out of the corner of his (Ron) mouth.
``Are you still there? This feels weird...'' (Ron)

They went to the post office; Ron pretended to be checking the price of an owl to Bill in Egypt so that Harry could have a good look around. The owls sat hooting softly down at him (Harry), at least three hundred of them; from Great Grays right down to tiny little Scops owls -LRB-

``Local Deliveries Only'' (Great Grays)
-RRB-, which were so small they could have sat in the palm of Harry's hand.

Then they visited Zonko's, which was so packed with students Harry had to exercise great care not to tread on anyone and cause a panic. There were jokes and tricks to fulfill even Fred's and George's wildest dreams; Harry gave Ron whispered orders and passed him (Harry) some gold from under the cloak. They left Zonko's with their money bags considerably lighter than they had been on entering, but their pockets bulging with Dungbombs, Hiccup Sweets, Frog Spawn Soap, and a Nose-Biting Teacup apiece.

The day was fine and breezy, and neither of them felt like staying indoors, so they walked past the Three Broomsticks and climbed a slope to visit the Shrieking Shack, the most haunted dwelling in Britain. It stood a little way above the rest of the village, and even in daylight was slightly creepy, with its boarded windows and dank overgrown garden.

``Even the Hogwarts ghosts avoid it,'' (Ron)
said Ron as they leaned on the fence, looking up at it.
``I asked Nearly Headless Nick... he (Nick) says he (Nick)'s heard a very rough crowd lives here. No one can get in. Fred and George tried, obviously, but all the entrances are sealed shut...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry, feeling hot from their climb, was just considering taking off the cloak for a few minutes when they heard voices nearby. Someone was climbing toward the house from the other side of the hill; moments later, Malfoy had appeared, followed closely by Crabbe and Goyle. Malfoy was speaking.

''... should have an owl from Father any time now. He (Father) had to go to the hearing to tell them about my arm... about how I couldn't use it for three months...'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

Crabbe and Goyle sniggered.

``I really wish I could hear that great hairy moron trying to defend himself...

``There's no `arm in `im, `onest that hippogriff's as good as dead --'' (Malfoy)

Malfoy suddenly caught sight of Ron. His (Ron) pale face split in a malevolent grin.

``What are you doing, Weasley?'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)

Malfoy looked up at the crumbling house behind Ron.

``Suppose You'd love to live here, wouldn't you, Weasley? Dreaming about having your own bedroom? I heard your family all sleep in one room -- is that true?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry seized the back of Ron's robes to stop him (Harry) from leaping on Malfoy.

``Leave him (Weasley) to me,'' (he)
he (Malfoy) hissed in Ron's ear.

The opportunity was too perfect to miss. Harry crept silently around behind Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle, bent down, and scooped a large handful of mud out of the path.

``We were just discussing your friend Hagrid,'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
Malfoy said to Ron. ``Just trying to imagine what he (friend)'s saying to the Committee for the Disposal of Dangerous Creatures. D'you think he (friend)'ll cry when they cut off his (friend) hippogriff's

SPLAT.

Malfoy's head jerked forward as the mud hit him (Malfoy); his (Malfoy) silverblond hair was suddenly dripping in muck.

``What the --?'' (Ron)

Ron had to hold onto the fence to keep himself standing, he (Ron) was laughing so hard. Malfoy, Crabbe, and Goyle spun stupidly on the spot, staring wildly around, Malfoy trying to wipe his (Malfoy) hair clean.

``What was that?

``Who did that?'' (unknown)

``Very haunted up here, isn't it?'' (Ron)
said Ron, with the air of one commenting on the weather.

Crabbe and Goyle were looking scared. Their bulging muscles were no use against ghosts. Malfoy was staring madly around at the deserted landscape.

Harry sneaked along the path, where a particularly sloppy puddle yielded some foul-smelling, green sludge.

SPLATTER.

Crabbe and Goyle caught some this time. Goyle hopped furiously on the spot, trying to rub it out of his (Crabbe) small, dull eyes.

``It came from over there!'' (Malfoy/Draco Malfoy/Draco)
said Malfoy, wiping his (Malfoy) face, and staring at a spot some six feet to the left of Harry.

Crabbe blundered forward, his (Crabbe) long arms outstretched like a zombie. Harry dodged around him (Harry), picked up a stick, and lobbed it at Crabbe's back. Harry doubled up with silent laughter as Crabbe did a kind of pirouette in midair, trying to see who had thrown it. As Ron was the only person Crabbe could see, it was Ron he (Ron) started toward, but Harry stuck out his (Harry) leg. Crabbe stumbled -- and his (Crabbe) huge, flat foot caught the hem of Harry's cloak. Harry felt a great tug, then the cloak slid off his (Harry) face.

For a split second, Malfoy stared at him (Malfoy).

``AAARGH!'' (he)
he (Malfoy) yelled, pointing at Harry's head. Then he (Harry) turned tail and ran, at breakneck speed, back down the hill, Crabbe and Goyle behind him (Crabbe).

Harry tugged the cloak up again, but the damage was done.

``Harry!'' (Ron)
Ron said, stumbling forward and staring hopelessly at the point where Harry had disappeared,
``you'd better run for it! If Malfoy tells anyone -- you'd better get back to the castle, quick --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
``See you later,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, and without another word, he (Harry) tore back down the path toward Hogsmeade.

Would Malfoy believe what he (Malfoy) had seen? Would anyone believe

Malfoy? Nobody knew about the Invisibility Cloak -- nobody except Dumbledore. Harry's stomach turned over -- Dumbledore would know exactly what had happened, if Malfoy said any- thing --

Back into Honeydukes, back down the cellar steps, across the stone floor, through the trapdoor -- Harry pulled off the cloak, tucked it under his (Harry) arm, and ran, flat out, along the passage... Malfoy would get back first... how long would it take him (Malfoy) to find a teacher? Panting, a sharp pain in his (Malfoy) side, Harry didn't slow down until he (Harry) reached the stone slide. He (Harry) would have to leave the cloak where it was, it was too much of a giveaway in case Malfoy had tipped off a teacher -- he (Malfoy) hid it in a shadowy corner, then started to climb, fast as he (Malfoy) could, his (Malfoy) sweaty hands slipping on the sides of the chute. He (Malfoy) reached the inside of the witch's hump, tapped it with his (Malfoy) wand, stuck his (Malfoy) head through, and hoisted himself out; the hump closed, and just as Harry jumped out from behind the statue, he (Harry) heard quick footsteps approaching.

It was Snape. He (Harry) approached Harry at a swift walk, his (Harry) black robes swishing, then stopped in front of him (Harry).

``So,'' (he)
he (Harry) said.

There was a look of surpressed triumph about him (Harry). Harry tried to look innocent, all too aware of his (Harry) sweaty face and his (Harry) muddy hands, which he (Harry) quickly hid in his (Harry) pockets.

``Come with me, Potter,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape.

Harry followed him (Harry) downstairs, trying to wipe his (Harry) hands clean on the inside of his (Harry) robes without Snape noticing. They walked down the stairs to the dungeons and then into Snape's office.

Harry had been in here only once before, and he (Harry) had been in very serious trouble then too. Snape had aquired a few more slimy horrible things in jars since last time, all standing on shelves behind his (Snape) desk, glinting in the firelight and adding to the threatening atmosphere.

``Sit,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape.

Harry sat. Snape, however, remained, standing.

``Mr. Malfoy has just been to see me with a strange story, Potter,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape.

Harry didn't say anything.

``He (Malfoy) tells me that he (Malfoy) was up by the Shrieking Shack when he (Malfoy) ran into Weasley -- apparently alone.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Still, Harry didn't speak.

``Mr. Malfoy states that he (Malfoy) was standing talking to Weasley, when a large amount of mud hit him (Malfoy) in the back of the head. How do you think that could have happened?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry tried to look mildly surprised.

``I don't know, Professor.'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

Snape's eyes were boring into Harry's. It was exactly like trying to stare down a hippogriff. Harry tried hard not to blink.

``Mr. Malfoy then saw an extraordinary apparition. Can you imagine what it might have been, Potter?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, now trying to sound innocently curious.

``It was your head, Potter. Floating in midair.'' (unknown)

There was a long silence.

``Maybe he (Potter)'d better go to Madam Pomfrey,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
``If he (Potter)'s seeing things like --'' (unknown)

``What would your head have been doing in Hogsmeade, Potter?'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape softly.
``Your head is not allowed in Hogsmeade. No part of your body has permission to be in Hogsmeade.'' (unknown)

``I know that,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, striving to keep his (Harry) face free of guilt or fear.
``It sounds like Malfoy's having hallucin --'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

``Malfoy is not having hallucinations,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
snarled Snape, and he (Snape) bent down, a hand on each arm of Harry's chair, so that their faces were a foot apart.
``If your head was in Hogsmeade, so was the rest of you.'' (unknown)

``I've been up in Gryffindor Tower,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry.
``Like you told --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
``Can anyone confirm that?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry didn't say anything. Snape's thin mouth curled into a horrible smile.

``So,'' (he)
he (Harry) said, straightening up again. ``Everyone from the Minister of Magic downward has been trying to keep famous Harry Potter safe from Sirius Black. But famous Harry Potter is a law unto himself Let the ordinary people worry about his (Potter) safety! Famous Harry Potter goes where he (Potter) wants to, with no thought for the consequences.

Harry stayed silent. Snape was trying to provoke him (Harry) into telling the truth. He (Harry) wasn't going to do it. Snape had no proof -- yet.

``How extraordinarily like your father you are, Potter,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
Snape said suddenly, his (Snape) eyes glinting.
``He (Potter) too was exceedingly arrogant. A small amount of talent on the Quidditch field made him (Potter) think he (Potter) was a cut above the rest of us too. Strutting around the place with his (Potter) friends and admirers... The resemblance between you is uncanny.'' (unknown)

``My dad didn't strut,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, before he (Harry) could stop himself.
``And neither do I.'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

``Your father didn't set much store by rules either,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
Snape went on, pressing his (Harry) advantage, his (Harry) thin face full of malice.
``Rules were for lesser mortals, not Quidditch Cup-winners. His (father) head was so swollen --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``SHUT UP!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry was suddenly on his (Harry) feet. Rage such as he (Harry) had not felt since his (Harry) last night in Privet Drive was coursing through him (Harry). He (Harry) didn't care that Snape's face had gone rigid, the black eyes flashing dangerously.

``What did you say to me, Potter?'' (unknown)

``I told you to shut up about my dad!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry yelled. I know the truth, all right? He (Harry) saved your life! Dumbledore told me! You wouldn't even be here if it wasn't for my dad!''

Snape's sallow skin had gone the color of sour milk.

``And did the headmaster tell you the circumstances in which your father saved my life?'' (he)
he (Snape) whispered.
``Or did he (father) consider the details too unpleasant for precious Potter's delicate ears?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry bit his (Harry) lip. He (Harry) didn't know what had happened and didn't want to admit it -- but Snape seemed to have guessed the truth.

I would hate for you to run away with a false idea of your father, Potter,'' he (Potter) said, a terrible grin twisting his (Potter) face.

``Have you been imagining some act of glorious heroism? Then let me correct you -- your saintly father and his (father) friends played a highly amusing joke on me that would have resulted in my death if your father hadn't got cold feet at the last moment. There was nothing brave about what he (father) did. He (father) was saving his (father) own skin as much as mine. Had their joke succeeded, he (father) would have been expelled from Hogwarts.'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

Snape's uneven, yellowish teeth were bared.

``Turn out your pockets, Potter!'' (he)
he (Snape) spat suddenly.

Harry didn't move. There was a pounding in his (Harry) ears.

``Turn out your pockets, or we go straight to the headmaster! Pull them out, Potter!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Cold with dread, Harry slowly pulled out the bag of Zonko's tricks and the Marauder's Map.

Snap picked up the Zonko's bag.

``Ron gave them to me,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, praying he (Harry)'d get a chance to tip Ron off before Snape saw him (Snape).
``He (Ron) -brought them back from Hogsmeade last time --'' (unknown)

``Indeed? And you've been carrying them around ever since? How very touching... and what is this?'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

Snape had picked up the map. Harry tried with all his (Harry) might to keep his (Harry) face impassive.

``Spare bit of parchment,'' (he)
he (Harry) said with a shrug.

Snape turned it over, his (Snape) eyes on Harry.

``Surely you don't need such a very old piece of parchment?'' (he)
he (Harry) said.
``Why don't I just -- throw this away?'' (unknown)

His (Harry) hand moved toward the fire.

``No!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry said quickly.

``So!'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape, his (Snape) long nostrils quivering.
``Is this another treasured gift from Mr. Weasley? Or is it -- something else? A letter, perhaps, written in invisible ink? Or -- instructions to get into Hogsmeade without passing the dementors?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry blinked. Snape's eyes gleamed.

``Let me see, let me see...'' (he)
he (Harry) muttered, taking out his (Harry) wand and smoothing the map out on his (Harry) desk.
``Reveal your secret!'' (he)
he (Harry) said, touching the wand to the parchment.

Nothing happened. Harry clenched his (Harry) hands to stop them from shaking.

``Show yourself!'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
Snape said, tapping the map sharply.

It stayed blank. Harry was taking deep, calming breaths.

``Professor Severus Snape, master of this school, commands you to yield the information you conceal!'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
Snape said, hitting the map with his (Snape) wand.

As though an invisible hand were writing upon it, words appeared on the smooth surface of the map.

Mooney presents his (Mooney) compliments to Professor Snape, and begs him (Snape) to keep his (Snape) abnormally large nose out of other people's business.''

Snape froze. Harry stared, dumbstruck, at the message. But the map didn't stop there. More writing was appearing beneath the first.

``Mr. Prongs agrees with Mr. Moony and would like to add that Professor Snape is an ugle git.'' (unknown)

It would have been very funny if the situation hadn't been so serious. And there was more...

``Mr. Padfoot would like to register his (Snape) astonishment that an idiot like that ever became a professor.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry closed his (Harry) eyes in horror. When he (Harry)'d opened them, the map had had its last word.

``Mr. Wormtail bids Professor Snape good day, and advises him (Snape) to wash his (Snape) hair , the slimeball.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry waited for the blow to fall.

``So...'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape softly.
``We'll see about this...'' (He)

He (Snape) strode across to his (Snape) fire, seized a fistful of glittering powder from a jar on the fireplace, and threw it into the flames.

``Lupin!'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
Snape called into the fire.
``I want a word!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Utterly bewildered, Harry stared at the fire. A large shape had appeared in it, revolving very fast. Seconds later, Professor Lupin was clambering out of the fireplace, brushing ash off his (Professor) shabby robes.

``You called, Severus?'' (Lupin)
said Lupin mildly.

``I certainly did,'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape, his (Snape) face contorted with fury as he (Snape) strode back to his (Snape) desk.
``I have just asked Potter to empty his (Potter) pockets. He (Potter) was carrying this.'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)

Snape pointed at the parchment, on which the words of Messrs. Moony, Wormtail, Padfoot, and Prongs were still shining. An odd, closed expression appeared on Lupin's face.

``Well?'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape.

Lupin continued to stare at the map. Harry had the impression that Lupin was doing some very quick thinking.

``Well?'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape again.
``This parchment is plainly full of Dark Magic. This is supposed to be your area of expertise, Lupin. Where do you imagine Potter got such a thing?'' (Lupin)

Lupin looked up and, by the merest half-glance in Harry's direction, warned him (Harry) not to interrupt.

``Full of Dark Magic?'' (he)
he (Harry) repeated mildly.
``Do you really think so, Severus? It looks to me as though it is merely a piece of parchment that insults anybody who reads it. Childish, but surely not dangerous? I imagine Harry got it from a joke shop --'' (unknown)

``Indeed?'' (Snape/Severus/Severus Snape)
said Snape. His (Snape) jaw had gone rigid with anger.
``You think a joke shop could supply him (Harry) with such a thing? You don't think it more likely that he (Harry) got it directly from the manufacturers?'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry didn't understand what Snape was talking about. Nor, apparently, did Lupin.

``You mean, by Mr. Wormtail or one of these people?'' (he)
he (Snape) said.
``Harry, do you know any of these men?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry quickly.

``You see, Severus?'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, turning back to Snape.
``It looks like a Zonko product to me --'' (Ron)

Right on cue, Ron came bursting into the office. He (Snape) was completely out of breath, and stopped just short of Snape's desk, clutching the stitch in his (Snape) chest and trying to speak.

``I -- gave -- Harry -- that -- stuff,'' (he)
he (Snape) choked.
``Bought -- it... in Zonko's... ages -- ago...'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (Lupin/R. J. Lupin)
said Lupin, clapping his (Snape) hands together and looking around cheerfully.
``That seems to clear that up! Severus, I'll take this back, shall I?'' (He)
He (Snape) folded the map and tucked it inside his (Snape) robes.
``Harry, Ron, come with me, I need a word about my vampire essay -- excuse us, Severus --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry didn't dare look at Snape as they left his (Snape) office. He (Harry). Ron, and Lupin walked all the way back into the entrance hall before speaking. Then Harry turned to Lupin.

``Professor, I --'' (Lupin)

``I don't want to hear explanations,'' (Lupin)
said Lupin shortly. He (Harry) glanced around the empty entrance hall and lowered his (Harry) voice.
``I happen to know that this map was confiscated by Mr. Filch many years ago. Yes, I know it' s a map,'' (he)
he (Harry) said as Harry and Ron looked amazed.
``I don't want to know how it fell into your possession. I am, however, astounded that you didn't hand it in. Particularly after what happened the last time a student left information about the castle lying around. And I can't let you have it back, Harry.'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry had expected that, and was too keen for explanations to protest.

``Why did Snape think I'd got it from the manufacturers?'' (unknown)

``because these mapmakers would have wanted to lure you out of school. They'd think it extremely entertaining.'' (Lupin)

said Harry, impressed.

``We've met,'' (he)
he (Harry) said shortly. He (Harry) was looking at Harry more seriously than ever before.

``Don't expect me to cover up for you again, Harry. I cannot make you take Sirius Black seriously. But I would have thought that what you have heard when the dementors draw near you would have had more of an effect on you. Your parents gave their lives to keep you alive, Harry. A poor way to repay them -- gambling their sacrifice for a bag of magic tricks.'' (He)

He (Harry) walked away, leaving Harry feeling worse by far than he (Harry) had at any point in Snape's office. Slowly, he (Harry) and Ron mounted the marble staircase. As Harry passed the one-eyed witch, he (Harry) remembered the Invisibility Cloak -- it was still down there, but he (Harry) didn't dare go and get it.

said Ron abruptly.

He (Ron) broke off; they reached the corridor where the security trolls were pacing, and Hermione was walking toward them. One look at her (Hermione) face convinced Harry that she (Hermione) had heard what had happened. His (Harry) heart plummeted -- had she (Hermione) told Professor McGonagall?

``Come to have a good gloat?'' (Ron)

CHAPTER FIFTEEN

THE QUIDDITCH FINAL

He (lip) sent me this,'' Hermione said, holding out the letter.

Harry took it. The parchment was damp, and enormous teardrops had smudged the ink so badly in places that it was very difficult to read.

Dear Hermione, We lost. I'm allowed to bring him (Harry) back to Hogwarts. Execution date to be fixed. Beaky has enjoyed London. I won't forget all the help you gave us.

Hagrid

said Harry.

said Ron fiercely.

she (Hermione) sobbed.

The safety measures imposed on the students since Black's second break-in made it impossible for Harry, Ron, and Hermione to go and visit Hagrid in the evenings. Their only chance of talking to him (Ron) was during Care of Magical Creatures lessons.

He (Ron) seemed numb with shock at the verdict.

``S'all my fault. Got all tongue-tied. They was all sittin' there in black robes an' I kep' droppin' me notes and forgettin' all them dates yeh looked up fer me, Hermione. Hermione wasn't at lunch either. By the time they had finished their apple pie, the after-effects of the Cheering Charms were wearing off, and Harry and Ron had started to get slightly worried.

Harry glanced into the crystal ball but saw nothing but swirling white mist. Had Professor Trelawney really seen the Grim again? Would he (Professor)? The last thing he (Professor) needed was another near-fatal accident, with the Quidditch final drawing ever nearer.

The Easter holidays were not exactly relaxing. The third years had never had so much homework. Neville Longbottom seemed close to a nervous collapse, and he (Longbottom) wasn't the only one.

``Call this a holiday!'' (Seamus Finnigan/Seamus)
Seamus Finnigan roared at the common room one afternoon.
``The exams are ages away, what're they playing at?'' (nobody)

But nobody had as much to do as Hermione. Even without Divination, she (Hermione) was taking more subjects than anybody else. She (Hermione) was usually last to leave the common room at night, first to arrive at the library the next morning; she (Hermione) had shadows like Lupin's under her (Hermione) eyes, and seemed constantly close to tears.

Ron had taken over responsibility for Buckbeak's appeal. When he (Ron) wasn't doing his (Ron) own work, he (Ron) was poring over enormously thick volumes with names like The Handbook of Hippogriff Psychology and Fowl or Foul? A Study of Hippogriff Brutality. He (Ron) was so absorbed, he (Ron) even forgot to be horrible to Crookshanks.

Harry, meanwhile, had to fit in his (Harry) homework around Quidditch practice every day, not to mention endless discussions of tactics with Wood. The Gryffindor-Slytherin match would take place on the first Saturday after the Easter holidays. Slytherin was leading the tournament by exactly two hundred points. This meant -LRB-as Wood constantly reminded his (Wood) team-RRB- that they needed to win the match by more than that amount to win the Cup. It also meant that the burden of winning fell largely on Harry, because capturing the Snitch was worth one hundred and fifty points.

``So you must catch it only if we're more than fifty points up,'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
Wood told Harry constantly.
``Only if we're more than fifty points up, Harry, or we win the match but lose the Cup. You've got that, Haven't you? You must catch the Snitch only if we're --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

``I KNOW, OLIVER!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry yelled.

The whole of Gryffindor House was obsessed with the coming match. Gryffindor hadn't won the Quidditch Cup since the legendary Charlie Weasley -LRB-Ron's second oldest brother-RRB- had been seeker. But Harry doubted whether any of them, even Wood, wanted to win as much as he (Wood) did. The enmity between Harry and Malfoy was at its highest point ever. Malfoy was still smarting ,bout the mud-throwing incident in Hogsmeade and was even more furious that Harry had somehow wormed his (Harry) way out of punishment. Harry hadn't forgotten Malfoy's attempt to sabotage him (Harry) in the match against Ravenclaw, but it was the matter of Buckbeak that made him (Harry) most determined to beat Malfoy in front of the entire school.

Never, in anyone's memory, had a match approached in such a highly charged atmosphere. By the time the holidays were over, tension between the two teams and their Houses was at the breaking point. A number of small scuffles broke out in the corridors, culminating in a nasty incident in which a Gryffindor fourth year and a Slytherin sixth year ended up in the hospital wing with leeks sprouting out of their ears.

Harry was having a particularly bad time of it. He (Harry) couldn't walk to class without Slytherins sticking out their legs and trying to trip him (Harry) up; Crabbe and Goyle kept popping up wherever he (Crabbe) went, and slouching away looking disappointed when they saw him (Crabbe) surrounded by people. Wood had given instructions that Harry should be accompanied everywhere he (Harry) went, in case the Slytherins tried to put him (Harry) out of action. The whole of Gryffindor House took up the challenge enthusiastically, so that it was impossible for Harry to get to classes on time because he (Harry) was surrounded by a vast, chattering crowd. Harry was more concerned for his (Harry) Firebolt's safety than his (Harry) own. When he (Harry) wasn't flying it, he (Harry) locked it securely in his (Harry) trunk and frequently dashed back up to Gryffindor Tower at break times to check that it was still there.

All usual pursuits were abandoned in the Gryffindor common room the night before the match. Even Hermione had Put down her (Hermione) books.

``I can't work, I can't concentrate,'' (she)
she (Hermione) said nervously.

There was a great deal of noise. Fred and George Weasley were dealing with the pressure by being louder and more exuberant than ever. Oliver Wood was crouched over a model of a Quidditch field in the corner, prodding little figures across it with his (Wood) wand and muttering to himself Angelina, Alicia, and Katie were laughing at Fred's and George's jokes. Harry was sitting with Ron and Hermione, removed from the center of things, trying not to think about the next day, because every time he (Harry) did, he (Harry) had the horrible sensation that something very large was fighting to get out of his (Harry) stomach.

``You're going to be fine,'' (Hermione/HERMIONE)
Hermione told him (Harry), though she (Hermione) looked positively terrified.

``You've got a Firebolt!'' (Ron)
said Ron.

``Yeah...'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
said Harry, his (Harry) stomach writhing.

It came as a relief when Wood suddenly stood up and yelled,

``Team! Bed!'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)

Harry slept badly. First he (Harry) dreamed that he (Harry) had overslept, and that Wood was yelling,

``Where were you? We had to use Neville instead!'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
Then he (Wood) dreamed that Malfoy and the rest of the Slytherin team arrived for the match riding dragons. He (Malfoy) was flying at breakneck speed, trying to avoid a spurt of flames from Malfoy's steed's mouth, when he (Malfoy) realized he (Malfoy) had forgotten his (Malfoy) Firebolt. He (Malfoy) fell through the air and woke with a start.

It was a few seconds before Harry remembered that the match hadn't taken place yet, that he (Harry) was safe in bed, and that the Slytherin team definitely wouldn't be allowed to play on dragons. He (Harry) was feeling very thirsty. Quietly as he (Harry) could, he (Harry) got out of his (Harry) four-poster and went to pour himself some water from the silver jug beneath the window.

The grounds were still and quiet. No breath of wind disturbed the treetops in the Forbidden Forest; the Whomping Willow was motionless and innocent-looking. It looked as though the conditions for the match would be perfect.

Harry set down his (Harry) goblet and was about to turn back to his (Harry) bed when something caught his (Harry) eye. An animal of some kind was prowling across the silvery lawn.

Harry dashed to his (Harry) bedside table, snatched up his (Harry) glasses, and put them on, then hurried back to the window. It couldn't be the Grim -- not now -- not right before the match -

He (Grim) peered out at the grounds again and, after a minute's frantic searching, spotted it. It was skirting the edge of the forest now... It wasn't the Grim at all ... it was a cat... Harry clutched the window ledge in relief as he (Harry) recognized the bottlebrush tail. It was only Crookshanks...

Or was it only Crookshanks? Harry squinted, pressing his (Harry) nose flat against the glass. Crookshanks seemed to have come to a halt. Harry was sure he (Harry) could see something else moving in the shadow of the trees too.

And just then, it emerged -- a gigantic, shaggy black dog, moving stealthily across the lawn, Crookshanks trotting at its side. Harry stared. What did this mean? If Crookshanks could see the dog as well, how could it be an omen of Harry's death?

``Ron!'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)
Harry hissed.
``Ron! Wake up!'' (unknown)

``Huh?'' (I)

I need you to tell me if you can see something!''

``S'all dark, Harry,'' (Ron)

``What're you or, about?'' (unknown)

``Down here --'' (Harry/Potter/Harry Potter)

Harry looked quickly back out of the window.

Crookshanks and the dog had vanished. Harry climbed onto the windowsill to look right down into the shadows of the castle, but they weren't there. Where had they gone?

A loud snore told him (Harry) Ron had fallen asleep again.

Harry and the rest of the Gryffindor team entered the Great Hall the next day to enormous applause. Harry couldn't help grinning broadly as he (Harry) saw that both the Ravenclaw and Hufflepuff tables were applauding them too. The Slytherin table hissed loudly as they passed. Harry noticed that Malfoy looked even paler than usual.

Wood spent the whole of breakfast urging his (Harry) team to eat, while touching nothing himself Then he (Harry) hurried them off to the field before anyone else had finished, so they could get an idea of the conditions. As they left the Great Hall, everyone applauded again.

``Good luck, Harry!'' (Cho/Cho Chang/Chang)
called Cho. Harry felt himself blushing.

``Okay -- no wind to speak of -- sun's a bit bright, that could impair your vision, watch out for it -- ground's fairly hard, good, that'll give us a fast kickoff --'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)

Wood paced the field, staring around with the team behind him (Harry). Finally, they saw the front doors of the castle open in the distance and the rest of the school spilling onto the lawn.

``Locker rooms,'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)
said Wood tersely.

None of them spoke as they changed into their scarlet robes. Harry wondered if they were feeling like he (Harry) was: as though he (Harry)'d eaten something extremely wriggly for breakfast. In what seemed like no time at all, Wood was saying,

``Okay, it's time, let's go --'' (Wood/Oliver/Oliver Wood)

They walked out onto the field to a tidal wave of noise. Threequarters of the crowd was wearing scarlet rosettes, waving scarlet flags with the Gryffindor lion upon them, or brandishing banners with slogans like

``GO GRYFFINDOR!'' (Gryffindor)
and ``LIONS FOR THE CUK' Behind the Slytherin goal posts, however, two hundred people were wearing green; the silver serpent of Slytherin glittered on their flags, and Professor Snape sat in the very front row, wearing green like everyone else, and a very grim smile.

from the Slytherin end.

``Captains, shake hands!'' (Madam Hooch)
said Madam Hooch.
